description:
Got dropped off here right after the brewery yesterday. I texted my cousin when I was in the Castro where to go for drinks and he didn't respond until we went back to the Dogpatch. And he was there with my other cousins and some friends.

So my bestie and I joined them while they were finishing up dinner and oh man the food was really good. And I love their side dishes. I killed that Korean pancake, the noodles were good, the dumplings, and the rice cake too.

I like the interior: very warm and bright.

It was my first time here. My cousins have been there more just because they're always in Japantown and one of their friends owns the place.

But I genuinely liked it for the things I tried.
author: Lilian L.

description:
doobu:

experience: came here at around 9 pm because we had a movie to watch at 11. there was not a long wait (they just needed to clean the tables) but we had a group of 9 and had to split up 5+4. 

in japantown you would expect us to eat japanese food but came around this korean place and decided to try it out. the beef was pretty good but the dinner food is quite pricy. if you are in need of some good korean food this place is just average. 

service: only okay, we had to wait maybe 20 minutes to get the check
author: Denise M.

description:
I had to update my review after today's experience. 
After watching the Dubs beat the Cavs in the Finals Game 1 next door (whooo!), we decided to eat at Doobu considering it was 9pm, not many other options nearby, and I've always loved their soon doobu (past tense now). Side note, I brought 4 others who were all first timers and were really excited after I told them about it. Now, I used to dine here frequently from 2011-2013 and by frequently I mean twice per week. Why? I was always happy with their quality of food, service, and price point. I came so often that walking through their front door always gave me such a warm feeling of nostalgia.
Today's food was still good (would have been a 1 star review if not for the food). However, service was just HORRENDOUS. We arrived just shortly after 9pm, like 5 minutes past. We were a group of 6 and there were only 2 other parties dining. We took about 5-10 minutes to decide what to order. That gave us 45 mins still to enjoy our food and pay before they close at 10pm. Our food came out quickly, but the server was very pushy trying to rush us to finish and leave. Soon doobu is a quick meal, it definitely wouldn't have taken us 45 mins to finish. Not only was there this awkward tension in the air, but she even limited our banchan refills!!!! They give 5 different types of banchan in a small dish. After our second time asking for a refill of banchan, she said "you guys already had 2 refills". Now remember, we were a table of 6. The size of those banchan dishes only gave 1 small bite per person. If anything, we had a party of 6 who ordered 6 separate meals and should be allowed 5 refills because logically if we all sat separately we would have each had our own set of banchan. We still tipped despite everything, but I just felt so disappointed and cheated of our money.
I felt guilty for recommending Doobu to my friends. 
This experience just left a very sour taste in all of our mouths. I had some great memories and amazing meals in the past. And now, they will only remain a thing of the past. You won't be seeing any of us dining here again. Next time, the short drive to Tofu House will be well worth it.
It's just not what it used to be. Bring back the old Doobu I so fondly remember!
author: Stephanie L.

description: The food tasted awesome. The service was good too. I wouldn't mind coming back again if I wanted Korean food.
author: Chong C.

description: If you like packaged spicy Korean ramen this is the best place to go. Their squid bibimbap is ok.
author: Elle B.

description:
You can never fully trust the Yelp ratings of an Asian joint... Sometimes the bad reviews are based on poor service, which c'mon is what you normally expect with Asian spots... But I'm sad to report that this place was a miss in the food department for me.

I give it three stars for the friendly staff but the food was a two star joint in my book. To me, I should've waited in line at the surrounding restaurants as there was a reason this place was empty.

Table of three we all ordered soondubu at medium spicy. At $11.95 a bowl, it was glorified flavored water for broth with no heat whatsoever. Staff brought out a lot of spice flavors for us to add to our bowls which helped but it wasn't a positively memorable dish. 

Banchan was pretty lackluster as well. Very few to begin with but also very little in each dish. 

Kimchi was good though, I like the purple rice, and staff were friendly. That's the positives otherwise I wont be going back anytime soon.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Used to come here a bunch a few years back. Honestly, they were my fav soondubu spot, during that period of time. The wait across the road for the ramen joints were out of control tonight, so the buds and I decided on Doobu instead (no wait at 8pm). 

I was talking this spot up, thinking the quality of food was the same as what I remembered from all those visits. Sadly, it was not. 

I ordered the seafood soondubu. From first sip into the soup, the flavors were completely bland. Terribly bland that my friend had to ask for more spices. It seriously tasted like water that was barely flavored. I usually opt for mild, and even went medium today, thinking I could use a kick. Unfortunately, there was none. At all. In addition to the soup, the purple rice was slightly undercooked. I like my rice pebbled, but the rice tonight was just too hard. And no, it wasn't bc it was purple rice and it tastes that way. It shouldn't be that hard. 

Anywho, the banchans were meh. Nothing spectacular. Nothing disgusting. The rice tea was good. The service was alright. All in all, would I come back again? Probably not anymore. I'll end this with 3 stars for all the previous yrs of better soondubu...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Amazing hot tofu soup! 

Funny location, among the Japanese restaurants across the street from the Japan Center. My friend and I shared a plate of spicy pork and the dumpling soon tofu, medium spicy. Our meal came with all the sides, from kimchi and picked daikon radish to perfectly seasoned seaweed. The pot of tofu soup came out bubbling hot and was delicious. Really reasonable prices too! Highly recommend.
author: Anny C.

description: We had the chicken bibimbap and it was great! Nice little spot that we came to for Sunday dinner. Their spicy sauce was the perfect addition but not required.
author: Karan C.

description:
It was during an event and I would say every restaurant was pretty packed. This place was surprisingly not. Since we don't like to wait for a long period of time, we decided to try this place out. 

We ordered soon du bu and something else I can't remember. Which is sad because good food makes me remember stuff. The food wasn't bad, but it also wasn't great. Would I go here again? If other restaurants are too booked, yes I would. This place wouldn't be my first choice to go eat though. Also the service was slow for it not being busy.

Hard to compete with the other Korean places here like yakiniQ and the other newer KBBQ place called beque inside the Japan town center.
author: Jade L.

description:
Decent tasting tofu stew in a homey, family restaurant setting. I often come here whenever I have a specific craving as it's pretty accessible in Japantown. Food gets a 3.5 from me, given the attentive service and good prices for the stews.

Menu items range from all different kinds of tofu stews and standard Korean dishes such as bibimbap, galbi, etc. In my opinion the best deal is the tofu stew as they'll run you about $12 and are significantly cheaper than the other menu items which start around $15-20+. I don't see why this restaurant doesn't just narrow down their offering as there are a surprising amount of different kinds of stews you can choose from, such as dumpling, seafood, corned beef, etc. It's easy to find something that will satisfy most peoples needs.

Note that the spicy levels are pretty mild, so if you're really into spiciness, ask for the maximum. From what people tell me, medium spicy just makes the dish flavorful.

Food came out pretty quickly for us, and the restaurant never seems too busy during the afternoon so it's easy to walk in. I love that the waiters offer spacious seating in the booths even if you're only coming with 1-2 other people.

Vegetable Tofu Stew - Comes with a good amount of fresh banchan, purple rice and an egg. Pretty average, nothing out of the ordinary and satisfies my needs. 

For the prices given the location in SF, I'm not complaining!
author: Chelsea W.

description: A friend of mine found a roach about a year ago. We stopped going since then. Went back today after a year to try it again. Guess what? ANOTHER ROACH. Also found a bug crawling around my other friend's dish... Beware. Always check what's in your soup or just don't go....
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I can't stop thinking about their kimchi. I wish I could buy it in bulk. I asked the waitress if they made it themselves and she proudly said "yes" and that the kimchi was similar to winter kimchi in South Korea. She also told me a story about how her mom used to make kimchi growing up in South Korea during the winter and bury it underground to ferment because they didn't have a refrigerator. 

I also really like their kimchi fried rice, which is what keeps me coming back. Their spicy fried chicken wings are also really yummy. I can't eat soy so I can't say anything about their tofu soups. 

There's only one waitress that works here and I actually feel really bad for her when the restaurant gets really busy, but she does her best. She's also really sweet. :)
author: K. E.

description:
Ordered the galbi and tofu soup combo. The galbi was average and soup was average too. Banchan was terrible!
They did have really good purple rice.
Service was just ok.
author: Janice K.

description:
I realized that Yelp ratings in San Francisco are not always accurate. Doobu is an excellent Korean restaurant.

We got the spicy pork bibimbap and the beef soon tofu for dinner. We came late at night so the place wasn't crowded. The spicy pork bibimbap was great. They give ample food and they're not cheap with their meat at all. The beef soon tofu was also amazing. I was craving Korean soup and this definitely satisfied my craving. Their side dishes were decent.

The service was great. The lady was very kind and fast in bringing out the food & whatever else we needed.

I'm not sure why this place has low ratings, but Doobu is a GREAT Korean restaurant. If you're looking to get your Korean food fix, check out Doobu! I'm Korean and I can vouch that their food tastes great/authentic :) If I'm around the area again and am craving Korean food, I will definitely come here.

Lastly, their prices are so cheap. I wouldn't expect these prices in SF, but Doobu's prices are extremely reasonable.

Parking: We were able to find street parking, but there is a parking structure for Japantown, which I believe costs money.
author: Jen S.

description:
Came here last night for a friend's Bday dinner, and it was quite tasty! Place is a bit hidden in the middle of the little plaza area between Sutter and Post, and is rather tiny inside as well. For a weekend evening, this place was surprisingly empty, with only a few tables occupied during our entire dining experience.  The service itself was very friendly and efficient, with the food coming out at a fairly quick pace for the most part. 

The few things that I remembered us ordering were:

-Seafood pancake: DELICOUS! Definitely a must get!
-Beef Tofu Hot Pot: Goes REALLY well with a bowl of rice. We ordered it with medium spicy but it tasted more like mild. If you like spicy, might want to order it at the Spicy level.
-Spicy Rice Cake: Another delicious dish! The chewiness was perfect and the spiciness added the perfect kick.
-Spicy Beef: This one was only ok. Not really spicy at all and is definitely passable.
-Beef Bibimbap: A staple of any Korean restaurant. Don't think you can go wrong with any of the different flavors.
-Galbi: A bit chewy, but pretty well marinated. 

Would definitely not mind stopping by here again in the near future!
author: Alex C.

description:
The cat and his wolf wandered into doobu on a whim. With the woof never having tried Korean food before, I decided that the time was now, and we stepped paw into doobu for the first time. 

I have gone to many Korean restaurants and for the most part, all of them share a menu that is fairly similar. Doobu definitely has a lot of the same options you would see at your local standard Korean restaurant, but a few unique things here and there. 

The two of us decided to share a plate of bulgogi which of course comes with all those wonderful sides that all are used to at Korean restaurants. 

Service here on a Friday night was a bit on the slow side, which made sense as it was getting busier and busier as the night wore on. But that said, our waitress was very friendly and polite. 

Now the food? Very good flavor! Beef was nice and tender, sides were awesome, my only gripe was that some of the onions were barely cooked in the bulgogi plate. Not much an issue but would have liked if it was a bit more cooked and not almost totally raw. Meat though was perfect :3 

Overall, A-ok place at a decently fair price. 
Worth a shot if you are in the area! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description: I was really disappointed in the portions, quality, price and customer service. I ordered the Korean bbq for lunch but they charged me $55 for the dinner menu and it was noontime.They had some nonsensical explanation for why they couldn't give me the lunch special during lunch. They said we never serve lunch on sundays. It seems like they are trying to mislabel their prices and give you much less food for way more money. They definitely cheated me on this one. They said everyone knows that the google menu prices aren't accurate. I tried to eat the food and it was not good unfortunately. For $55 I really expected more flavor and quality but the meat was not good. It's very sad that we have dishonest and misleading merchants that we cannot trust to do a good job and provide decent meals. This restaurant made a dent in my wallet and in my mother's day. So sad. Be smart and spend your hard earned money elsewhere.
author: Petunia A.

description: Favorite place for soft tofu soup and small plates that come with every meal, kimchi, seaweed salad, fermented bean sprouts
author: Jane G.

description:
I've gone to this place for years and have consistently enjoyed their lunch specials. Their lunch special comes at a affordable price and is very well portioned, looks like a bento box with soup, salad, rice, protein, and side dishes. All super delicious!

The service is good even when it is busy and the food comes out pretty fast. I highly recommend this place if you're looking for a good lunch spot as this really is a steal. 

Dinner is a different story though, the pricing for dinner is on par like most Korean places which to me is expensive, if you have an option to go during the lunch special, then it is highly recommended. 

Lunch special is usually from 11:30AM-3:00PM. Does get really crowded too. There is a parking lot across the street in Japan town if you can't find street parking.
author: Brian H.

description:
We just stumbled on this restaurant.   Most noodle places were crowded and we were looking for something different.  If you like tofu, this is the place.   We had the hot pots, they were done perfectly.  Our meals stayed nice and hot throughout the dinner and the rice cooked perfectly because of the pot.
Service was excellent,  the food was tasty and the shochu was good.
We will definitely return....
author: Rayna V.

description:
I like it here!! I usually go to Arang for korean food cuz it's literally right below my apartment, but this place is worth the walk for good Soondobu soup. It comes with egg! And cheese! And purple rice!

Note: I'm not korean so I can't comment on its authenticity. I just know the options are generous, as are the portions. and the flavors are distinct. Worth trying!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Local Korean Style Cooking right in Japan Town.. 

Been Glued into Tofu Salad , Mild Spicy Seafood Soup, Bulgogi and Beef Pancake..

This place has simple menu ... Their service is like I'm in Seoul.. Nice experience ..

No problem at all .. I'll keep coming back to this place side from the proximity to my condo...
author: Donovan L.

description:
If there's a menu item in the restaurant name, then that's what you should stick to ordering.

I really like this place. I've been here over 5 times, and I've been satisfied 90% of the time. Why? Because those 90% of the time, I ordered soondubu. The price is just right, the banchan is plentiful and fresh, and it's just delicious. They have various spice levels, though I think they tend to hold back a little.

What about the 10%? Well, for my last visit, my boyfriend and I went for galbi + soondubu combo and crispy chicken (I thought it was Korean Fried Chicken, but it wasn't :( ). The dumpling soondubu was just as good as the other soondubus I've had. Unfortunately, the galbi and chicken fell short. The galbi was dry, not juicy or tender at all. A little overcooked. There wasn't a lot of sauce or flavor on it either. The chicken was okay, and tasted like if you combined popcorn chicken with hot wings. 

This place does soondubu SO WELL, so I advise you to stick to that. The other items, eh. I think they should narrow down their menu to allow for more focus on certain items. I'll update this review whenever I go again :)
author: Jacquelyn T.

description:
I completely agree that the service is terrible here. We came here during dinner time and there's no other customers in the restaurant. I was pretty surprised but I guess I know why now. Anyways the staff wouldn't let us order the combo to share and insisted we both order a entree. But we were not hungry at all. And the food was expensive and wasn't worth that price...
Throughout the entire time we received terrible service that I would give 0 star. I will not come back.
author: Daniel W.

description: I came here with my friends on a Tuesday around 12:15ish and the place was pretty empty so we were seated immediately. The menu consists of typical Korean food: tofu soups, bibimbaps, and meats. I ordered a kimchi tofu soup with beef (mild, since I can't handle the spiciness that well). They gave us banchan as well, which consisted of fish cake, pickled radish and carrots, some leafy greens, kimchi, and some root veggie that I'm not quite sure what it was. I wish they gave us more variety of banchan, but that depends on the restaurant so I was a little disappointed in that. The food came out quickly, and the spiciness level of the tofu soup was just right. My friend ordered hers to be extra spicy, and she said it wasn't that spicy, but maybe she has a high tolerance for spiciness. The soup was delicious, though there was more tofu that soup, making it kinda like a lumpy mush and less like soup, but it was still delicious nonetheless. The only main downside was the lighting, it was kinda dark in the restaurant, I'm not sure if it was the color the walls were painted or if it was the lighting, but it was kind of dim and dark. The service was quick and efficient, and I would come back if I'm in the area.
author: Lisa C.

description:
As a vegetarian, there are certain things you kind of give up trying unless you're ready to make it yourself, even if you have no clue what it's supposed to taste like. In my case it's Filipino and Korean. Or at least it was, since the Korean bit is covered at Doobu! They can make most of their dishes vegetarian, and already have a veggie version of pretty much every option. Even though that means their soup is made with water instead of beef stock,  it's not losing any flavor! The soft tofu soup is my favorite, followed by the dubukki rice cakes. The gochujang chili paste mix isn't so sweet like at other places, so my Mexican sensibilities aren't put off when I take a bite :) 
Pro tip: spring for the cheese on top of the spicy bits, its worth the $1 :d
author: Astrid V.

description:
The service here is so great! My friend had to go take a phone call and so her food went cold. The lady was very nice to warm it back up for her. She also brought out more side dishes for us as she could tell what our favorites were! Food was great too. Would definitely recommend to others.

I ordered A4 (spicy rice cakes) and my friend ordered T11 (tofu soup).
author: Isabelle B.

description:
The service is ridiculous here. I've eaten here before in the past and the food is ok. However they close the place down before their close times. I specifically called them earlier to confirm they'll be open at 9 and I come and they are closed telling me they are open at 9:30 but they close at 9. 

If you're a restaurant, no reason for the place to be open till 9:30 if you don't intend to service anyone. This is the 3rd time this has occurred. Never coming here again! Completely ridiculous!!!

The food is ok but for the experience and the level of service, do yourself a favor and go somewhere else!
author: Bobby K.

description: I've been to Doobu twice now and had their fish roe bibambop each time. Their fish roe bibambop is by far my favorite here. It is a combination of brown rice, an array of vegetables, and the different colored fish roe served in a sizzling bowl. The spicy sauce is optional and you can add as much as your heart desires. The seafood pancake is also very good. They serve it with a sweet vinegary soy sauce which complements it very well. The waitress referred to it as the "Korean pizza". Haha Other than that, I've also had their spicy pork. They are very generous about their side dishes and refilling them so I suggest leaving an extra tip for them. The restaurant is very cozy with booths on one side and tables on the other. The staff is phenomenal and knows how to make you feel right at home.
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Service was a little slow on a weekday, even though it was nearly empty. Food was decent; I got the lunch combo with bulgogi. The soup that came with it was a spicy seafood soup w tofu. It was delicious. The bulgogi felt a little plain, and had way too much onions which was almost half of it. Prices were fair. 
Would probably try again if in the area
author: M C.

description: If you haven't had any Korean food, this place would be a good place to start. It's not very perfect but, meh, just fine. I like side menu anyway. I recommend to have bibimbop here.
author: Changmin L.

description: Very average food. Seafood pancake was basically just flour and water and a couple tiny shrimps and clams. Tofu soup with shrimps was not great either. Bulgogi was ok..
author: Beatrice E.

description:
This is a great Korean restaurant in the heart of Japantown.  My favorites here include the pajeon and albap.  I really like that you can get organic soymilk here: It's perfect for washing down all the spicy food!  When I've come here for lunch it's pretty empty, but I'm sure it gets much busier later in the day.  

My only lamentation with Doobu is the music: I always come in with the hopes of hearing SES or Yoo Seung Jun, but instead I'm greeted with Pitbull and Taylor Swift.  I won't remove a star for that, though.
author: Virgo A.

description: The spicy squid bibimbop was the worst I ever had. I used to come here for only this dish, but today It was so dry that I was almost eating smoked dry squid from market. Top of that the waitress was not committing that it's not fresh one and very rude to us.  I bet all Korean know how fresh daily made squid dish taste and look like. This restaurant, not only food is really not for Korean cuisine standard, also the service is the worst. If you don't want to waste your time and your appetites, please don't goto this restaurant. I am all for supporting Korean restaurant in Bay Area, for sure not this restaurant.
author: Lina S.

description:
Doobu looks the part.

It has a nice atmosphere, and genuinely nice service. As a matter of fact there are no complaints about the service whatsoever.

As for the food, it isn't bad, but don't expect to get your money's worth whatsoever.

We ordered the galbi+dumpling soup combo, and a half order of the chicken wings.

First things first, the fishcake and seaweed banchan were really good. That is kinda where it ends for me.

Galbi: The galbi was decently cooked, it was a little bit on the red side and tough for the S/O. The problem for me was that it really didn't seem like it was marinated/sweet enough. You could definitely taste the seasoning, but it just didn't stick The galbi is eh/OK, this one didn't leave me salivating. I LOVE GALBI EVEN GHETTO GALBII, so it's a bit of a disappointment.

Dumpling Soup: The soup was ok, I'm not a big fan of tofu soup anyways, but she definitely is. She liked the soup PASS

Wings: The chicken wings honestly tasted like your average salt & pepper wings doused with some korean style sauce. In her words "It's more like BBQ wings." They kinda sucked, and they aren't double fried as korean-style usually indicates. SKIP

Also, our straw had a manufacturing defect and it isn't there fault, but given that the straw was unwrapped, you'd think they noticed.

Honestly though, what's a good atmospheric restaurant if the food is meh and costs an arm and a leg? I've had better galbi at cheap places that cost $10 less than it would here.

This place is meh.
author: Peter N.

description: One of the best Korean restaurants I ate at (and it's in Japantown)!  I've been here twice and I would definitely go back more times.  The first time we ordered kal-bi, spicy rice cake, and the korean pancake.  The second time we ordered tofu soup and the mandoo.  It was so delicious!!  Although the customer service is lacking, I have to give them credit because there weren't much workers.  You do have to be patient for your food.  Highly recommend this place!
author: Mikayla M.

description: We stopped in here on a cold, rainy Fourth of July holiday weekend, and many of the nearby restaurants were closed. Doobu, however, was serving up soon tofu, beautiful bubbling cauldrons of goodness, and it was delicious. I had the beef soon tofu, with all its requisite sides, and it was amazing. My gf had the fried tofu salad, which was also delicious. Definitely recommended. Good atmosphere, good service. Definitely recommended!
author: Ken L.

description:
This is my first review. I wrote this because I was too angry with this restaurant. I want to give them zero star if I can rate it 0.
As a Korean, it was a TERRIBLE restaurant. The waitress was not that friendly. And they brought me wrong food. So I told them I ordered another one, but they treated me like I made a mistake.
We ordered seafood soon tofu and spicy squid bibimbab, but the taste was TERRRIBLE!! Squid tasted like rotten socks.......I think the ingredient was NOT fresh. They even didn't apologize to us, and they just said there was some problem and they will not charge for it. They didn't apologize at all!! The worst taste and service.
It was totally not worth it to pay around $30! Even the side dishes tasted terrible.......it was the WORST korean restaurant I've ever been in usa.
author: Seowon Y.

description:
After my afternoon shopping at Nijiya Market and various shops at the Japantown "mall" I needed lunch.

I stopped in to this little restaurant and had a seat in a booth. 

After I ordered the server returned with a plate that held a still sizzling and popping litte fried whole fish. I suspect it was yellow croaker. 

Then the banchan and my purple rice came. Oh I was so happy! 

..and then the pancake and jjigae. I was in seafood heaven. 

I probably looked insane with a table full of food all to myself and anyone who knows me knows how little I actually eat. 

They were happy to feed me and I was more than delighted to enjoy their hospitality. 

The only bad thing that they lose a star? It was so danged hot and they did not have air conditioning or even a fan so I was sweating from heat and sweating from the super spicy jjigae I ordered. 

Aside from that I had a lovely lunch that easily could have fed 4 people at a price that reflected only one diner. 

Thank you Doobu. I ate very well!

I will return ...we both know I have been here many, many times before :)
author: Jennifer C P.

description: great food, great service, great prices. Tofu and spicy pork we're both par excellent
author: Bryan K.

description: The food seemed like authentic Korean without all the jazz. Presentation isn't the strongest feature but the vibe and taste is very traditional and homely. I wouldn't take first time visitors to SF here, but it's worth trying at least once if you're exploring the area.
author: Dion L.

description:
Doobu is located in the middle of Japantown, which is a little ironic, but cutely quaint. Seating is mostly booth, but there are a few tables as well. When I went with a friend on a weekday for lunch, there was a decent stream of customers but only one waitress. She was super chipper and energetic though, running around to all the tables and keeping up quite nicely with the lunch rush. 

They have a lunch special selection as well as a regular dinner menu, and we ordered one item from each to try it out. The regular dinner menu comes with side dishes in the little platters, while the lunch special comes in a bento box with fewer side dishes already planned into the bento.

Side dishes:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#3odl1vIAIbx4JDNRG1IfEg)
The side dishes were pretty standard, with pickled seaweed, marinated bean sprouts, sliced fish cake, kimchi, and pickled radish slivers. There was also a fried yellow croaker (I believe?), which was a nice addition. I thought the kimchi was a little lackluster compared to other Korean restaurants I've been to, but I liked the pickled seaweed because of its acidity. The fried fish was okay, a little cold and not crunchy anymore since it'd been sitting around for a bit after being fried. 

Seafood soft tofu soup (mild):
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#fKy9pVB7RjjSDNNGjw86Zw)
This soft tofu soup wasn't bad, but it wasn't the best I've ever had. It's hard for any soft tofu to measure up to SGD Tofu House, but there was a generous amount of seafood in this. There were small shrimp, clams, and oysters. The flavor was just mediocre though, maybe a little bland.

Purple rice:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#j7X3LZIXSIyxJOOgQaADRg)
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#a-q80BNeQSqvtaloEKA0Og)
I appreciated that the rice came with a lid to keep it warm, but the kernels were a little hard in my opinion. I love the purple rice that's a signature of Korean restaurants, and I always look forward to the contrast of the softer kernels of white rice and the crunchier texture of the purple. I didn't really get that here.

Combination soft tofu soup (lunch special portion):
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#PiP0dNxCy774spxmT1-r4g)
The lunch special came with a bowl of combination soft tofu soup, medium spiciness. The level of spiciness cannot be altered because they premake it, and I did not notice any seafood or beef within the soup despite it being listed as combination. The flavor was similar to that of seafood soft tofu soup, not unpleasant, but a little bland. The spiciness had a kick to it, but it wasn't unbearable. 

Galbi (lunch special portion):
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/doobu-san-francisco?select=CoCYbh9-xgv7W1kOUnRLtg#X77erU_M0KGo-inviLx-sw)
This was probably my favorite part of the whole meal. I got the lunch special with galbi, marinated beef short ribs. The marinade was pretty good, although a little too sweet. The grill on the ribs was good, and the meat was chewy yet tender. The pieces were a bit on the fatty side though, especially near the bone.

Overall, this place wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd return specifically. Nothing really stood out, and while prices weren't unreasonable, I think there's better fare out there at similar pricing.
author: Maggie X.

description:
"Doobu" is short for "soon doobu," or Korean Soft Tofu stew, which is what this place is known for, duh! I came here last Sunday with some friends to eat and hang out after church. I was also feeling a bit under the weather so hot spicy soondoobu was EXACTLY what I needed. Ahhhhh.

SETTING
-In Japantown. There are tons of little restaurants sprawled out all over here. Doobu is located in the middle of the alley in this part of Buchanan. 
-Medium sized restaurant; they have plenty of booths and table space. It was Sunday around 12:30pm and the restaurant wasn't crowded at all. We had a group of 9 people and they quickly accommodated us all by pulling up another table

FOOD
-Combination Soon Tofu. I always go for the combination since it gives you the best of everything: beef, shrimp, oyster, clam! 
-If you're looking for spicy, get the highest level - SPICY. I browsed a few reviews before ordering and good thing because several people noted that their mild spice level soups weren't that spicy. My soup was really red but it hit the spot. My bf also ordered spicy and his soup ended up being orange and tasted bland. Either they mixed up his order or the amount of red powder they put in varies... 
-Panchan and little fried fish for each person as a starter :)
author: Grace J.

description:
Underrated in my opinion - very good Korean food for San Francisco! It's a little on the pricier side of what I'm used to. For 4 people food and alcohol with tax and tip came out to $130. Service was really friendly and attentive.

The menu was huge! The seafood Korean pancake (~$18) was one of my favorite items. It is a thinner crispier pancake than other places I've been to but it's so delicious especially with the sweet salty sauce. The dumpling tofu soup ($11) was amazing! Note the spiciness levels are a bit high. Medium spice level was already really spicy for the people in my group that love spice and can handle it well.

The galbi was spot on. Very tender, flavorful and a reasonable serving size plate of ribs. The bibimbap was good but nothing out of the ordinary. Lastly the beef japchae (glass noodles) was delicious. I enjoyed every dish we tried!
author: Linda X.

description:
The food quality at this place has gone down a lot. So did the service. First time I came here was back in 2008 and I remember the food was fresh and delicious. They served fried fish too. There were about 2-3 servers working there and the service was decent. Last time I visited must be back in 2011 if not earlier and we always liked the food. 

Today we went again and it's by far the most disappointing experience. There was only 1 person working everything from taking orders, delivering dishes, serving tables and swiping credit cards on a busy Saturday night. Our appetizers were sitting on the counter for quite a while and the waitress chose to make us wait. The appetizer size has gone a lot smaller and No more fried fish! The tea tasted like they mistakenly used a coffee pot to make hot tea. During the whole dinner, the server didn't even bother to swing by to check on us. Of course, she had too much to do. We had to wave her 3 times to get the check because she kept on ignoring us. We ended up paying cash WITHOUT any tip because she doesn't deserve any. Will not come back here again. Very disappointed.
author: Bob H.

description: It's hard in Japantown to find a solid vegetarian menu. They have many items to choose from - I got the vegetarian potstickers (very rare to find!) which were at the perfect sweet spot of spice and flavor. I also got fried firm tofu with a variety of mushrooms and vegetables - it had a delicious sauce and was flavorful. My partner got a combo hot pot and was plenty pleased with his dish too.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Food (3/5): I got the dumpling soondobu with extra broccoli, which came with a side of purple rice. A little bit on the watery side, but maybe my fault for asking for mild haha. Pretty satisfying overall. 

My bf got the hote stone beef bibimbap, and he thought it was okay - not as many toppings as other places, and the stone pot wasn't hot enough to crisp up the rice on the bottom.

Banchan was hit or miss - some dishes were great, other dishes weren't as fresh. Free refills, though!

Service (3.5/5): The server was kinda rude when I asked her to add extra vegetables to the soondobu, but other than that service was fine. We got refills of water and banchan when we asked for them! 

Value (3/5): A little bit pricey considering the ingredients and portion size. I think for 2 of us it was almost $40 total.

Not the best Korean place in the area, but pretty solid for tofu soups!
author: Abby S.

description: My go to place when I want tofu soup for lunch on Saturdays when My Tofu House isn't open. They are never fully packed so I've always been seated quickly. In my first two visits I always get the medium spicy seafood tofu soup. The flavor is decent and there is a good amount of shrimp, clam, and oysters. On my most recent visit, there was something terribly wrong with my tofu soup. My tofu were all in tiny chunks and pieces and the texture was more like cheese than soft tofu. The soup tasted watered down as well. I asked the waitress if they changed suppliers and she said they made it using the same ingredients as before. I compared the pictures I had from my previous visit and they look completely different. I really wanted to like this place but I will stay away for now until they fix their tofu issue.
author: Michu B.

description:
The food is pretty good. I had dor-so bi-bim-bap (fried rice), garbi, sea food tofu soup.
Went on Saturday at 7:30 and was crowded.
Good service as well!
author: Kim K.

description:
Korean food is hard to find in the city and this is one of the only korean tofu places I know that is not out in richmond or sunset. I think the prices here are higher than south bay or farther out, but the food is still decent. I ordered their galbi x tofu combo which came out to $30 post tip & tax. I must've been extremely hungry, but I ate all of it and wanted more. 

The staff is super nice because we miscommunicated about the order and they made me a whole new tofu soup. I'd come here again, next time I want korean food but don't want to travel far distances.
author: Annie Z.

description:
The atmosphere was the first thing i noticed here. It wasn't too stuffy nor did it have dim lighting like other places do. It was a pretty welcoming environment and the servers were very attrntive and friendly as well. We came on a thursday late afternoon and it didn't get too busy until after we were about to leave. 

The thing i like most about this place is the tofu soup combos that are priced pretty reasonably. The seafood tofu soup was nothing better than my tofu house my still pretty good. However their salmon teriyaki was delightfully made and was the perfect portion. I adding this because some places the salmon can be tasteless or overcookedand they give you the smallest piece ever. 

Overall, its a great place to satisfy korean food cravings after exploring Japantown in sf :)
author: Nessa R.

description:
Surprisingly, there are not many good korean restaurants in the city. This one restaurant was nearby and had the best reviews so my friend and I gave it a shot. I was very satisfied with the food! 

Ordered: dumping soon tofu - was super good! Definitely satisfied my craving. I was happy because it also came with a fried fish beforehand! 

The Banchan was good too!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
Lunch special is off the chain. So much food for 10 bucks. 
Soondobu is extra fishy and not too salty. Quality traditional taste.
Service is friendly and fast!
author: Chris L.

description:
Came during lunch time on a Friday. It wasn't too packed. 

The lunch special is a pretty good deal. For about $10 you get tofu soup, salad with tofu, sides of kimchi, eggplant salad, brown rice, and your choice of meat. Its a really good deal. 

The food tasted pretty good, the tofu soup was decent and had a slight kick to it. The salad was actually very good, especially the fried tofu they put on top of it. The meat was pretty fresh too. My GF had the short ribs, and it wasn't too salty. It lacked a little flavor, but the meat was actually pretty tender. I had the bulogi and mine was really flavorful. Each tofu soup has a shrimp in it, I don't recommend eating it. 

This is a good place to grab lunch for pretty cheap. You get a lot of different sides things on the lunch special and food came out very fast and service was good. If I worked in the area I would probably be a regular.
author: Allen C.

description: I'm really happy that my wife and chose to dine here. It's quaint, casual and affordable. We chose the Bibimpap...VERY NICE! The service was great considering there were only two people doing all the floor work.. they worked hard!
author: Michael V.

description: Probably the worst Korean food I've ever had and the service absolutely sucks too. That's why they have low ratings. If you want good Korean food try some where else you won't find anything worth trying here. BIG THUMBS DOWN!!!
author: Rita A.

description:
Poor service ever!! I usually do not write comments on Yelp unless it is really very good or bad. However, this is the bad one. I went there at 2:00 pm on Friday afternoon, and it was a down time. Seats were empty but not cleaning up. It was not full but we waited for a long time for the food! We ordered 2 lunch box and waited for around 40 minutes, and without any Korean kimchi or small plates. We were told that it was because we ordered lunch boxes, and kimchi were in the lunch boxes. There were only 2 servers, and they pretended to be busy. Actually they were just walking around, chatting with a pair of customers. Not taking care of the customer. We felt we were ignored! 

As for the food, I was not expecting too much for the lunch box, but it really sucks. I ordered the bulgogi and there was only few slices! Although it was $10 per lunch box, it didn't really worth that price. Kimchi I mentioned earlier, only 1 type of kimchi (1 tbs). The salad was so oily, not sure what sauce they put in. And the tofu soup was too salty! I was not there for the junk food. I would rather go to Macdonald! It was not my first time came to this place, and it was not that bad in my memory. But this time, I should say this is the worst restaurant in SF Japantown. There are other affordable places provide good food, but definitely not this place.
author: Yvonne T.

description:
I saw this place as I was browsing around during the 48th annual Nor Cal Cherry Blossom Festival. I love korean food!! 

The place wasn't busy at all but it doesn't mean nothing to me. It was pretty shabby to me. 

I had ordered the beef tofu soup. My fiancé ordered the beef bibimbap. The bibimbap was okay.

However, I'm all about the tofu soup. The tofu soup was BOMB!! I'm really picky too. I was surprised that I had to crack open my own egg and put it in my soup. Plus I got purple rice which was different but it came out quite delicious. 

As far as the side dishes it was eh...it didn't suit my taste palette. But my fiancé enjoyed it. 

Overall the establishment was ok.
Customer service was ok. 
Food was delicious except the side dishes. 

Overall this place is average and deserves a 3 star.
author: Lily T.

description:
The food is barely ok but the price is over charged. 
The worst thing is the owner lady is very rude at customers and also decided the tips for customer. Stay away
author: Yarzar T.

description:
After a long and awesome 4th of July weekend, I was craving something hearty, spicy, and comforting. My traveling buddy and I dropped in to Doobu before hitting the Jazz Festival and it was just what the doctor ordered. 

Last time we went, I had recently devoured a BLT at The Grove Fillmore, so I didn't eat much and mostly picked at what my friend got. This time I was aptly able to devour my own meal, and so I did. I ordered Soondoobu with kimchee and pork. Boy, oh boy was it good. First a fried fish comes out, which is salty and crunchy and delicious, then an array of pickled small dishes come out, Mung beans, tofu, kimchee, seaweed, etc. Then the main course is brought out with a little tin of purple rice. 

My Soondoobu, still bubbling, deep red in color with a clean, spicy broth and filled with soft, custardy tofu, kimchee, and shreds of tender pork was tops. We cracked eggs in our stews and stirred them around a little so the bottom didn't burn. One thing I love about this dish is that is stays consistently hot throughout. I like to take a little rice in my spoon and let it soak up some of the rich, spicy broth. 

At around $11 per soup, I think this dish is well worth it. I want to try other things, but I always get in a rut and end up ordering the same thing all the time. Old habits die hard I guess.
author: Crystal C.

description: The place is not fancy, but really cozy in Japantown. I had the Soon Tofu soup with corned beef, with a lot of side orders coming along (including a raw egg you will put in!), the experience was really fun and the food was good! very reasonable prices and the waitress was very friendly! I will come back to try the Bibimbap :-)
author: Vanessa S.

description: Tried something new. It's been years since the last time I had Korean cuisine. I ordered the vegetable tofu soup which came with a handful of side dishes like pickled lotus root, seaweed, kimchi, rice and so forth. The interesting part of my meal was cracking a raw egg into my boiling soup. Everything tasted great. Atmosphere and service were spot on. Will be back again.
author: David S.

description:
I agree one hundred percent with Linda. This place is underrated; it should be 4 1/2 stars. I have eaten here many, many times with my wife and sometimes with out-of-town guests.

One caution however: Doo-bu may go off the rails a little bit when it's really crowded. It was jammed on a Monday, perhaps with tourists from a bus? Anyway, My bi bim bap was bi bim burnt, and this from a place that in our experience has always been delicious. It was a cold day out, and really cold in the restaurant. But I still love this place.
author: John H.

description:
YES and YES!!  Their ban chan is on point, service is friendly and quick.  And I love their kim chi tofu and pork soup.  It's ON POINT!!!!  Always hits the spot.  My korean gf showed me this place and it did not disappoint!!  I always get my soup spicy and it's the perfect amount of spice. 

Definitely better than my tofu house.  =)
author: Vicky T.

description: Really delicious and some vegetarian options. Food is even better than a few years ago. New menu items. Just great! Will return.
author: D S.

description:
I used come here a lot. But after today, I decided not come here anymore. 
First, they do not offer the free fish with tofu soup anymore.
Second, I ordered BBQ short ribs. They all overcooked, they are black color with full of "burnt"  I do not want to get cancer, so I did not eat it. 
Third, they gave me a used bag for my to go food...wow.... 
Last, the waiters just there to talk or stay in the kitchen, they did not really there for you. I asked several times for check out, no one heard.  Finally someone came out from the kitchen, and after paid it. The short hair lady pointed at the tips, and asked to that much tip....
author: Ting Z.

description:
Solid Korean food in Japantown. While that first sentence doesn't appear to make sense, there's actually a surprising number of businesses in Japantown owned by Koreans, so I guess a Korean restaurant isn't totally out of place.

This place serves up some good Korean food, including:
- Sundubu: Korean tofu soup with your choice of meat/veggies. Comes boiling hot (temperature), and with a range of heat (spiciness). Crack an egg in and enjoy with the purple rice (the mark of an authentic Korean restaurant).
- Pa Jeon: Seafood pancake. Well-fried, tasty, and crispy!
- Spicy Pork: My friend ordered this, I stole a bite, and it was spicy, flavorful, and tender. Would recommend if you aren't feeling the soup.
- Banchan: The small side dishes here are good but not particularly memorable.

The atmosphere is warm and cozy, and service is really friendly. I will say the booth-style seating, though cozy, probably wasn't the best choice, as servers have some trouble with passing hot bowls of soup and hot plates of food to the people sitting on the inside. 

Come here when it's cold outside and you just want a piping hot bowl of tofu soup to warm you up!
author: Brittany C.

description:
Love the food here - hearty soondoobu (spicy tofu stew) and deliciously marinated galbi (beef short ribs). The combination menu is a great deal - one combo order was definitely enough for two of us.  

The service here is sweet-  they will refill your banchan once over (small side dishes such as fish cakes and pickled radish that come at the beginning of your meal), which is nice! 

The only thing I'd work on is the decor - would love if it had more of a social ambience. Right now I go here if I want a casual quick Korean meal - but I'd stay longer if there was a better ambience.
author: Amelia C.

description:
The spicy rice cake consisted mostly of onions and vegetables.  I was like.... Where's the rice cake???
And they also do not have white steam rice only brown rice.  Quite disappointing because bulgogi and Galbi tastes better with white rice
author: Nina C.

description: This place is nice. I'll probably be back when I'm in the mood for Korean because it's close to me, and they do have a really good vegetarian lunch bento.
author: Madeleine M.

description:
I ordered the soon tofu  with spicy pork. The soup was okay (i ordered the combination soon tofu which has a little bit of seafood and meat in it). There was only one clam and it was sandy, the prawns were very tiny, I didn't bother to peel the skin off. The taste was good and served relatively very fast.

The spicy pork was served about 5 mins later then the soup. It was not marinated long enough. It was blend and tasteless in comparison to the soup.

Overall I gave it a 3 stars, and i'd suggest only order the soup here... probably want to avoid the seafood options as well.
author: Sze Wa C.

description:
Others have written about a fried fish being part of the proffered banchan.  Was I bad as in "no fried fish for you" or have they stopped offering this?  I'll never know.  We were served up less than a handful of banchan (4 to be exact) and fried fish was nowhere to be found.  Sad face.   

Amusing though was the whole, in-shell egg which arrived on my table simultaneously with said banchan and without explanation.  Bless the lord, my friend knew what this was for.  Left to my own devices I'd have taken it as more banchan, cracked it open, and had a yolky, viscous mess on my hands.  And table.  

Though never explained, the egg was there for us to crack open and lay atop the bubbling hot, spiced-to-order tofu soup of which Doobu has many versions.  I sampled the one with shrimp, prepared to "medium" spiciness, as specified.  'Twas a good tofu soup, not remarkable, but one I'd happily have again were I in the area.  I'd never before seen the "cook an egg on top" thing and didn't really think it was necessary or that it added much but it's a cute idea.  

The bibimbap was also solid: full of many tasty cooked vegetables, well-flavored, and had the required crisp rice sticking to the scalding hot stone pot.  

On a Saturday evening when so many other places in the area had hour plus waits, I was able to waltz (yes, I waltzed) right into Doobu and, after waiting for the clearing of a tabletop, sit right down.  Sometimes you just want to sit down and eat a meal not stand around and wait to sit down and eat that meal.  That this can be accomplished at Doobu is a good thing.

The place isn't fancy and neither is the service.  It's perfunctory and gets the job done.  Visually, it'd be nice if the servers cleared the tables a bit more quickly but it appeared there's only 2 people to work the steady stream of patrons so I'll cut them some slack.  It'd be nicer still if they'd expand the number of banchan offered and bring back the one of fried fish.  Even without it though, the food was solid (dinner for 2 -  including 2 soft drinks and tax - was under $30).  

Doobu is a respectable choice for K-town food in J-town surroundings.
author: Tracey A.

description:
There aren't many things that I love more than an authentic bowl of kimchi soon tofu. Honestly. The lovely kimchi color, flavorful chunks of pork/beef, slippery tofu.... and it makes me cry when some "korean" restaurants  can't do it right... 

I've heard from a lot of people that there aren't as many korean bbq place in SF, which lowered my expectation for Korean food in this area. However I'm suuuper happy that I found this place where the kimchi soup is heavenly. My personal life quality in San Francisco has just leveled up :)
author: Rachel Z.

description:
first time pretty much likeable korean restaurant out of the whole city

dumpling soon tofu soup is best
author: Jaesang C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and saw a Korean Tofu place which is rare in SF. I decided to take my chances and try it out.

I ordered the Combination Soon Tofu combo and it came out boiling hot (would prefer it not be boiling). As I waited for it to cool down they serve you the basic Korean side dishes; I only ate the bean sprouts and bean curds.

The shrimps that came with the combination were small; I didn't bother peeling it.

Overall I didn't mind the lack of quality and I would come here again for my Korean fix :) There's also barely any lineups too so I recommend this place if you wanted something quick to eat.
author: Brian L.

description: Open on Xmas eve. Small and friendly, not too noisy. Pop music in the background. Great sundoobu/tofu soup!
author: Daniel N.

description:
Wow - the place is pretty unassuming, but the food and service was excellent!

I got the combination Soon Tofu with Dumplings and Bulgogi - So Delicious! The Soon Tofu with dumplings was my main surprise, it came in hot, we threw an egg on top, then creamy full bodied goodness followed. 

My compatriots enjoyed their fare as well! We all left with doggie bags. (Oh did I mention they serve very generous portions?)
author: Greg F.

description:
I was so craving tofu soup! Found this place on Yelp. Had to go and try.

It was quite empty on a Saturday for lunch. But more people did come later. We ordered the spicy pork pancake as appetizer ( I was also craving this). So yummy!
I had the beef dumpling tofu soup, medium spicy. My hubby had the ramen tofu soup. They are both served with side dishes of kimchi (banchan). Also both came with an egg that you just plop on top of the soup, and it cooks. Both soups were soo soo good! Loved the taste. And just the right amount of spicy kick. The hubs thought medium was too spicy so if you're not into spicy try the lower levels. 

An interesting thing is the fried whole fish they give you at the beginning of the meal. It's complimentary, I guess their version of chips and salsa LOL. This is prob traditional Korean? I think it is dried fish that is fried? Not too sure but be careful eating it, quite boney. Also, the tofu soups are really hot in temperature because of the pot it comes in. It remains hot for a long time. I mean, I could feel the hot tofu go down my esophagus. So be aware!

Overall we really liked this place. It is a little pricey but we'll be back!
author: Vol T.

description:
TOFU mania.

The restaurant is located in the middle of Japantown. The restaurant has traditional ambiance with wood walls table and booths to sit in.

FOOD: Beef soon- The tofu soup flavor was a bit bland and did not have much flavor. Most of the taste was salt and spices. I was a little disappointed about the side dishes as well. 

SERVICE: We came on New Year's Day so the service was a bit slow. The food also took quite a while. The waiters were apologetic though and knew they were understaffed.

Overall, it'll be a place to grab an eat if Iam really craving korean tofu soup.
author: Stephen C.

description: So many tofu options for us vegetarians. The tofu bibimbap was good but not the best I have had. Their side dishes are great as well, but like the usual Korean places. If you're in the neighborhood and not wanting Japanese food, this place is a nice Korean spot as it's pretty low key.
author: Ashlyn R.

description:
Not much in the way of quality banchan, and the food was good. Nothing to write home about, but not bad, either. Right in the middle.

For Japantown, it's a decent bet, but it's certainly far from the best Korean food in the city.
author: Harley C.

description:
The menu carries a great variety of bibimbap and soon doobu. Their bibimbap all come in clay pot, so you get that delicious crunchy rice at the bottom of the bowl. The flavor was wonderful. Best bibimbap I've had in SF thus far! 
Soon doobu was also done well. I had their mushroom one and it had lots of flavor and really hit the spot. 
This my favorite Korean spot in SF. Will def be back!!
author: Nancy Z.

description: Went here for lunch and got the combination soon tofu which was pretty filling and it came with side dishes too. Service was ok, nothing special
author: Sui N.

description:
I've been called many things in the past, but the most relevant one for this review is "the Soon Doobu guy". Korean restaurant staff and owners always remember me by my dedication towards the Soft Tofu (pronounced Doobu in Korean) Stew. Needless to say, this is exactly what I ordered when I arrived at Doobu.

The Soon Tofu Stew was, on the scale of all the Stews I've had in the past, pretty good. It's got a good flavour, although I think they are lacking in spiciness. It is, however, good enough to warrant my recommendation when it comes to the Soon Tofu Stew. The little fried fish they bring as the little appetizer is also pretty neat. It's always a bonus when they give you a classy appetizer. 

No complaints about the service. The restaurant has a typical Korean decor.
author: Don L.

description:
I came here on a Friday night looking for something warm and soothing to save me from the cold SF night. I ordered the seafood soon dobu and my friend got the combination soon dobu. We also ordered the beef and onion pancake to share. 

The seafood soon dobu wasn't anything special and with medium spice you would think it was more flavorful. The combination medium spicy was better but still nothing spectacular. The soup definitely hit the warm comfy food spot but nothing particularly special.

The beef pancake however was awesome and served with a dipping sauce. We finished the pancake before our tofu soup! 

The side dishes were tiny and gave little variety.

If you're around Japantown and just want some tofu soup this place might be good. However, with all the Japanese and Korean restaurants around Fillmore I won't be back soon.
author: Linda L.

description:
Don't bother come back. 

Bibimbap vege cut so big. No green vege at all and so do side dishes. 

Tofu soup is okay.

Spicy chicken wings are not good.

In short, not recommend.
author: Huan L.

description:
If you know me at all, you are aware I do not often use the word "awesome." But here it is well deserved. This is an awesome little shop where I was immediately made most welcome and offered all kinds of nice things to eat. The tofu and vegetable bibimbap was perfect for the moment to calm me down after an anxiety-producing morning at the Chinese Consulate. I will certainly find an excuse to be back.

And I did. I was back for dinner the next night and the service and food were not quite as good. Nevertheless it was a good experience.
author: Philip S.

description: I've never posted any review but I really need to post one for this place from how bad the service I got. There are many Korean restaurants in sf that are way better than here. Food is nothing special, pricy from what you get. Kimchi is a little sour. They force you to pay 20% tips which is totally not acceptable to me. I don't mind paying tips when I do get serviced. But there is no service here. Wonder what the lady owner would do if I don't pay the tips she wanted me to. Keep away from this place!!
author: Edison C.

description:
This place is called "tofu", yet the things I know it for are anything but. They have albap (various roe over vegetables and rice, often in a hot stone bowl), one of my favorite dishes, Korean or otherwise. Alongside the banchan, you get deep-fried whole fish, something like one per person. They have signature dishes, including corned beef stew and ham & cheese stew. Try them. Also try asking for the peanut butter & jelly stew in your best Ninja Turtle voice and watch the server's reaction.

Sometimes there's only one server handling all the tables, so speaking with them can be brisk (once you catch them). Friends and I still think this place gets the job done when we've got a Japantown agenda.
author: Dan B.

description:
What I ate: Mushroom soon doobu
Visit date: September 11, 2012
First time? Yes.

This joint is in Japantown so I was expecting it to be an overpriced tourist trap, but it wasn't. Score! I was having a rough day, so a nice hot bowl of soon doobu was just what I needed. Added bonus, it was good and the spice was right. The meal came with assorted banchans; my favorite was the whole fried fish. I love snacking on fried fish; it reminds me of home. We came in a little late for lunch and little early for dinner (just in time for linner I suppose) so they didn't see us in the front and no one was waiting there or keeping an eye out. Once they saw us though (after some flailing arm action) the service was prompt and the food came out quickly.
author: Erin G.

description:
Is pretty good for Korean food. 

Came here the other night with a friend and had the chicken bim bim bap and dumpling tofu soup. 

Bim Bim bap came first, and I probably shouldn't have mixed it so quickly - none of the rice had hardened on the bottom yet, but after mixing we did let it sit for a few minutes so we got the crunchy rice. 

Tofu soup was pretty decent, but not totally amazing. I'm not convinced that they make the dumplings in-house (I guess they never claimed that...), and it comes with "brown" rice. Except the rice is purple...so purple rice? No idea. But was pretty good, and quite filling. We had the soup in mild, as my friend does not do spicy, and she found it spicy still. I...did not mind. Ha.

One of my complaints about this spot is that it took them FOREVER to give us the little side dishes! They came by with a fish per person first. Then took away the fish and didn't bring us any of the side dishes until our other foods came. Was sad.
author: Lily W.

description:
the usual cold sf night, so we wanted tofu soup to warm up.
got the combo + mozzarella and kimchi tofu soup.  Hmm but they came out flat, no bubbling at all.  Cracked an egg in and it just sits there, still clear and raw.  we asked them to bring it back to heat up, which they did kindly, so thank you.
after the reheating, our pots were bubbling to the brim and each spoonful was tongue burning.  flavor of soup was good-flavorful and whole.

adding the mozzarella for $1 was interesting.  my friend did not like the experience at all.  in fact, it added more to his tongue burning trauma.

service was slow.  pan chan were ok.  cant complain if youre hungry and cold and need to get inside to warm up.
author: Linda T.

description:
I had the seafood pancake, which only had calamari, my least favorite "seafood" so I wasn't too happy.

The daughter had spicy pork bimimbap, and she liked it a lot.

The  place is ok, in a sea of touristy restaurants.  It's not the best, but nothing around there is either.  The service is okay.

We came here today after walking around the Union Street Festival, then after we ate, we walked about 100 ft. to the Japanese grocery store to get  the coffee crunch cake!  Now, that's five stars!
author: Foodlover B.

description: Good food, bad customer service. The waiter anxiously came to us as we were leaving to exclaim that the check didn't include a tip. The only cash we had on us was a $5 bill, but even then she rejected the $5 and requested for a 20% tip. We took our tip back and left.
author: Shirley V.

description: Love love love this place! I've been there about 3-5 times before. So far I've tried the tofu soup, the kimchi bbimbap,  and the ddok bukki. Everything has been great! Its never really been too crowded and the servers are really nice!
author: Samantha R.

description:
If San Francisco had a winter, I would spend my nights warming up over a bowl of sundubu jjigae, the bubbling in the stone bowl replacing the crackling of the fireplace I don't have. 

THE VIBE:

One of the few Japantown restaurants that actually serves up decent fare, Doobu is tucked away in the secondary plaza by Post street. Usually just one waitress on duty, she none the less serves with a smile and is available and friendly. comfortable booth seating.

THE FOOD:

high quality banchans that are readily replaced if finished, and tasty tasty sundubu jjigae. I wouldn't say the meat is super high quality (I've had the pork, chicken, and beef), but everything comes together well. I've also had the ramen sundubu jjigae, which is made with instant ramen noodles. A little cheap, but comforting all the same.
author: Patrick T.

description:
My friend took me here today for lunch around 3pm. I know we had a late start. There was like only one or two other tables when we arrived. I do like how the seats are mostly booths. I love booths. We both ordered the tofu soup which came with a bowl of purple-ish rice, some side dishes, and an raw egg. We got about 4-5 dishes. Not bad.

It was very filling and the rice went really well with the soup. If I didn't eat breakfast I could have finished the rice but since I did eat breakfast I finished the tofu soup and 1/4 of the rice. I did eat some side dishes. 

Overall, it was a good experience. Their tea was a bit rich so we both opted for the water. The waitress was kind enough to accept two debit cards from us. =] I wouldn't mind coming back on a cold day for some tofu soup. They have about 10 choices for tofu soup so there should be something for everyone except those who hate tofu.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This was one of the quickest dinners I've ever had at a sit-down restaurant and it was totally good!

After watching a movie at the Sundance Kabuki Cinema nearby and saying so long to friends I embarked on a journey to find myself some dinner.  Doobu Tofu closes at 9:30 PM on Sundays, and as most restaurants are very accommodating to folks who are already dining in I've always had this quirk where I just feel bad about staying past the closing time at any restaurant.  I sat down inside the restaurant at 9:05 PM.  After a quick glance of the menu I was ready.  The waitress took my food and drink order immediately.

At 9:10 PM I had several plates of banchan, a whole fried fish and a raw egg (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WyBN8MGM6LVuDNBD4cBEqA?select=90y2c9jVK14IegWZsCPqZA) in front of me.  I loved the fried fish and appreciated that the bones were easy to locate and remove.  The glass noodles and the bean curd strips were probably my favorites, but I enjoyed all of the banchan dishes.

My Shrimp Soon Tofu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WyBN8MGM6LVuDNBD4cBEqA?select=QCh9co8rl3jPrCSuwtlMHw) arrived around 9:13 PM.  This was my first experience with Korean tofu soup.  I ordered it mild and the spicyness was pretty mild, but I loved this.  It was served in a miniature stone pot so as much as I wanted it to cool down fast so I could just guzzle it I just couldn't because it stayed hot throughout my meal.  I loved the big blocks of soft tofu and the soup had lots of little head attached, soft shelled shrimp.  I wasn't sure if my system could digest the shrimp heads and legs otherwise I might've eaten them whole.  It was kind of a chore removing what little meat was in those little shrimp.  The broth was very flavorful even though I forgot to crack the raw egg into it.

Immediately after the Soon Tofu arrived I got the Bulgogi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WyBN8MGM6LVuDNBD4cBEqA?select=lAMGCrTrpzap76DK-eVjdA) served on a stone platter and a bowl of rice.  I forgot to ask the waitress, but the rice was very interesting.  It had a purple-like hue to it, but it tasted fine.  The Bulgogi was delicious.  The beef was shaved thin and cooked very tender.  The vegetables, mainly onions, peppers, zucchini and carrots, were also cooked tender but not soft.  I had no problem finishing everything except for the raw egg.

In my eating flurry the waitress did stop by to check up on me, and when she started to clean up different areas of the restaurant I picked up the pace.  By 9:30 PM I was full and happy.  The waitress brought me my check.  I paid it and left a nice tip, and rolled out of the restaurant at 9:35 PM.  Doobu Tofu was awesome for a quick dinner, and I will be back!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Doobu is decent Korean food for SF, but certainly not the best ever (tastier/cheaper options in Palo Alto, Cupertino, LA). 

Although, I still keep coming back here because....
1) Accessibility. I live in the neighborhood, so it's easy for me to come here for lunch or order to-go for dinner. There's rarely a wait. 
2) Their bibimbap is large in size and fills you up. 
3) Service is quick. Whether you're eating in or taking out, you can order and get your food within 10 minutes. 
4) They serve the traditional purple Korean rice -- believe it or not, this is actually hard to find in many Korean restaurants in the Bay. (purple, grainy rice tastier than white rice, IMO). 

Why I DON'T like Doobu: 
1) The prices are ridiculous for Korean food. $14 for a Bibimbap? Commercial rent must be really expensive in this part of Japantown. 
2) Also, for the high prices, you get about half as much side dishes than at your typical Korean restaurant. Higher prices for less value. 
3) They serve you the side dishes at the same time you get your entree, not before to eat as an appetizer. Again, this deviates from your typical Korean restaurant. 
4) Service: Everyone always looks bored and not interested to help you out. However, this doesn't bother me that much; it's pretty standard when dining at Asian establishments in general. 

Lastly, I read another reviewer's complaint about a cockroach that crawled across the surface of his table... I will say I have NOT experienced this myself, the restaurant has been pretty clean the couple times I've been at Doobu. However, if I ever saw this critter, I'd bail right away as well.
author: Helen W.

description:
Kalbi, tofu bibimbap, seafood pa jun, all delicious here. Really satisfied my afternoon Korean craving. Wasn't exactly brimming with business when we walked in, but there were actually Korean people eating here, so I usually assume anywhere with people who really know the cultural cuisine is vouched for...

Friendly service, good food, boom.
author: Ellie W.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

0/1 Star: need to pay for Japantown Parking lot. 
_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

0/1 Star: this is the only Korean restaurant I've ever been to that charge for side dishes. $3 per round of small side dishes. They do not help you crack the egg in your tofu soup. They serve the side dishes when you get your meal so you can't snack on it while you wait. 
_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: average tasting place. The food got cold fast. Only 6 side dish options. The fish cake side dish is good but they don't give you much. If you want more it's a $3 charge. 
_____


Overall Experience
2/5 Stars 

_____

Pictures


_____

Last Words

$3 side dish refill is a rip off!!!
author: Elliott N.

description:
Came here as a suggestion from a friend and it's close proximity to Japantown. After ordering, we received fried fish as free appetizers. Ordered the Seafood Pancake which looks like a ginormous pizza. Comes with a dipping sauce that was somewhat salty. I liked eating the pancake with the Bi-bim-bop sauce instead...yeah kinda weird. My friends seemed to enjoy the Bi-Bim-Bop, but please make sure you add the sauce and mix it well otherwise it tastes very bland. Even though I have never had it before, the Dubuki was sub-par. I guess I'm not a fan of hard rice flour. This dish is also expensive for a small amount ($8.95).  The side dishes were normal but I liked the seaweed one the best. It was nice that we got a small water jug so that we didn't have to keep asking for water. The place definitely does get crowded during the lunch hour so be sure to come early. 

Ps. Props to the one waitress manning the whole restaurant!
author: Kathy W.

description: First time at Doobu today! There was 11 of us ready to eat, service was speedy - which was great because we were in a rush! The food was sooo good and tasty! I was extremely happy! The restaurant itself was very bright and colorful! I think I've found my new favorite restaurant in Japan town!
author: Hannah W.

description:
Food was okay. Service was horrible. I dont know why this resturant only has ONE server?!!? My friends and I came in and she greeted us and pointed to where we can sit.. ( already minus 1 pt) i hate servers who tell you "sit over there" really? I think it would be professional for you to walk us to our seat but heyyy okayyyy. She also slammed our food on the table and never came back after that to refill water or ask if everything was okay. We waited for 5 minutes for our tab... She never came to us so one of the girls had to go up and get the tab ( minus 1 pt)  we paid for our food and didnt bother to tip... We did not like the experience at ALL. Right after we paid and left our tab on the table and was about to exit the store, the server ( btw a korean lady) was sooo quick on her feet ( yes.. Speed so fast) ran up to us and asked if we tipped. I was dissapointed that the whole time she didnt even have time to come check on our dining, but had the audacity to come check for her tip! She was very demanding about her tip!!! We told her she did not service us and she seemed so confused. She wanted me to write down a tip amount on my tab. The whole store was watching us... And let me remind you again, she was the only worker out front serving.. Seemed like her tip was more important to leave everyone waiting. I tossed three dollars at her and left the restaurant.

I tip servers wherever I go.. Good servers, decent servers, and amazing servers. I tip for service. There was no service here. Im sorry.
author: Dd X.

description: Yes! Tofu stew on the brain?  Come eat here. Similar to the Soon dubu jeeps (tofu houses) in los angeles K-town, this place is authentic, and keeps it real. When it's cold and you want something protein heavy, go where the heavy weights eat. Here silly, now go be korean!
author: Kato D.

description:
This Korean place is definitely worth it for their lunch specials! 

You get so much food for only 9 dollars. I got the chicken terriyaki with tofu soup and it was definitely enough to fill me up. They don't give you the standard side dishes but they do give you some but not many. The only thing is that you HAVE to get the seafood tofu soup and you can't substitute it all.

Definitely would come back if I'm in the area.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
My friends & I were hungry, and this was the first place we walked into. The first thing I noticed was how cute and intimate the setting was. The place was pretty small (max capacity was 46).

We were seated immediately and the waiter was very polite. We weren't sure about eating here because the price was a little higher than what we're used to when it came to Korean food. But I convinced my friends to stay... And I'm glad we did. 

I ordered beef bi bim bop... So good! It took awhile to eat because it was so hot (temp wise). For the amount I got the price wasn't too bad, I believe less than $10. The sides were the usual, but I especially enjoyed the fishcake & kimchee (really good!). And this was the first time I went to a Korean restaurant and got a whole fish as a side haha...

I'd recommend this place to anyone who's in the area craving Korean food.
author: Lala K.

description: Went here for dinner and was disappointed.  We ordered the pancakes, bulgoggi, and squid.  The waitress forgot to place the order for the pancakes and then later said the kitchen was too busy to make what we ordered.  We had to send the squid back because it was so tough we could not eat it.
author: Amit P.

description: Been coming here 2/month for the past year. Fantastic food and exceptional service. The waitresses are very friendly and accommodating - provides a very homely atmosphere. The food is awesome, especially if you're in the mood for large portions of Korean comfort food. Highly recommend the beef bibimbop, chicken wings, and chapchae!
author: Nolan S.

description: 3 stars and I am just being nice because I finished my food anyway. But, first of all the price is too much for what you are getting. Then, the lady said they only have four sides left because it was a busy day. She did apologized as well and since it is a Saturday night I am giving them a star for that. I would originally just give them one star, but spicy pork and bulgogi taste decent. Yes, just decent. I usually go to a closer korean bbq place and they're cheaper and taste way better.
author: Connie A.

description:
The tofu soup is so rich and hearty. It's a surprising find in Japantown.

I always get the Combination Soon Tofu (with spicy broth). The broth itself is so good that I feel like the other ingredients aren't necessary - the shrimps tend to be kinda small and not worth eating (although they probably do add some flavor to the broth), and the beef doesn't add much.

Price is $8.95 here for the sundubu, which is cheaper than at Tofu House (supposedly the best place for sundubu in SF, so I'm using it as the 'gold standard'.) Honestly, Tofu House wasn't that spectacular, and this restaurant is a great cheap non-crowded alternative.  I find the soup to be on par with BCD Tofu House (a popular chain scattered throughout SoCal and New York).  This is also the only place I know of so far that serves purple grain rice!!!

The ban chan is on the skimpier side (just a selection of 6), but there is also a mini fried fish, and 2 of my favorite things (fish cake and seaweed)! Unlimited refills except for the fried fish.  Yum!
- fish cake
- seaweed
- kimchi
- bean sprouts
- pickled radish
