The restaurant never seems to be that busy.  It's debatable whether that itself is the cause for the lackluster service, or vice versa.  However I've learned to never expect fantastic service from any Asian hole-in-the-wall.
author: Jeanne L.

description: I would give no stars if there was this option. Came here for dinner, nothing special. Their food is just okay. The service is horrible. First, they kept rushing us to order, then they weren't happy about two people sharing a huge combination meal. Second, they don't really speak English, but that's not a huge problem. We asked for what she said and she repeated it impatiently. Third, they gave us check to rush us out while we were still eating and there were literally NO ONE in the restaurant but us. Moreover, THEY CHARGE TIPS BEFORE WE EVEN GOT THE RECEIPT TO WRITE TIPS AND TOTAL ON. The check was our meal price plus tax and we gave our card without any doubt. And when we got our card and the receipt back, we were charged 18% of tips ALREADY! Like really???? I'm never coming again.
author: Jennt C.

description: I love Doobu and the purple rice. I ALWAYS go here at least once during my SF trips. I get the dumpling soft tofu soup medium and sometimes spicy. No regrets and no negative comments from me. The bathroom is really clean which I appreciate haha.
author: Shivam P.

description: We found the selection of ramen restaurants a bit overwhelming, so we chose tofu soup for lunch.  I would say the tofu soup I had was about 3.5 stars but I rounded up since I liked their attentive service.  I had the mushroom tofu soup...Mmm...enoki!  After you get over the initial spoonful of mushroom flavor that may come off a little strong, your taste buds get acclimated and it's all good.  The soup is served with purple rice.  The appetizer is a fried fish that was pretty good.  I think we had 4 banchans, ie kimchi, seaweed, fishcake, pickled daikon and carrots (? not completely certain on this last one).  My favorite of the lot was seaweed.  My favorite banchan, that weren't served, are jae chae and the fried potato with sticky sauce.  I wish more restaurants offered them.
author: Melinda Y.

description: Pretty chill Korean Tofu place. Has high-quality pre-meal "snacks" (they even give you one of those fried whole fishes! Which I usually only see at the higher quality Korean tofu houses), and the sofu stew I ordered was fantastic. Would definitely come back often.
author: Henry L.

description: Having tried lots of soondubu all over the bay area, this place is one of the best you can get in SF proper. Hidden gem lost in the crowd in Japantown, Doobu is amazing. The staff is minimalist but friendly and the prices are probably more than what some are used to for soondubu, but it's good. Trust me. The tofu they use is so silky and just works with the soup, no matter what flavor you get. My favorite is mushroom. A likes the beef. You get the egg on the side, and stir it in when it comes--SO GOOD! They used to give you a little fried fish as an appetizer, but appear to have stopped. If you want some variety, we've had both the seafood pancake and the ddokbokgi, which isn't uber saucy (depends how you like it). Enjoy!
author: Vivian C.

description:
CAme here about twice last week. Was in the Jtown area and felt like eating some korean food. I'm not too familiar with the korean resturants here I assume they are mostly the same quality. A person I met a t the cafe recommended Doobu and I was always curious what the food was like inside after passing by so many times. 


The first time I came here I ordered the Combination soon do bu (seafood+beef+vegetables etc.) and Seafood Bibimbap. The soon du bu was meh* nothing special,n  ormal for SF but you can get better elsewhere. The seafood bibimbap though I fell in love with!! Absolutely amazing! That alone is the reason I had to come back the next day.lol  There was the right amount of crisp texture you can feel when taking the bite of the seafood and rice combination and the taste had the right amount of sesame oil and chili paste. I wish I could make this dish like them. 

Other then the seafood bibimbap nothing really surprised me here. Prices are about the same like any other tofu house so is the taste. Unless their is a tofu house or any korean restaurant that can bring the same prices like in Korea ($5) for soon do bu vs. $10 here) or LA quality, I'm not going to be too taken back.
author: Jude N.

description:
This is a hidden gem for me. I've been here twice and it's allotted me (I consider myself the best non-Korean soondubu connoisseur) the comfort and deliciousness of beef soondubu, medium spicy. Kalbi was a littttleeee bit too salty but still did the trick.

The ambiance is great because it's not crowded and it seems like it's not that known. No wait on a Friday night at prime dining hours (such a plus in SF). 

Panchan and the fried fish that they serve were mediocre, but they were super nice on refills. Great service.

Definitely want to come here all the time to get my soondubu fix.
author: Adele Z.

description: My friends and I wanted to get some good tofu soup so we decided to come here. It's was a Wednesday night 9pm. We walk in and got seated. We got our menus and ordered our food. Everything was great. Food was delicious, the cucumber and fish cake side dishes were my fav. Then halfway into our meal the waitress comes to our table and asks us if we can pay now because she is closing the register. Which I understand, she's trying to go home. Ok. So my friends and I then spilt our bill, I payed cash and they paid with a card. She waited close by and grabbed the check. Then she comes back and asked is that all the tip she was receiving? I've never been to a place where they rush you out, then expect a decent tip (rude). Don't go to this place if you want good costumer service because you will not get it here.
author: Che D.

description: This was the first place I've ever had soon tofu.. That was a while ago btw.  Anyways, I was starving and thought, "why not?"  I was highly disappointed.  The galbi wasn't very flavorful and the meat they used was okay AND it was so friggin expensive.  This tiny portion is $24. SOOOOOO NOT WORTH IT!!  Also, I ordered the seafood soon tofu... My oyster was the size of a pearl... Can't even call it an oyster.  The fried fish they gave us was cold too.  You can tell they fried it and left it there for a while.  I'm so disappointed :(
author: Kenitha Y.

description: I'm writing a review for this new waitress there. My friend and I came into the restaurant very hungry to grab Korean food. I heard that this place was cheap and good so we decided to try it out. We then try to order alcohol and the waitress said my friend couldn't. He was born on 1994.. It's 2016 right now. It's legal to drink alcohol when you're 21, but she called her boss and even her boss said my friend couldn't. We then tried to explain to her that it's legal to drink once we turn 21, but she kept saying no. We were all confused and ended up leaving the place. Maybe the boss thinks it's illegal?  Maybe he thought the legal age is 22? I have no idea. Either way that was a bad and confusing experience. For a place that sells alcohol they should get the correct information...
author: Mimi T.

description:
This place is amazing! 

Great food

Reasonable prices.

My only complaint is that they take forever!!!!  I ordered my food at 11:50am and didn't get it till 12:30.... Lunch time is just really busy.
author: Cel Y.

description: Kimchi tofu soup was really good! But I didn't want to pay 17 dollars for a pancake. My Korean friend said that dough for the pancake was not very authentic. We also ordered spicy rice cakes. Wish they could be less sweet. Our bill ended up being $55 for main dishes and one appetizer.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Came here on a friend's recommendation. Our table ordered the spicy soon tofu combination, bulgogi, and the kimchi panju. 

Upsides: 
-the food's good. 
-soon tofu combination shined. The soup was flavorful and nicely spiced. 
-the bulgogi and banchan taste as you would expect them to. Not out of this world, not a disappointment. 
-the panju was oilier than the ones I've had before, and felt like pleasant comfort food. 

Downsides:
-The place was understaffed. For a busy night, there was only one waitress and she belatedly served us banchan (side dishes) and barley tea.
-It was pricier than expected; I'm used to cheaper prices in Korean neighborhoods in socal.
author: Michelle J.

description:
First off, I created my Yelp account because of this place. So you already know where I'm coming from...

I ventured in here along with friends (four of us all together) after escaping some horrendous prices of a nearby restaurant...

I ordered the Spicy Pork bbq, which was no where near as good what I'm used to at Koreatown back home in Los Angeles. Although, I was hungry, and it did suffice. The portions were good, I was full.

Now this is where it goes bonkers, a COCKROACH the size of the tip of an index finger crawls across our table, only to get squashed by one of my friends, and held as evidence. Now this was midway through our meal, and at this time we we'rent actually fully disappointed at our meal just yet.

Then our check comes back significantly higher with no clear description why. Their gratuity of 16% was marked on their menu for parties of 6 or more. THERE'S ONLY 4 OF US! We then brought this to the attention of the lady who had been helping us and were told to TIP MORE! Beside ourselves, we immediately demanded our money back and showed her the roach. She took it, then threw it away and asked us "What roach? I know what you guys are trying to do, you just don't want to pay!" (Yes this really happened in the middle of the restaurant full of customers.)

We then asked to speak with management, but were told "there is no manager." She played the "poor English" card for a while, then made a phone call to someone and told us the manager isn't answering and wouldn't be coming in tomorrow or for days!

We ended up leaving shortly after in utter disappointment, not wanting to deal with such a childish person.

The next day, we sent an email to the email address they have on their website, explaining our ordeal and requesting a refund. But were replied with one of the most unprofessional responses I have ever received from an establishment. We were called frauds, and dared to take legal action because her family is in the justice department, someone's a judge, a brother an officer, and a brother in-law is a lawyer, etc...all in efforts to scare us. I find it very immature.

All we wanted was our money back for unsatisfactory experience with their business. The matter in which they handled this matter has been extremely unprofessional and juvenile.
author: Gee S.

description:
Going off the reviews here, I'm guess Doobu can be pretty hit or miss. Fortunately, I came on a night when it was more the former than the latter, where the worst part of the night was not the food, but the torrential rain outside that managed to soak us through in mere minutes (we were lacking in rain gear, after all). For 8pm on a Friday night though, Doobu was surprisingly empty, with perhaps only one or two other parties in the restaurant, and a single waitress (wo)manning the entire floor.

I ended up getting a pork soondoobu, and a kimchi seafood pancake to share with my dinner companion. Compared to some other places I've been, Doobu is a wee bit pricier, and pretty lacking in the banchan department, but, at the very least, they do serve up a tasty fried fish, which most places I've been do not (and which is probably my favorite item anyway). The rest of the food was also pretty good, and all very filling, with enough leftovers to last another meal, at the very least. 

I can certainly see myself coming here again, as it sure beats trekking out to Sunset/Richmond. I just hope the food manages to stay consistently tasty!
author: Johnny W.

description:
The following is based on a trip that I took to San Francisco in May 2013 and was written on my personal blog during that time:
I cannot recommend this restaurant. While the food is superb, I was not fond of the service. The waitress yelled at me when someone gave me their rice (after he said he did not want rice), she put 11 of us on the same ticket (for a meal totaling near $200), and gratuity was forced (when I personally thought she did lousy service). Also, I was served fish as an appetizer when I explicitly ordered from the vegetarian menu and the waitress knew about my vegetarianism (while this would have been a good gesture, it was lacking in tact). I felt bad for writing this, but some of the lower ranking Yelp reviews about the restaurant changed my tune.
author: Derek R.

description:
Do not come to this place if its crowded.
They do not have enough staff to handle a full house.
author: Vidhi V.

description: This is a Korean restaurant famous for its tofu soup inside Japan town. My friend and I decided to check it out this Saturday afternoon. So we arrived this place at about 1pm. The place is nice and quiet. We ordered beef tofu soup, Bulgogi, and spicy squid bibimbap, which cost us about 60 dollars all together. As typical Korean restaurant, we got a bunch of Kimchi starters which taste nice. Then the waiting period was a little bit long considering there were not many people at that time. It turned out the beef tofu soup is delicious though not reach the level I was expecting. I will probably try other tofu soup next time, say pork tofu soup. What surprised me is that the squid bibimbap is excellent. I guess I will add this place to my favorite list.
author: Fangliang Y.

description: I came in for a late lunch at about 2pm on a Wednesday. I was drawn in by the lunch special (bulgogi, salad with fried tofu,kimchi, noodles with bean sprouts, purple rice, and tofu soup). $8.95 (although the sign outside said $7.95) for all that food! I was the only person there and the food was taking forever.  It was the first time I tried that soup and thought it smelled a little funky for my taste...kinda like Japanese nato. The wait time and my opinion of the soup are my reasons for 4 stars.
author: Khloes M.

description:
Try the tasty, piping hot veggie tofu soup with all the goodies on the side: egg, kimchee, sweet pickled cucumbers, pickled sprouts, seaweed, and purple-y rice. 

Fun tip: you can either crack your egg in and leave it the way it is (so it looks like it would be sunny side up), or you can mix in the yoke & whites with your chop sticks so it comes to look like egg flower soup - either is ok, according to the waiter. I preferred the latter.

Do I believe the broth was vegetarian? It's questionable. If I knew for a fact it were, I would definitely give Doobu a higher rating.
author: Amber K.

description:
Meh. Prices are reasonable for japantown, but nothing was hot except the soup. Lukewarm tea, sake, pancake. The kimchee is supposed to be cold, but portions are on the small side. 

The tofu soup was good, and the other reviewer had it right. Come here for the soup!!
author: Janette R.

description:
Ah, Korean comfort food in the middle of Japan Town is a good thing. Now everybody sing...We are the world...We are the children...We aren't the ones with nuclear warheads, so let's start eating...

A new eatery on the Buchanan Street cobblestone mall is always a welcome sight, and Doobu is a pretty nice place, a combo Korean BBQ and tofu house. With mustard walls and geometric paintings, it has a cleaner look than most in the area with a contemporary West Elm-meets-Pier One look. You can certainly expect service with a smile here.

The menu is robust with at least ten different tofu soups all conveniently priced at $8.95. The BBQ dishes - galbi, bulgogi, spicy pork - and the house specials like dolsot bibimpap, al bap and haemul pajun are all in the $10.95-$14.95 range.

But honestly, the best deal is the $7.95 lunch box special. It's a tasty collection of Korean flavors - a heaping bowl of tofu soup, a salad with a couple of wedges of deep-fried tofu, kim-chee, some mixed vegetables, some marinated glass noodles, a full bowl of rice and a good pile of galbi (or if you prefer, bulgogi, spicy pork or chicken teriyaki). They give you a little bottle of libation called Yakult, which tastes like an overly sweetened combo of watery milk and orange juice.

FOOD - 4 stars...the lunch box special is a real good deal
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...pretty modern...and quite possibly the cleanest men's room in J-Town
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly and responsive
TOTAL - 4 stars...not the best Korean I've ever had but a good option when you're in the area and tired of sushi
author: Ed U.

description:
I had the combination tofu stew. First, pretty inexpensive for this much food, located in a tourist location. 

I have seen that people comment about the little fried fish appetizer that accompanies the main course. So good!

The tofu stew was hot and delicious with many pickle dishes accompanying the stew. 

I'd go there more often, but it costs more to get there than the food. Definitely try this one.
author: A I.

description:
I was craving me some soondoobu recently and since I can't just hop to Seoul Garden in K-town (I recently moved from NY) anymore, I was so happy I discovered this place while strolling in Japantown. They have, by far, the most eclectic selection of soondoobu I've ever seen (ham and cheese, seriously?)!

Since I was on the verge of a cold, I got the veggie soondoobu with only mild spice, and of course, with extra tofu! I'm always appreciative of restaurants that accommodate my request without batting an eyelash. We also ordered a bibimbap to share.

The soondoobu was not as good as Seoul Garden (but I think I have too high expectations for Korean food in SF). The broth was on the bland side and was very watery. However, the bibimbap was very good! Well seasoned with lots of veggies - awesome in my book.

The service at this restaurant is really good! (Perhaps because we came on a Monday night, who knows). The banchan was a little on the light side, but I did like the fried fish.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I got the Oyster Tofu Soup.  On a cold day it's gotta be one of the best meals out there.

I got some of their other food too, but it was just ok... 

But regardless if they can just keep making good or even make their tofu soup better, i will keep coming back
author: Steven F.

description:
Why would I choose to have scalding hot soup on one of the hottest days of the year? Well, I'm 1st generation Korean, my mom was in town to help me pack and I wanted something to soothe my sore throat. And because this is the food of my motherland, this review is kinda long. As a Korean I feel compelled to give some credible review so all of you non's know what's up.

That said, I may be 1st generation but I'm no Korean food conoisseur so I grilled my mom on her opinions for this Yelp review. I think she was a little perplexed as to why I suddenly cared so much about Korean food tonight. (It's not my favorite cuisine. There. I said it.)

Due to the proximity of J-town to my current abode we walked over there and checked out Seoul Garden's menu. Mom's reaction to the prices: "Are you fucking kidding me???" Actually she was a bit more demure than that and it was also in Korean, but it was the Mama Han equivalent to Hell to the Motherfucking No. So we wandered across the street and Doobu caught my eye.

Starter: A whole fried fish. I've never had this before at a Korean restaurant, but ok, cool. I'm down with some complimentary food. Except it was a whole fried fish that kept LOOKING AT ME and I wasn't keen on picking out the bones. Yes, I had my mom do it. It was... meh. It's pretty much just salted fish that's been fried in some batter.

Banchan (the little side dishes that always come with a Korean meal): Mom says, "That's it? They give you so much more in the East Bay." The cucumber kimchi and cabbage kimchi were a bit too marinated and had been "sitting too long" for my taste. It's hard to explain but you can serve kimchi too soon before it's ready, this was on the other end of the spectrum. The portions of the other three (bean sprouts, fish cake and spinach) were small. Sadness.

Spicy Seafood Doobu (Spicy, tofu, seafood. Exactly what the name says): Yay it was actually spicy! Mom said it was not bad, but then she also informed me that it had MSG. "How do you know?" "You can just tell." "But how do you KNOW?? Can you taste it??" (I'm totally thinking my mom has some weird superpower to detect MSG in food.) "Look it's thick and if you made this at home, you'd never add it so it wouldn't look quite like this. And most restaurants just DO." (Superhero Mom fantasy deflated.)

Beef bibimbap (beef mixed with rice, egg, and other veggies in a hot stone bowl): This was inneresting. Instead of using bulgogi that typically comes in this dish, ground beef is used and marinated in the same stuff as bulgogi. There was quite a lot of meat and not as much veggies as I'm used to. It was not bad, just different from what I'm used to for bibimbap. Mama Han says, "This is ok, just different. But that's a small portion for $12. I could make this way better." Bitchslap, Doobu. And yes, my mom's cooking is the shit.

Random: They played Boyz II Men's "I'll Make Love To You". Made me misty-eyed for the 90's and middle school dances.

Mama Han's conclusion: For better Korean food go to the South Bay.

My conclusion: For the best Korean food have mom's home cooking. 

(If I had gone by myself and I didn't know any better this would've been a 3-star review, but tonight I'm putting myself in my mom's size 6 shoes. Love you, mom.)
author: Leilani H.

description:
There's only one soon-doobu place I ever go to in San Francisco and this is it! The tofu soups are wonderfully spicy, served with the awesome purple rice. The pajun (korean style egg pancakes) is all right, nothing that fancy. The bibimbap is definitely the star of this place. Doobu also used to have way cooler and a wider variety of side dishes, but I get it, the times are tough and you can't be giving away food for free. At least all my favorites are still there (bean sprouts, kimchi). 

Price: Coming form Los Angeles where the restaurant market is much tougher, prices are much friendlier. Here, a bowl of soon-doobu will run you about $10 each and a dish of Korean BBQ will run you an additional $17 -- combo is about $22. Bibimbap is about $15, so a dinner for two is about $40, not including alcohol. 

Service: No one is ever in a rush to boot you out. Come with friends and sit up for two hours if your stomach can handle it. The staff is also very nice and attuned to your needs -- and not over-bearing, just how I like my Asian dining experience. 

Tip: Doobu has mocha ice cream on the menu. I would recommend spending a couple extra dollars to cleanse your palette after your spicy meal with ice cream.
author: Linna L.

description:
"Let's go get ramen!!"
"Okay."
"I'm so excited for ramen!!"
"Okay."
"BUT WAIT.  I KIND OF WANT KOREAN FOOD!!"
"Then.. let's go get Korean food.."
"Really?"
"Yeah."
"NOW I DON'T KNOW WHAT I WANNNNT."

This is what my boyfriend has to put up with.  Every single time we get food.  Poor guy.

It is very rare that I get a craving for Korean food up here in San Francisco.  I've mentioned before that the best Korean food is back down in LA, and since I go there once every few months, I get my fill.  However, I really wanted either a bibimbap or kimchee fried rice, and that craving was beating up the ramen craving that I had right before I parked in Japantown.

So, we ended up at Doobu after I remembered a few recent 4-star reviews from fellow Yelpers Wilhelm Y. and Mike L.  Good sign.  Plus, the other Korean restaurant on Post had only 4 people inside, and they weren't Asian.  You win, Doobu.

There were a few other groups in the restaurant (note, this place is not good for parties of more than 4), and there was one booth left.  We sat, and the waitress, a very nice Korean girl, brought us our menus.  I decided on the beef bibimbap (they didn't have kimchee fried rice) and Boyfriend had the spicy pork, which came with rice.

The small plates that came out before the meal were hit or miss.  The fried fish (my FAVORITE), seaweed salad and the fishcakes were good.  The others (soybean sprouts, kimchi, some other pickled cabbage) lacked flavor in general.  The waitress accidentally gave us another egg, and we were confused until she brought out our orders and took the egg back.  Who does that?  I could've used an extra egg!

My bibimbap was in a smaller pot (and more expensive) than the ones I've had in LA or elsewhere, but the stone pot was super hot and kept the rice, beef and veggies piping hot throughout the entire time I was eating.  I liked that the beef wasn't marinated sweet like in others that I've had, but I didn't like how they just cracked the egg into the bowl and didn't fry it first before putting it in.  I know it cooks rapidly because it's so hot, but I'd rather just break up the already-fried egg myself so my chopsticks don't dig into the raw egg yolk.

Boyfriend didn't really enjoy his spicy pork because he said it wasn't enough meat, too many veggies and it wasn't spicy.  I didn't try any because I don't like pork (except bacon and ham), but the meat itself didn't look bad.

When I was almost done with my meal, I looked up on the wall and saw a few small flies posting up on the artwork.  It might've been from the heat wave that we had, but ..it kind of killed my desire to finish eating (I ate the whole bowl anyway).  I'm just glad I saw that after I finished eating, not before.  Hopefully this isn't a recurring problem?

Boyfriend gave this place 3 stars, I gave it 3.5 because of the flies and decent food.  I'll probably go elsewhere for my Korean fix next time.
author: Tori S.

description:
My verdict for this place before I go into detail:

Good food.

Not so good service.

Good food: The tofu was a hit - seafood tofu soup & combo soup - just enough of the yummy foods in the tofu and the it came out very hot, temperature wise. I think I almost burned myself.. lol It was flavorful and not tasteless. You could taste the spices and the tofu oozed with soupy-goodness. 

The banchan was a decent amount food w/ fish. We didn't opt for refills since some people from my group didn't want to eat them - but I've read that they charge for refills...? Mweo???

Purple grain rice! This is the 2nd place I know that services this type of rice. It just sucks that they don't have it in the stone pot to scoop out in front of you - I kind of wanted to eat some of the crispies. 

Not so good service: I don't know what was going on in the kitchen or the servers earlier tonight - maybe they were understaffed or something.. but they like.. either FORGOT my friend's order or there was a MISCOMMUNICATION between the staff and the kitchen - either way, they tried to compensate us with a salad.. Sure... I guess. 

I mean, the tofu all came out fairly fast but her beef bibimbap shouldn't have taken so long or even forgotten.. I guess we waited too long to wave down a server but still.. It's can be frustrating when everyone in your party has already gotten their food and one person in your party still hasn't. -_-

They also mixed up the tofu soup orders and gave me, my friend's and vice versa - not a very big deal but I was pretty sure she handed the wrong tofu to me.. But again, maybe I should've checked it before. Small issue.
The servers were nice but still - forgetting an order is not so fun. 
My friend did say she liked the beef bibimbap though. And I haven't noticed if other places put mushrooms in their dishes - but this place does.

I guess if I come back, it'll be a while since it just wasn't as great an experience as I had hoped for.
author: Susan Y.

description: Wasnt as good as i anticipated. It doesnt taste bad, but there is definitely better korean food in SF that is better than here. I ordered kimchi pancake, which tasted more like a scallion pancake from any chinese restaurant. I also ordered a ghalbi which was just ok.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
The sunshine has been deceptive in SF the whole week. I feel the UV rays, but the low-pressure arctic winds gives me the chills. Not quite east-coast cold, but brrrr. Would a bowl of soon dubu at Doobu's satisfy?...probably so.

Ordered the soon dubu with seafood and veggies. After the egg-crackin' ritual, I dived in and noted the good thick-texture and spicy flavor. They include fried-fish as part of their banchans (always a yay). For some reason, all I get is the soon dubus here. Overall, It was a satisfying/good/fast k-meal in j-town consumed by an abc (hehe...couldn't resist).
author: Derek N.

description: It's between 2  and 3 stars, I gave it the benefit of doubt.  The quality has gone down somehow.  The soup wasn't flavorful.  The lunch bento box just wasn't quite right.  The fried tofu was soggy.  The salad and Galbi was good. They give you red rice.  The skimpy bancha was included, but the flavor wasn't there.  So disappointed, I was so looking forward to their lunch.  No fish.
author: Helen L.

description:
Gotta agree with Krista K here. This place is fabulous. Definitely one of the top choices before a movie at Kabuki. Such great flavors.

The tofu bibimbap is amazing!
author: Nikki M.

description:
Had a couple of OK meals at Doobu (hence two stars instead of one), but then, disaster.  I actually think that was one of the worst dinners I've had in San Francisco, excepting very cheap hole-in-the-walls, almost all of which were still better than this.  

Ordered two soups, one tofu/veggie, one seafood.  Both were so bland as to be almost inedible.  It was a lot like eating a hot bowl of water with weird blobs of nothing that really resembled food.  Such sad, grey veggies!   I mean, how could Korean food be so epically tasteless?  Could barely finish half of what was in my bowl.  

It was early on a Saturday night, so I'm *guessing* the regular chef wasn't in yet.  Not going back to test this theory, tho.
author: Joe B.

description:
Perfect cure for a hangover: something soupy, something spicy. The Koreans do it right.

BF and I were actually hunting for some udon or ramen, actually, in Japantown, but could not resist the allure of this bright orange tarped-little Korean place (which happened to be open at the odd hour of 3pm, thank god) nestled amidst Japanese novelty stores.

I ordered the Vegetable Tofu Soup ("very spicy", which was perfect for my spice-craving tastebuds), he got the Beef Bibimbap (or something like that...)

As is typical with the Korean restaurants I've been to, tofu comes with a side of rice (purple! not typical) and an array of small side dishes including kimchi, seaweed salad, bean sprout salad and fish cakes.

We also, however, each got a little whole fried fish as an appetizer, which I thought was pretty cool.  

Our waitress was lovely--very attentive, despite the late hour, and understanding (if a bit skeptical) of our sometimes strange requests: case in point, BF wanted an additional egg to his bibimbap, but a while after the heat from the stone pot had faded. He just ended up with a gummy, heavy bibimbap, which was sad but understandable. 

Prices are on the higher end, but understandable for 1) Japantown, and 2) such a cute place

Although the restrooms are strange. Never have I been to a place where they tell you the only thing you can flush down is "human waste"-- even paper liners (for the seat) and toilet paper need to be thrown in the trash? HMMMMM...
author: Michelle L.

description:
Surprisingly only a few vegetarian dishes. But the Tofu Vegetable Soup is amazing and worth the trip on any night.

Make sure to let them know your a vegetarian. There are a few hidden animal products, such as one of the common side dishes they give you, and some of the broths.

I went on a Sunday afternoon and it was slow, and had poor service, but it was at an odd time too. So I don't discount for that.
author: Jason S.

description: 超暖胃的；好適合寒冷的夏天來吃！The warm tofu spot is suitable for This cold weather in summer!!! With delicious side dish. If you like spicy you can ask to add a little bite. I like the balance of hot soup and cold side dish together.
author: Meilin J.

description: poor food quality, poor service, pricey, AND forced 20% tips. Never again in my life. Take care.
author: Ethan W.

description: The food taste wasn't as good as other korean around the area, however the tofu menu was good.
author: Patcharaorn T.

description: This restaurant has very nice options for Korean food in Japantown.  Their meal selections,  portions, and prices are very reasonable. We were here on Wednesday night for dinner, it was recommended by a coworker and we were able to make a reservation for a group of five ahead of time, which is very nice for Japantown since we did not have to wait to get seated for a nice meal. I do agree with other Yelpers that this place is probably underrated and is a hidden gem, since there are so many Japanese and Korean food options in this area.  It was not busy at all on Wednesday night, I think only two or three other tables were occupied.  Our waitress was very friendly, helpful, and efficient.  We ordered some drinks and they were served very quickly. We also tried a good variety of Korean dishes on the menu, and everyone enjoyed the food. I especially appreciated that they were very accommodating about customizing meals, since I have some food allergies, and some ingredients had to be taken out.  I am glad we tried this restaurant, and will definitely be going back!
author: Sarah W.

description: Had the bento box lunch special with galbi. It was delicious. I loved the soup on the side. It was a reasonable price. Service was a little slow but I came on the off hours, so it was only one person.
author: Isabel L.

description:
(See pics)

I know it's hard to give a tofu house 4 stars but this is too incredible of an experience!

A friend suggested we all came here. Without knowing what this was by the name, I thought it would be a Korean BBQ place.

I had the hot bubbling tofu dish. It was still cooking when they delivered the dish. It also came with the brown rice. Such a healthy meal.

I also got to taste the deep fried fish which was very good too.

The place was not too busy and the service was very good.

This is a place for a group dinner where you want the relaxing environment sharing food and drinks and having a fun conversation and chitchatting.
author: T L.

description:
They need to hire another server. Service was sooooo slow. Woman was handling 11 tables by herself. 

Food is good, though
author: Yunah R.

description:
My first time having tofu bibimbap! Delicious! I especially loved the crunchy rice on the bottom. My husband and I came here for a late lunch on a Sunday and the place was very empty so our food came very quickly. 

I will definitely come here again!
author: Jen A.

description: I'm really puzzled that this place doesn't have more stars. Their soon tofu is incredibly delicious, especially the seafood one with medium spicy. I love their grilled mackerel and pancake with beef. The panjan is wonderful, and the service is incredibly kind. It's the best Korean food in SF at the moment, and it always being packed with Koreans is a sign I'm not the only one who thinks that.
author: Cyn K.

description:
I found a new Korean spot! With a little help. =)
I went with a friend for the first time, the food was excellent ! They were short staffed it was just the two of them cooking , hosting and cleaning. I have to say they handled it well. 
I was shocked after I ordered they gave us a whole (small) fried fish for an appetizer that was the first time I had seen that so I was surprised . My friend saw my face a reassured me it was good and to be careful of the bones. I didn't really like the taste of the fish but it was cooked very nicely (tender and juicy).
I ordered the Chicken Bibimbap I was so hungry after cleaning that is made me full. they give you a lot of food!.
The couple running this restaurant is so nice and they are genuinely concerned with your experience and I like that.
author: Sherrell D.

description:
So-so.
I am explorer, and have to say it was my second Korean meal ever.
The restaurant has a great location in the disputed area of Japan town. It's small but clean, tables and Boothe are as close together to maximize the space, but not tight enough that it takes your privacy away.

It was a Friday night and they seemed understaffed. There was literally one young server running, yes running, to help all customers. I am confident everyone was serviced ok, it's not his fault, but it was extremely unpleasant to see him running and throwing the aluminum cart close to the kitchen entrance to grab another one.

The food was kinda blend. I expected a nice and tasty ottogi but I was rather blend, and the little plates weren't anything special. I probably wouldn't come back.
If you are desperate for a place to eat, perhaps this is for you.
author: Filipe G.

description:
Ever eat at a restaurant that leaves an impression so strong that you just have got to create a yelp account just to review it? This restaurant is one of such.

The menu says they'll charge 18% tip for parties of 6 or more. 

I came in early today for the first time with my mom, grandma, and two brothers. If the restaurant staff was unable to count, that makes FIVE people. We had japchae, one BBB, two combo bulgogi+tofu soup, and just one solo tofu soup

Received the bill to see that the waitress took the liberty of adding the extra tip herself. We inquire about this; she mumbles something like 'Yes, we do this sometimes if people order too much food'

Order too much food? Since when was one dish per person too much food?

Had I known I might have ordered less, just to avoid that tip, but now I'm going to do the favor of never coming back again.


P.S. Get a new freaking toilet. Posted sign in the women's bathroom currently reads that the toilet jams when flushed with substances other than human waste (read: toilet paper, toilet seats covers?!?!) A trash receptacle is placed beside the toilet for customer's convenience...
author: Eve V.

description:
I love Doobu!  Well, maybe not LOVE since it seems that my favorite waitress is gone now, but it's still pretty damn good!  Not quite on the level of My Tofu House for me taste wise, but you can't beat the lack of a serious wait.  Been here a number of times now, and I think we only had to wait for a table twice, and neither of those times was the wait longer than 5-10 mins.  The servers are all really friendly, and are certainly hard workers.  Typically there are only two working on shift, so while things can slow down from time to time, it's hard to blame them when there's a full house.

Their soon doobu (tofu soup) tastes pretty good, but has a thinner consistency than My Tofu House.  There's some definite kick as you move up the spiciness scale, so those with a weak stomach have been warned.  There's plenty of good stuff loaded in, but not too much of any one thing, so plus points on the balance there.  Also, the variety of soups is pretty decent, ranging from the usual suspects to more unique ones like ham and cheese and corned beef.

One tweak compared to most tofu soup places is that you get a bowl of purple-ish rice...some sort of red bean or taro rice?  Either way, it's better than the usual white rice just for something different.  Their Haemul Pajun (Seafood Pancake) is not bad...about average to what I've had and a decent amount of fillings with a good dipping sauce.  If anything, maybe a little doughy for my taste, but I know one of my friends likes it that way so that's more of a personal thing.  As for the meat plates...holding comment for now.  The first and only time we got something, we felt it was a little light on meat and heavy on onion compared to the neighboring table.  Not sure if the orders were mixed up or if that's how it was intended, so will have to order it a second time just to make certain.
author: Mike L.

description:
fast and friendly and close to my house...
I love the little fried fish they bring  you, just cuz...and the food is good, not incredibly great but pretty good for a weeknight Korean craving.
author: Nilu r.

description: My family loves this place.  First time we were there several years ago there was a lot of side dishes (banchan) given out.  They are good about refills on the side dishes.  Hits the spot.  It can get spicy, so we ordered mild spiciness.
author: Husky D.

description: Service okay, often get neglected.  Food is okay but varies time to time.  I've been here twice for Oyster soon tofu and it's always out.  If they are out again the next time, I'm never coming back again.
author: Juila L.

description:
How to have a Pre-Movie Dinner in 30 Minutes Flat

Walk into Doobu Friday @ 7pm, grab a seat, peruse menu, raise eyebrow at the ham and cheese tofu soup, order the old standbys seafood tofu soup and seafood pajun, drum fingers on the tabletop, are we gonna make the movie, nosh on ok banchan, food is here already, ugh that pajun is greasy, and burned on the bottom too, tofu soup is pretty good but spicy for a "medium," sweat, more water, bill please, we're walking, we're walking, why hello lovely friends at Kabuki Cinema, hug hug kiss kiss, 10 minutes till movie time.*

*Coincidentally, just enough time to grab a brownie and a beer.  :)
author: Amy C.

description:
Thanks to Wilhelm Y. and his recent review, my curiosity was sparked again about the little Korean restaurant in Japantown with the bright orange awning above its front entrance.

Before heading over to the Kabuki Theater to see "State of Aloha" during the Asian American Film Festival, we ordered a quick meal of mushroom tofu and teriyaki chicken.  I loved the banchan:  kimchee, fried little fish, pickled daikon, tofu, rice noodles, spiced radishes, etc., and we loved the tasty fried fish that came separately (why is it that fish with small bones are always the tastiest?) - it's a test of good chopstick skills to get to the meat of the fish, but it is well worth it.  

When the mushroom tofu arrived, we cracked an egg into it and broke it apart so that it could cook in the tofu soup, loved it, loved it.  And the rice was a brown, healthy rice.  The chicken was sweet, tender and tasty. 

The service was real nice.  Since I ordered the mushroom tofu, the lady nicely asked me if I was vegetarian and if I would prefer not having the fried little fish and the other fried fish that came later - I'm not vegetarian but that was still nice of her to check.  We hurriedly ate and I think she sensed our anxiety about missing our movie, so she efficiently brought over a box for our leftover chicken and our check.  

No one was in the restaurant when we first arrived around 5:45 PM, but it sure quickly filled up.  I liked the ambiance, comfortable, simple and easy-going.

Thank you!  We'll be back!  Thanks, Wilhelm!

Shared mushroom tofu+teriyaki chicken+tax+tip = $28
author: Maile N.

description: My favorite soondoobu place in the area is Tofu House in Palo Alto (Mark Zuckerberg's fav) so I was hesitant to try a new place. I must say though that I was pleasantly surprised. Service was fast, and food was good and spicy. I got the vegetarian dish and it was nice to have broccoli, cauliflower, and carrots in addition to the standard mushroom.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Well, Korea town in LA spoiled me too much. Like my other reviews for korean restaurants here in SF, it's a big EHHHHHH-OK.

Kimchi Soondobu: EHHHH. It's hot, it's got tofu in there but something's missing

Bibimbap: Served in hot stone pot, yummy. I would get more sesame oil!

Great place to go for my korean food fix in my neighborhood.
author: Emily T.

description: Great bibimbap! The tofu was delusions. Don't let the location in the middle of Japan town put you off. This Korean food was delicious. Wait until you get all the sides,  you get a lot of food so don't over order. Enjoy!
author: Brent H.

description: I've only come here for their lunch menu.  A set box lunch consisting of rice, salad, tofu soup, and your choice of meat.  A good amount of food for a decent cheap price, so you can't expect too much.  I've always left here satisfied and willing to come back.
author: Karen L.

description:
Reviews from my friends made this place seem amazing. But yelp made it sound like the total opposite. I was honestly hesitant after reading all the bad reviews on yelp, but I was craving Korean food and I really wanted to try something new! We drove around Japantown on a Saturday night and there was NO PARKING! We tried to park in the parking lot but that was full too... but persevere, because the food is worth it! There is normally only 1 person working, but there were 2 that night :) Then they seated us at these hugee tables! It could definitely fit 6 and 8 crammed but there was only the 4 of us, so it was roomy and comfortable! We instantly ordered the spicy pork and spicy seafood soup combo, korean pancake, dokboki, and kimchi bimbimbap. The dokboki was a little undone, and there wasn't enough sauce... sigh. The korean pancake was oily and wasn't so crunchy as I normally like. The kimchi bimbimbap was bomb though. I enjoyed the sauce, the stickiness of the rice and the bottom crunchies. The spicy pork was good too, I wish they weren't shreds though and the soup was tasty but small. By the way, yelpers were complaining about their soup... I don't see what's wrong with it, haha. Hmm... I had nothing to complain about when I was there... maybe because I was SUPER hungry haha. But overall this place is yummy and decently priced. We werent super full, but that just gave us room for sophies crepes!
It was our lucky night after all!
author: Linda K.

description:
Went here for dinner a couple times before, but the food and service has gone downhill. The free fried fish for and appetizer was ok, but tasted extra fishy and full of bones. The Teriyaki Chicken was dry and the Seafood Tofu soup was very watery. The sides tasted like it was sitting out all day. 

Long story short... we had dinner and paid our bill. We left a generous tip for our non-existent waitress that just brought us our food and left.  

I would give them no stars if I could because of what happened next. After we walked out the door, the waitress came running after us with the bill in her hand. She said we only paid the bill and left no tip. What?!?! We told her to look on the table. Anyways, Who runs after a customer and beg them for tips. Last time I checked, it is not mandatory to tip. We were being nice by leaving her a generous tip too. The nerve of her! Needless to say, they lost a good customer.
author: Cindy W.

description:
If you ever want a simple and cost effective Korean meal, Doobu is the place for you. The meat and tofu combination is your best bet. I like the Kalbi and the seafood tofu combo the best. The spicy pork isn't that good in my opinion. If you want something different, the Bibimbap is tasty too but not enough meat in my opinion. Their side veggie dishes are good but few in selection compared to other Korean restaurants. Lastly, their multi grain rice is interesting; I think the verdict is till out on that one.

You will come out of Doobu full, and the meal won't bleed  your wallet.

~A
author: Alex C.

description: Delicious food and (usually) friendly service. The spicy pork is excellent and of course so is the soft tofu soup. Also if you are in the area at lunchtime check out their lunch specials - they are absolutely great.
author: Ananth U.

description:
My friend and I went to this restaurant on a whim. We wanted Korean food, and this seemed to be our cheapest option. It was helpful that they had a menu outside as well as pamphlets outside with the prices and descriptions. My friend and I could walk around Japantown while comparing the prices to this restaurant. We finally caved and went in. The place was pretty empty, but it was around 3:30pm-4:00pm, so it's understandable. We waited to be seated, even though there weren't many customers. It took maybe 30 seconds before a waiter helped us to our seat--not bad. The waitress was fairly nice, but seemed to be rushing all the time. I didn't see a reason for her to rush considering there were maybe two other small parties eating. She was able to take our orders when we were ready, and refilled our glasses promptly, without us asking. 

There wasn't much variety to the food--alot of the basic stuff: kalbi, donaksum spicy tofu stew. The food came pretty quickly. We also got appetizers, which were fried fish. It was decent, my friend really liked it because it was what her mom cooked for her in China. I thought it was ok, but it was cold! If you give an appetizer it should at least be warm, i don't really care if you microwave it. As long as it's warm when it gets to me. The bibimbap was fine also. I've eaten bibimbap form many different restaurants, and this one didn't really meet the standards of the others. For reference, I got the beef bibimbap. It wasn't a very colorful bowl of bibimbap. It had carrots and lettuce but they weren't vibrantly colored. I did like the sauce for the bibimbap though. it made it better overall. The beef, even among the rice and sauce, didn't seem like it had very much seasoning in and of itself. it was quite bland.
author: Athena P.

description:
Korean? More like Mediocre-Rean.  (Say it out loud so it makes more sense...) 

I knew I should have turned around as soon as I saw the 2 Cute 4 School waitress wearing a shirt with "LEAVE ME ALONE" emblazoned in Arial Black Size 24 Bold Font.

Then, when we tried to get a table closer to the middle (as opposed to at the far back next to the bathroom) and the lady said "NO, TABLE IS RESERVED" even though it was the exact same table size & shape. Not to mention, we were there for over an hour and that "Reserved" table stayed empty. The entire time. WTF KOREA? 

Monica was right when she sang, "U SHOULDA KNOWN BETTER"

In addition, the food was not good. The "Spicy Chicken" was nothing but chopped chicken pieces (think Teriyaki Chicken orders) then slathered in some generic, unflavorful "spicy" red sauce, then slapped onto a "sizzling iron platter" which was neither sizzling nor awesome. True let down.

Someone else ordered the Teriyaki Chicken, which is why I have an expert opinion as to what the Spicy Chicken resembled, and it was literally the same thing as the Spicy Chicken, but instead of being slathered in generic, unflavorful "spicy" red sauce, it was a congealed, sweet brown "teriyaki" sauce.

N-E-WAYZ

I am just bitter because it truly wasn't worth coming out smelling like Korean smoke, you know what I mean?

The banchan they gave us came with only six plates. SIX!?!? Helloooo? And when we asked for refills, Ms. LEAVE ME ALONE got a little snotty, and then proceeded to come back with only 4 plates of refills, 2 of which were completely different from what we originally got, which led me to the conclusion that she was not only picking & choosing, but skimping. Excuse you!!!!!
author: Joshua L.

description:
Came here with two of my fellow linguistics classmates for late night grub one night. Service was quick, but it seemed like the manager wanted to scoot us out of there asap since it was 40 minutes before closing time. 

I ordered the Mandu Soft Tofu soup, while my classmates ordered Kimchi and Pork Soft Tofu soup. We like it somewhat spicy, so we went with that and shared a Hyumael Paajeon (Korean Seafood Pancake). The food was delicious since we were starving, freezing and we had just taken a midterm for our Korean linguistics class. This was the best way to warm us up during the week. 

Service: The waitress failed to refill our ice waters and our banchan dishes. At the same time, one shouldn't wipe the floors while we're eating. We left before it closed, but the workers didn't have to be so rude about it. 

Overall: PRICEY.. For the price we paid for food, I'm glad we didn't leave a tip for the shitty service. 

The only thing that really stood out for this place is one item on the menu. It was the Ham & Cheese Tofu soup. For me, it sounds interesting, but at the same time..Who would want to drink cheese grease soup?! Bleagh..
author: Jason C. J.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch here today.  Was going to go to Tanpopo but then we came across this place and went to check it out instead. 

Legit soon dubu...and you can mix and match different ingredients!  I had dumpling+kim chi.  The soup isn't watered down like other places...it's hot and creamy, and loaded with tofu.  The ban chan was wonderful...and the fish they give you is a good size.   

Definitely on my soon dubu go-to's now along with my tofu house!
author: Justin L.

description:
I am not good at ordering Korean food.  I rarely go to Korean restaurants unless it's the one where you can cook yourself or all you can eat.  But I was craving these "glass" noodles I had as a side dish a couple weeks ago.

So I come in and sit down with the bf in tow.  He orders the seafood Bibimbap (sp?) and I get the Tofu Jap Chae for kicks.  

The waitress comes out with a couple sides:  seasoned seaweed & onions, something stringy like finely diced fish cake, kim chee, and something that was pickled.  I ate all the slightly sweet, vinegary seaweed but left everything else rather untouched (just me, not a fan of certain spices).  She also gave us two complimentary (?) fried fish which I gave up eating after a bone lodged itself between my gum and molar ):

I loved my jap chae.  It had spinach, onions, red bell peppers, mushrooms, broccoli and tofu delightfully stir-fried with glass noodles.  The broccoli was a bit undercooked but it was barely noticeable.  I think the dish might have been better with baby spinach.

I also liked my bf's bibimbap though I am not a fan of seafood at all.  His dish was still steaming long after I had finished my meal (probably because of the awesome iron bowl it came in).  

I'm no Korean cuisine connoisseur but I would probably come back here because I liked what I ate.  It was a little steep in price but I've never found a cheap Korean restaurant anyways.  My own meal + soda was around $15 incl. tip.  My bf's was about $20.  It was a good, hearty, meat-free meal.  3.5 starzs
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
First and last time here.

Food was below average. Also we had to crack the eggs for the tofu soup ourselves. 

Worst part was the waitress chased us down after we left because I "didn't have common curtosy to leave 15%". Really? .. Really? I tipped easily over 15% pre-tax (she was showing me the credit card bill). And even then the difference between what she chased me down for and what she got was 21 cents.
author: Greg M.

description:
My go-to spot for lunch when working near Japantown.

The Galbi lunch special ($8.95) is a great deal: soup, purple rice, DELICIOUS salad with fried tofu, kimchi & sides, and plenty of sesame seeds covering galbi. 

Definitely worth checking out. Dine and take it all in. Or try ordering to go, as many people have their varying opinions about the staff.

Haven't tried Doobu during dinner time, but I can assume there is a bring crowd, based off the regularly packed lunch hour.
author: Drea B.

description:
BBB only review.
 
I am talking about Bi Bim Bup.

My BBB craving is still coming twice in a week at least.

I was avoiding the place only because I am not big on Korean Tofu soup.
I like Korean BBQ very much but not that boiling torture terror shit by John Yoo like.

Korean Tofu Soup is way too hot in terribly bad way.
Korean BBQ is way too hot in extremely good Way.

Difference between Korea and Japan is weather.
That's all.
People are very similar.
Hot temper, sexist, women come second, harass people often, arrogant, dick, asshole, ..... Man, it sounds like any one.

I have heard that Northern Korea had better Kimchee.
I think Seoul is too close to North Korea for capital of South Korea.
My home town was a mecca of Koreans ( still is.)
And they are K to 8 North Korean schools.
And there are pictures of Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il in the class rooms. I think it's outrage. For me, Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il are criminals.
And there are people who still support North Korea in Japan.

..................................

I like Banchan I like Kimchee
I like a Bup, Bup, Bi Bim Bup Shit

Bunchan, Kimchee, BiBimBup and me
a bup, a bup, a bup, a bup, a bup

about the Doobu
My heart bump up a little when I see that BBB in the menu.
I had to have the Doobu's BBB.
It is in a large hot stone bowl comes with Banchan.
They don't have cold version.
11 bucks.

The BBB isn't that bad.
Service was good.

BBB is the dish that it won't go that bad.
I mean, I never had a really bad BBB.
How can you go wrong?

Even though I had a bad diarrhea many times because of raw-egg.
But that's BS because that sounds like you are complaining how filthy table in a Chinese restaurant.
There is no such a thing clean table Chinese restaurant.
If table is clean, it's something else.

You can't go wrong having BBB.
BBB is decent food, great for lunch.
It maybe, BBB was,  a all OK, so so, yo-yo food like having a sandwich or taco like. Basically, BBB is dump things into a bowl. Pretty easy thing to make. People made it by own before but no one make it own any more like food.
Because we are so lazy now.

But, I like my BBB made by some one else.
Fxxx me but it's true.
author: Nobu K.

description: Been to this restaurant for multiple times. Their soft tofu soup is fantastic, couldn't ask for more!!! Will coming back for more!
author: Kevin A.

description:
Sigh..... I cannot believe that i'm gonna have to rank this to lower rate and it aches me to rate from 5 to 3. even though it was me and my friend favorite place before. And, at this present still as well since it gives her and me good memories. 

- 2 stars
Recently, me and my friend went to doobu for lunch. We ordered one soup to share and order with extra rice along with the side dishes. I was excited for dish to come out coz of the fish. Since it's always good and crunchy on the outside. As my friend, she just does like having clam for soup choice. Anyways, when our meal arrived, I go on eating the fish again but when I taste it. It doesn't taste right as my friend trying her clam soup. Hers went wrong as well but we still decided to continue to finish it so we could ASAP. Since its the same server that we encounter before that chase customers for tips.

Anyways, i cannot really rant much of why it's not good, sorry to keep it sealed. All i know is, they need to improve their customer service. 
1. As a server, always a good idea to check the soup if it's good to go or not before serving to customers. Not just handling to them because that's not a way to do it as a server. Why? It regards to customer satisfaction, If wanted bonus(extra tips).
2. It's better to get certain side dishes last after getting the soup. So it will still taste right not just sat at an area that will get cold soon while waiting for soup.

+3 stars
Like I said before in one of my paragraphs, about cannot rant much and it brings great memory. One or two years ago my friend and i came here, made a friend that used to work here and given us a nice customer satisfaction. Though I did wish he works here again but oh we'll. Everyone has its own reasonable thing, hehe.
author: Lorrine L.

description: I really liked this place. Surprisingly, it wasn't crowded on a Saturday night. But it was just the kind of thing I wanted--- since I was dining alone. Got the kimchi bibimbap and loved it. Service was really excellent as well. The waitress always had a smile on her face.  Very pleased with experience.
author: Jigesha D.

description:
Out of all of the eating establishments in Japantown, I'd have to say Doobu is the best place to eat. Yes, a Korean restaurant in Japantown is the best place to eat...well, there's also Playground (another Korean place), but I think of Playground more as a nighttime kind of place. I don't think Playground is even open during the daytime (I'll have to check on that after I write this update).

Anyway, despite the somewhat limited menu in comparison to Playground, Doobu tops out for the versatility and the lunch special. For 7.95, you get a choice of meat ($1 extra for Kalbi), tofu soup, 3 side dishes, a bowl of rice, a salad, and a yogurt drink. It's a pretty hefty platter; usually I don't go for lunches over $5, but this one was a true exception. Plus, as I already said, the plate is hefty, so it's well worth the money.

If you miss out on the lunch special (11am to 3pm M-F only), that's okay. The rest of the menu is still great; prices are average for Korean establishments ($10 for most of the tofu soup, $15 or so for the other dishes). Extra kudos for the variety in bibimpap and the combinations (tofu soup + meat). They're very generous with the banchan as well, and, if dining with a friend or two, you'll each get a fried fish to nibble on.

Service is prompt and friendly; decor is chic and modern. I can't say it enough, but this is the place to go for good food in Japantown.
author: Helene K.

description:
Lots of tofu options, though most of the tofu dishes have meat in them. So much better than the place across the street, Tanpopo, in every way but especially for vegetarian/vegan options and quality of food and service. 

I had the tofu bibimbap, no egg, and asked for extra kimchi. The kimchi was soooo good. I grew up eating kimchi and rice with every meal so I make sure I get as much kimchi as I can when I have the opportunity. My waitress was really sweet and I will definitely come here again when I'm in the area - probably after visiting Kinokuniya and the other great shops in Japantown.
author: Emily M.

description: It's been 20 years since the last time I visited sf from LA. This morning my family and I found this spot in the heart of J-town and since we wanted Korean food, we checked it out. We ordered the oyster tofu (spicy), clam tofu (spicy), combination tofu (spicy), and tofu bibimbap. Right off the bat, everything tasted sweet. Tofu is not supposed to be sweet(imo).  But what threw me off was the denial of extra side dishes. Normally, Korean restaurants are supposed to offer unlimited side dishes, but the waiter said "I can't give you extra side dishes because we're too busy." which translates to "hurry and get the f out."  yeah never going to come back here again.
author: Nick L.

description:
Doobu is great for lunch because it's efficient even with one waitress. I've never seen someone move so fast except perhaps when I am playing "cooking dash" on the iphone.

You get a great value for your buck. In addition to ample portions of food, Doobu serves up a wide variety of  delicious side dishes including a fried fish. The sizzling seafood tofu soup comes with an egg so you can drop it in. 

There are giant booths where you can sit and chat with friends or side tables where you can observe people and unwind. Next time I am dragging friends so we can get our fill of fried fish, kimchi, fish cake, and seaweed.
author: Sophie C.

description:
For my fellow Koreans - you remember that one kid who had a mother who couldn't really cook but would force you to eat whenever you were over anyway? Something about pride in taking care of other people's children...that's kind of what this place is like, only you're paying to eat here.

Everything at Doobu tastes like it was bought pre-packaged from the local HK Market with the addition of random garnishment combinations created with whatever was leftover in the fridge. Hell, you can request ham and cheddar cheese be added to your spicy tofu soup (which I admit is pretty O.G. Korean, +1 star).

It's a bit on the pricier side as well given the fact that the whole place has a to-go cafe vibe. Stuff you'd pay $8 to $10 for in LA comes priced at $15+. The bulgogi and kalbi dishes are $20+ IIRC for a smaller order.

It's a good thing you can't mess up basic Korean dishes too bad (hence the 3 star total), so sit yourself down, order the combination tofu soup extra spicy, and make sure to say 'Jal-mog-ot-sseb-ni-da,' as you leave, confused at the fact that you keep coming back to this slightly below-average restaurant when there's not even a Super Nintendo system to play to make the meal worth it.
author: Leo K.

description:
Tried the bibimbap and seafood tofu soup. It was standard, with just a few side dishes, nothing really that sticks out. Prices are maybe above average for what it was - quality and experience-wise. 

I don't know if I'd really go back unless there's nothing else open and I'm really craving Korean food.
author: Victoria K.

description: Chosen by proximity to our hotel more than specific desire, especially since I live in LA's Koreatown ("Hi, I'm from New Orleans, got any crawfish?"); nevertheless, the chicken dolsot bibimbap did not disappoint, and definitely made up for the higher pricepoint with a whole lotta chicken.
author: John M.

description:
The good:

1. They put a ton of tofu in their soonduboo. Well at least they did in mine. Hell, the stew was packed with all kinds of stuff. Rocked.
2. The side dishes were fresh. 
3. Very clean and comfortable
4. The bibimbap is massive

The bad:
1. The prices. The soonduboo is a bit pricey (9.45), and the bibimbap is super expensive for that type of dish (10.45? close to that). Then again they do give you big portions. 
2. Spicy isn't that spicy

Overall, a decent Korean place in Japantown.
author: Sean B.

description:
This place is so hit or miss. Usually there's only one person working there, so if it's busy then the service is going to be awful. However, on an empty night like tonight (a sleepy Tuesday), the guy was really great and had the time to be attentive.

The food is also 50/50. The ban chan I got tonight were kind of bland, but the fried fish was really yummy.  I also thought that the dumplings in my dumplin soon doobu were great - the insides had lots of good flavor! However, the rice cakes in my soup seemed a little undercooked (some were so chewy they were almost inedible). 

I just don't like that the food quality and service are unpredictable. You can spend a little more at My Tofu House for an experience that is consistently good. At this point, I think I'm only going back to Doobu out of habit.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I had a great experience dining here. 

During lunch hours they have some great deals going on. I paid $8 for a full meal with tofu soup, bulgogi, rice, salad, and side dishes. It gets really busy during lunch, but the servers were working as fast as they could. 


Service was fast and the food was delicious. 

Will be coming here again. :)
author: Selina K.

description:
01.30.11

It's Sunday night and I'm hungry and impatient.  Suzu had a wait list of 10+ tables before us.  Tanpopo had a line out the door.  Unable to satisfy my ramen craving, we walked across the way to Doobu, where we were seated immediately.

Service was quick and friendly.  Complimentary fried fish upon arrival with our tea.  Three orders of soondubu and an order of kalbi for the table.  Mild, medium and spicy all ordered.  I thought mine was fine, but nothing special.

Would probably return if I fail out of ramen again.
author: Jenny L.

description:
It's good.  I can't complain about this place.  Obviously it's the best soon-do-bu house I've been to, but it isn't horrible.  I prefer My Tofu House in Inner Richmond, but sometimes I just can't make that hike.  Doobu is pretty close and soondobu is perfect for hangovers -- so it does the job.

I also go for the Dduk Mando (rice cake & dumpling) soondoobu, medium or spicy (depending on my mood).
author: S R.

description: Basic decor. Rather empty on a Thursday night so our service was good. Very good Tofu Soups that arrive bubbling to your table. We had the seafood and it was tasty. Also had the Galbi short ribs which were ok. Not hot off the grill which I would have preferred. We also had a silver noodle dish which was simple but kind of expensive for $14. The rice is good. A mixture of sticky white rice and red rice.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
...on a chilly night, a pot of spicy (mild for me) tofu with either beef or seafood does the trick. it clears up my sinus =) 

Luv their small dishes that accompany the tofu (cucumber, bean sprout, anchovies, etc...and the purple-ish rice: yum!  they used to serve a small fried fish but the last two times i was there, they didn't (boo hoo). AND what happened to the free yogurt drink!!! that's gone too =(  (hence i am only giving it 3stars...it's like taking candies away from a kid)

BBQ Kalbi is yummy (tho i personally think ARANG makes it better and more tender)...go try it!

I haven't tried their soju so....you tell me...

Overall, this is a great restaurant for quick tasty Korean food. 3stars is just right =)
author: Vee V.

description:
Not bad. Great, friendly service, even with just that one woman manning the fort. Seafood pancake was a bit too thick, soft tofu soup had lots of tofu yet failed in the soup department, spicy pork was more like spicy pork bits, but all still tasted good. I loved the fried tofu salad.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Food was decedent. Nothing to remember. Server asked us how we were doing once. We had to call her over 3x to get more napkins, and other things. When we were done we had our checks split 3 ways. One of us left cash tip, and the other left on credit card. So one credit card receipt did not have a tip. The lady hounded my friend for a tip. He has every intention of leaving cash and waited for my other friend to get out of the restroom. She continued to hound him about a tip and said if we liked her food we should leave a tip, continued for another few minutes till we told her that we don't have too. Then she walked away pouting. Mind you this lady was older. I found it disrespectful and poor customer service to hound someone for a tip.
author: Jennah B.

description:
It was a cold, rainy day, and I was shopping with a friend in Japantown.  We were starving and craving ramen; unfortunately, so was everybody else.  Suzu was packed and wasn't taking anymore names on the list (they close at 3 p.m.!), so we wandered around outside of the Japantown mall to see what else we could find.

We stumbled across Doobu, and a hot, steamy bowl of tofu soup seemed like it could hit the spot.  There was no wait, so we sat down immediately.  I got the pork tofu soup medium spicy, it was tasty, hot and filling.  The food was good, and I would probably go back, though it doesn't seem like they have much else besides tofu soup.  I like going to places that have a wider variety of menu items - it's all about having lots of different things to try! - and Doobu didn't have that much variety (though I was intrigued by the ham and cheese tofu soup).  The soups were ~$11.

On a positive note, if you like fried fish, we each got a fried fish to start our meals!
author: Wendy L.

description:
We came here with some friends that recommended it. They were after the Tofu Soup, which I am not a fan of.
So I ordered the Fried Tofu Salad, which was excellent. I'd get this any day. It was just perfect. 
They also had a really good nutty rice that tasted excellent. 
Shared with a bottle of Korean Beer. I was in heaven.
author: Germaine N.

description:
Where else can you find corned beef tofu (doobu) soup or a Korean version of ham and cheese with doobu?  This place is great for some side dishes of seaweed, fish cakes, bean sprouts and other "pan chan".  The Korean style barbecue meat (galbi) was marinated well, but the quality of meat can be tender or tough to chew.  Moreover, they are sliced up into smaller section to look like a plate full of meat.  The stone pot rice (dolsot bibimbap) is good with a different flavor than white rice, but can be crispier.  Overall, this is a good place to sit down and enjoy doobu.

Parking is tough on the street unless you park in the local garages.  However, it's an easy and cost-effective option that's worth it especially if you're shopping and/or wandering around after your meal.
author: Jenny L.

description:
After getting tenderized at Suchada for an hour and a half, I was totally dazed and starving.  I went to J town coz I was craving some strawberry and peanut butter mochi from Benkyodo but damn them, they were on vacation.  Forlorned, I wandered about the square in J town and decided to give this place a try coz I was really about to pass out from starvation.  I wasnt expecting much from a place named doobu (as cute as the name is) coz I couldnt realy decide if this place is Japanese or Korean or conFuzn food.  

Anyways,

It's a cozy lil restaurant. Service was quick and friendly.  I ordered the lunch special with chicken teriyaki.  The bento was average.  The chicken could definitely be better.  The spicy soup with clam, beef and tofu  totally hit the spot.  4 stars for the great soup alone.
author: Kris H.

description: The tofu bibimbap was amazing! One of the best I've ever had! Was skeptical coming in since it had only 3.5 stars, but was positively surprised. There was a little too much onions in it but it was super good nonetheless. Vegetarians have to try this place!
author: Justin L.

description:
UPDATE:
I've come back to Doobu about 4 times since my last review, and the food gets more and more disappointing. Maybe it's because I'm not with my previous Asian friends, or we didn't ask for the right things? I don't know.... I noticed you get short changed on the little plates if you seem (or look) like you're unfamiliar with Korean food. These visits served up the most bland, basic, "whatever" side dishes, that set the tone for me. To add insult to injury, my dolsot bibimbaps were just not up to par from the first dish I had here. Maybe it's like drugs --- you're always chasing your first high. Don't know if I'll be back here, but decor is still cute.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Can I just say.... dolsot bibimbap. My lordy Doobu makes a damned good dish of it! The stone bowl piping hot, and luckily we were distracted by our delicious, yet not as spicy as I would've liked, tofu soup (with oysters), that we left the bibimbap crisping and crunching. 

That's the trick, don't touch it straight away. Let the bowl sit for a while, dress the dish with spicy sauce (you have to ask for it), and mix, mix, mix. Your eyes will roll to the back of your head as the crunchy bits of rice, beef, sauce and egg (yes, don't skip that egg!) amalgamate into a bibimbap orgasm. *sigh* That hot bowl is my new boyfriend!

Loved: said dish, decor, cleanliness, service, fair prices.

Did not love so much: kitchen needs to deliver spicy when I say spicy, wish the tofu soup was a bit larger
author: Antoi C.

description: It's a good value, and you get to choose the level of spiciness for the tofu soup and there's chili paste on the table too.  You get many sides, which are quite good.  The server will help you crack the egg into the soup, which is helpful if you're clumsy and otherwise I'll get eggshells in it.
author: Dan C.

description: This place sucks... Japan town mall was closed today that's why we went to this restaurant. Waited for a long time for the food and the taste was not acceptable. I ordered the hotpot thing and the shrimp was tiny as a quarter and the beef is just chewing gum. I would've stayed home and cook!
author: Max C.

description:
I love coming here to grab their soft tofu soup. It's just delish and honestly the experience for the price is well worth it.

When you come in, you get seated right away and within seconds there is a complementary hot tea and cold water set in front of you and if you are ready, the server takes your order. I am traditional and always order the combination soft tofu soup with beef, oystes, etc.  Then the snacks start coming.

Btw, i have to say, that I particularly like the fact that they have metal chopsticks and not the wooden ones. It's a pain to get rid of the splinters on them when you tear them apart, and so the chopsticks and the long spoon is a nice touch.

Back onto the review. Where was I ... Oh yeah, the snacks. First, they bring you a fried sardine, which is nice and crispy. By the time you are done with that, the rest of the dishes arrive. There is always kimchee, seaweed, sprouts, zucchini, and I think this time there was a potato dish. Did I mention you can get a refill?! Yuuuuuum.

The soft tofu soup is great, although I wish there was one with just beef and oysters sans the clams and shrimp. They bring a fresh egg that you can crack in yourself and a side of rice. The pot is hot, and even though it looks small, every time I wal outta here, I feel like a rollypolly cause I'm stuffed with delicious korean food. 

Service is prompt, courteous, and the restaurant itself is cozy. I come here on a regular basis and so far no disappointments and only glorious food!!!!
author: Yelena K.

description:
Went there in the afternoon when there's no crowd.  Standard Korean fare, had soon doobu - tofu stew with beef and seafood.  I think, these days, it's hard to get traditional right.  My side dishes were good, though kimchee was weak.  The deep fried fish was a treat though, and so was the screaming hot stew in earthenware.  

It SHOULD be screaming hot, because you crack a raw egg in it, and let the temperature of the stew heat it up.  Frankly, I make a better soon-doobu, but it does take a little time.  http://www.maangchi.com/recipe/soondubu-jjigae
or
http://www.noodlefever.com/2009/11/spice-girl-pork-and-mushroom-soon-dubu.html

Not 5 stars because side dishes were sparse and "spicy" was not really all that spicy.  Solid food, and would go back to try more if in the neighborhood and wanted Korean.  Though, seriously, it's Japantown.  Should be supporting the Japanese establishments there, otherwise, why go to Japantown?

Hypocrisy aside... lunch special looks good at a very reasonable $7.95 served before 3 p.m.  I don't know if people know how much Korean food usually costs, but it ain't cheap.  

Service and decor good.  Spacious and comfortable.
author: HQ G.

description: Just comparing this to bcd tofu house in LA, i think  the flavor is actually better. All meals come with side dish and fried fish. Purple rice is also good. The service though maybe a little less desirable.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Doobu = Tofu
Doobu House in Japantown = As good as it gets in the city

I have to admit that in one week I came here 3 times.  If you've ever had soondubu (spicy silken tofu soup) in Korea, I can guarantee you that the soondubu here is the closest thing to homeland's original than anywhere else in SF.  

Order the kimchi, pork soondubu and ask for it spicy. It's savory, it's hot, and it's filling.

Sure the place only has 1 or 2 waitstaff at hand, but I don't go to a restaurant for its service, I go there to GRUB, and grub I do yessiree. So if you are hesitant to try this place out -- don't be -- because you're going to miss out on a truly authentic and delicious Korean dish :)
author: Helen L.
