description: Their lunch special is warmed in a microwave. The soup, though tasty, was luke-warm. The ice berg lettuce salad was a disappointment. And the side-dishes are so/so. Although the server did refill my tea glass, there was nothing special about this place, and no real reason to support it for lunch unless of course if it is Monday, when half of Japantown is closed-- which is why I ended up here.
author: Brian J.

description: Seriously as an Korean & foodie, their attitude towards customers and taste for food were awful. I don't want to go there again at all. I expected authentic korean food and kinds of feeling of home,but  nothing. Furthermore I can't understand how they get good reviews seriously!!!!
author: Seon-yeong P.

description:
No matter where I go for korean food, I almost ALWAYS get the mushroom soondubu.  This is the second place I've gone in SF for soondubu and I can definitely say that in terms of the actual soondubu, it's as good as the places I usually go in south bay.  Flavorful soup, good variety of mushrooms, plentiful tofu and well cooked so that all the ingredients meld together into a single dish (sometimes the mushrooms aren't cooked together long enough so that the enoki, for example, is still one big clump).

In terms of the rice, can be improved.  They were going for purple rice but barely had any purple grains, so the rice came out to be neither white nor truly multi-grain.  Also served in a steel bowl rather than a hot stone (my preference).

The barley tea can also be improved - lukewarm at best and more water than tea.

The side dishes were all delicious, albeit a little small in portion.  I think you can request refills but we didn't bother.

Overall, satisfied my craving for hot soup + tofu on a foggy night!
author: Judy L.

description: Food us suck I order bullgogi no meat vegii bullgogi no worst place I ever dine price is high
author: Puje B.

description:
Yet another good option for when I want my Korean tofu bowl fix.  Piping hot, standard fare tofu bowls here.  

My favorite part though were all the sides.  They had the typical kimchi and bean sprouts, but the other three were more unusual, and they were my fav.  Seaweed, some sort of marinated cabbage and cucumbers, and the best, strips of what i'm told were fish...maybe tofu...hard to say.  But those were good.  Plus we all got a fried fish to start us off.  

A tasty option.  Don't know that I'd go here over any other tofu house, but the side dishes certainly would push me back to Doobu.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Doobu is one place were outstanding food makes up for poor service.

Stepping in here on a Sunday night was like living out a real life game of Diner Dash.  One waitress, a dozen tables, and she even did that trick where you do the same activity (taking order, giving checks, etc) to many tables in a row for extra points.  She would not have made expert this level.

We stood awkwardly in front of the "Please Wait to be Seated" sign for about 10-15 minutes until the busboy took pity on us and seated us before returning to the kitchen.

About five minutes later, we got some water and the waitress took our order.  We both ordered a combo, I got the combination soon tofu and he the mushroom soon tofu, both with bulgogi.

The small appetizers were tasty and refreshing.  I especially liked the seaweed and the fried tofu strips.  

The soon tofu was HOT.  I cracked the egg into mine and then waited a bit for everything to cool down.  I knew I had to work slowly because my water glass was never going to get refilled (I'm more stating a fact here than complaining).  The bulgogi was very tender, exactly what I wanted.  And not quite as hot as the soon tofu.  I highly recommend the combination soon tofu, with strips of beef, whole shrimp, clams and oysters (about two each of the seafood bits).  I knew I was burning my mouth but it tasted so good I kept going.

The tofu+bbq combination is a lot of food, and I was very sad when I got home and realized I forgot the leftovers on the table...:-(
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Ordered Lunch speical to-go:

- Spicy pork side was way too marinated (salty?  Jaa?) but mixed with lots of rice, it was pretty good.
- The TOFU soup was terrible...it had a strange odor to it...and that's NEVER good...ewww  :( :(
- The kimchi was pretty decent!  Other sides included bean sprouts with strips of tempura (yum) and miso dressed salad.  
- Large portioned and I paid $10 (plus tip)
- Very friendly waitress :)

I came here cause Playground was closed at the time... I'm not sure if I'd come back ... maybe I can try something else...the bibimbop?  hmm....I'll sleep on it.
author: Kat C.

description:
Reasons why I love this place:

The rice
The fried fish appetizer on the house that comes with every meal
The combination platters
The fried tofu salad

The BBQ is decent, not really the best. But definitely a great compliment when ordering the combination platter. You get to select your tofu soup, which has tons of variations, and hot temperatures for those not into the standard "hot". And your choice of meat. Pork, Beef, or Chicken. I always get the Galbi with the oyster tofu soup. YUM. You also get a starter of fresh fried fish and of course the standard side dishes. If you are a fried tofu fan, you will love the fried tofu salad. Everything is reasonably priced. Atmosphere is cutesy, and relaxed. The servers are always really nice.
author: Natasha S.

description:
the food isn't bad or great. nothing special and the service is horrible

walked in the restaurant and there was a heavy smell of bleach. We asked if we can just open the front door and keep it open. the waitress said she'll open the back door. the smell was super strong so we went ahead and open the front door. less than 5 mins later the waitress asked if the smell went away and to be nice we said pretty much gone since the door was open. she said she was cold so she'll close the door... okay, whatever

went here a few times and it's always the same waitress. short boyish haircut waitress. she gives you that feeling that she do not wish to be there. our table were the only ones there. she gave us the menus and we've decided what to order, she was busy playing with her phone with her back towards us. we tried to call her over and she nodded her head as if she've heard us but continued to finish up with whatever she was doing with her phone.

the only reason why we come back time after time is because of the location. we live close by. let's say that was the last
author: Lillian r.

description:
In a never-ending [not to mention, quite frustrating] quest for the best Korean restaurant in the city, there's bound to be some sour lemons in a sea of oranges [or lack thereof].

friday night
7:30pm

no wait.

sweet.

The limited menu left little to be desired and made my decision easy as pie.

combination soon tofu
seafood pajun

out comes the banchan. 

first thought.

hmm, this is pretty skimp.

The banchan consisted of 5 little dishes: lightly-salted rice vermicelli noodles, crunchy pickled radishes, boiled bean sprouts, pickled seaweed + tiny slivers of daikon, chewy fishcake + onions and a raw egg.

oh waitress, where is our fish?

the question was never asked, the answer was never delivered and the fish was never devoured.

- 1 star

pedestrian banchan

- 1 star

combination soon tofu came out, the egg was broken, the yolk was mixed.

The result was creamy [not-so-spicy], medium spicy, combination tofu soup. 

The Seafood Pajun finally made its appearance and saving the best for last was definitely not the case with this dish. It was extremely greasy and overly-battered to the point of death.  

because I'm feeling rather nice today, I'll spare them the additional - 1 star.

My search continues.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I went to Korea a few years ago and did not have the luxury of enjoying good Soondoobu then, but it feels like had I been able to, it would have tasted like what I had here.

The tofu was so soft and flavorful.  The broth was perfectly seasoned. 

I ordered Galbi with it...that was disappointing. Portion was small and flavor really did not do the price justice. 

I would return, but only if I have a doobu craving.  If I crave for meat I would go somewhere else for sure.
author: TM O.

description: This is by far the worst soon dubu I've ever had. I'm not Korean, but fairly used to Korean food. I ordered vegetable soon dubu, and my colleague ordered oyster soon dubu. Both of our meals came out to be of no taste. I thought they forgot to put some seasoners, but on second thought, they perhaps use tap water instead of soup stock for their soon dubu. Then looking around, I found no Korean customer in the restaurant. Well, no wonder.
author: Mac I.

description: As far as Korean goes, meh.  With all the other options out there, I don't find anything special about this place.  The food is decent. Authentic.  But overall, not memorable.
author: PB W.

description: Love it! Inexpensive... Love it! Fried Croaker.. Love it! Side Dishes.. Love it! Spam and Cheese Doobu... Freakin love it! This place is delicious, it's immaculate and the service is excellent. You will not be dissapointed.
author: Ooh K.

description:
I've noticed over the last 15 years that eating hot food when you've got a tongue bar in doesn't make eating that food any easier. Your mouth just gets hotter, retains the heat longer, and it takes forever and a day to finish delicious things like BiBimBop.

I think I've gotten fed up with it. I finally took it out. Ask me why? It's so I can eat hot food quicker, speak with more diction, and I just got plain tired of burning my mouth. 

Yes, it took me over 10 years to make that decision. I'm smart, but indecisive, and it takes me a while to make a "major" decision. 

Doobu is worth burning your tongue over. Or you could be like me and numb the sizzling sensation of your mouth's roof  with something cold like sake. That's a brilliant combo. Screw milk, give me the sake.

The green onion pancake is killer and not as oily as the other pancakes I've had at similar establishments throughout the city. The sauces were flavorful, and we drenched the pancake in the amuse bouches that Doobu serves up, keeping it's classic lines. 

BiBimBop, sizzing with amazing tofu, veggies, and kimchi. I don't think I can get it any better than that. I'll eat kimchi until I get a sour stomach and can't handle it anymore.I love the crispy little pieces of rice with egg stuck on the corners of the hot pot. Those crispy corners are worth taking your tongue bar out for, but you still may need the sake like me. 

We went early, and were the only people sitting down to eat, but I just didn't want to deal with the business of the crowd and the noise. They feed you quickly at Doobu, so just be prepared with some sort of mouth cooling device, otherwise  you'll feel it for the next two days, and everything will taste like cardboard from a burned mouth, or like me a singed tongue.
author: Danielle S.

description: This feels like a fast food place and tastes like fast food but overpriced.  I ordered the firm tofu with mushrooms which tasted gritty and the vegetable and kimchi pancake.  Plus and iced tea and the bill came out to $32 with tip! Ouch! And it wasn't even stellar or remotely delicious.  It fell into the category of, "it's food" or in this case, "it's overpriced mediocre food". Move on...
author: Favoloso M.

description: We had a big group. Some of the group never had Korean food before. The waitress was super nice and quick. The food was delicious. I thought the tofu bipimbop might be bland, but it was very flavorful. They do need a better vegan selection.
author: Mark S.

description:
HATED: The little fried fish appetizer that was chock full of bones.

LOVED: *EVERYTHING* else!

I ordered the Tofu Soup with Dumplings *HOT*.  I admit, it wasn't burn-my-mouth out hot nor even break-into-a-mild-sweat hot but it was spicy and damn tasty!  The small sides that accompanied the soup (and are typical of Korean restaurants) were similarly delightful.

And then there's the price.

This please was CHEAP!  My soup + appetizer + sides was $10 before tax.

I only wish that we had a place like this in BFE where I live!
author: Evan L.

description:
Tofu house??? There are way too many restaurants to choose from in this little block of Japantown but I had never seen a tofu house and they had Bibimbap (or Bibimbob) on the menu. I hadn't had that in a while. I wasn't too impressed with the Bibimbap because I've had better at Seoul Food in Denver but daaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaamn the Tofu Bowl was amazingly delicious and full of flavor. 
We ordered to share but I wish I had ordered my own tofu bowl. The rice that came with it was flavored with, well, I'm not sure. It was purple and good. The service was great and hey look!!! A surprise appetizer of a fried whole fish. And it's free!! But I ain't eating no head of fish. A great experience overall. And not too pricey for San Francisco.
author: Jay B.

description:
Still. Can't. Find. Perfect. Bibimbap.
It was okay here, sweeter than I'd have liked. 
Again, their lunch box specials and soups are the way to go.
author: jeddie k.

description:
One word: Yummy!

Where do I even start? This place is HELLA good. I especially liked the fried tofu salad, so good! The rice cake (dukbokki) is a must try! 

My most favorite love though, is the Dumpling Doobu soup thing...I forgot what it's called. The portion may seem small but it is really filling!

The squid bibimbap is alright...

The service is great, they're pretty on top of it and are really nice and accommodating. 

All in all, love for Doobu!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Pretty standard soondobu. I got the combination with ribs and the combination soondobu but I was not all that impressed. I definitely agree with the first reviewer that My Tofu House is much better but if you are not in the mood to go over to RIchmond I guess this would be a reasonable alternative. As long as Korean restaurants give me the fried fish thing as one of the small plates I'm generally a happy camper - and they have it here! 

As a summary, this is the place to go for soondobu when you're not craving it enough to really work to get the good stuff.
author: Christina L.

description:
If you're hankering for some hearty rice dishes, I would definitely recommend Doobu for a quick and fairly cheap option.

Whenever I go it is usually not crowded at all, and you can sit comfortably in the large booths.  The meal is also usually accompanied with tons of the small korean dishes, such as kimchi, potato, sprouts, and more - and I LOVE this portion of the meal.  

My favorite?  As weird as it sounds, the corn beef dish was pretty good.  Boiling and piping hot and sits nicely in the tummy.
author: Shay F.

description: if i can choose 0 star i would do it. been there today on the cherryblossom festival, my wife is Pregnant and she felt so dizzy and we asked to purchase a hot water in a to go cup, the male waitress is about to give us the water, but there is a lady came up and said they dont have it to go and her face just look mad and unpatients, i was like WTF ! i didnt ask for free and about to pay and i dont know if she is the boss or whoever, the service is just mean ! how could they do that to a pregnant lady !! i dont care how good or bad the food is at that restaurant, i wont go there again for sure and will also tell all my friends to avoid that place because of the service !
author: Li C.

description:
Yummy!  Hahah I just love that this place is smack dab in the middle of J-Town...right next to the Aloha warehouse (hehehe). 

Anyhow, my tofu Bibimbap was hella good. I can still hear the rice sizzling in clay pot! I loved all those extra crispy veggies and rice that were hanging out at the bottom of the pot. And, they dont skimp on the tofu or veggies! Winner! The BF got some beef dumpling soup and he seemed to enjoy it. Our server was really nice, and for some reason it totally smelled like clorox in there...it kind of gave me a headache. Prices are decent about 23 buckaroos for our lunch here.
author: Trina A.

description: we ate kimchi bibimbop and al-bop. It tastes really good and people are very kind. I want to recommend to you.
author: SuKyung Y.

description:
* Food:
o Presentation: Ok. (3/5)
o Temperature: Hot! (5/5)
o Quality: No. (1/5)
o Dishes ordered: Kimchi tofu soup and bulgogi.
o Tastiest dish: None. (1/5)

* Server:
o Attentive: Yes! (4/5)
o Knowledgeable: Ok. (3/5)
o Friendliness: Ok. (3/5)

* Restaurant:
o Atmosphere: The restaurant was clean since it was newly open. (4/5)
o Cleanliness: The restaurant looked organized and clean. (5/5)
o Cost vs. value: Ok. (3/5)

* Will I revisit restaurant? No, I prefer Tofu House in San Bruno, CA. The soup at Tofu House is more flavorful and less watery!
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description: After a day full of American food, being Korean, we need our Korean fix. After strolling around Japan Town, we came across Doobu and we decided to get our grub on. The place is pretty small and not the cleanest, but the service wasn't horrible and the place seemed pretty busy. My family shared the kalbi, spicy squid, and some soon doobu stew (spicy tofu stew). All of them were pretty standard, nothing over the top amazing, but after Korean deprivation, it was definitely satisfying. San Francisco is pretty expensive in general so it wasn't surprising that the food was more expensive than LA. Pretty good Korean food, nothing to complain about.
author: Sarah P.

description:
This is currently my favorite tofu place for soon doobu in San Francisco. I used to like My Tofu House on Geary but I feel the quality of the food and the service has dropped a lot. You pretty much get the same deal at both places ... tiny shrimps and clams, and small portions of meat. But Doobu has more non-traditional types of soon doobu like corn beef or ham/cheese. Yes, I actually had the corn beef and it wasn't bad.

To me what makes this place stand out more is the better quality of sides. The fried mackerel appetizer is more plumper and looks more fresh here. The side dishes here will actually have fish cake or chapjae, potatoe salad w/ apples, not the cheap plain, boring stuff you get at My Tofu House nowadays. Also, for dessert, you don't get a lame stick of gum like My Tofu House does. You will actually get the dessert drink, shikkae.

What's lacking at Doobu is they don't serve and make the rice in a stone pot like My Tofu House does. So no crispy rice and no crispy rice w/ tea. You just get rice in a metal bowl. Also, for some reason they only have 1 server, so you need to be a little more patient.
author: Daniel L.

description:
yesterday, the Jul 29th i went there with my parents and ate there, and the food there sucks ass, service wasn't  good, asked for 2 bowls of rice waitress seem a little upset. i never seen a place where people dont give rice when customer order  bulgogi, and spicy soups..  Lol
the most funny thing is that our bill came out to $45.50, i didn't want to leave tip for this waitress but my mom forced me to leave tip. So we left $50 on the table before we leave. Guess what happened?  The waitress came after us while we were going to our car and said we didn't leave at least 10% tip. So we went back in and the waitress got a calculator and calculated and found out we left more than 10% tip for someone who didn't deserve any tip and said sorry you guts can go. Seriously she was the dumbest ass i've ever seen in a food places. This place is a joke, rip off.
author: Alta B.

description:
Went with a group of 7 for y Birthday, we got 2 orders of Galbi, A seafood pancake, some chicken and salmon teriyaki, seafood chapchae, Spicy Chicken Wings, and the Vegetarian Tofu Soup. 

Everything was good, well everything except the spicy chicken wings, they weren't bad, just a bit too messy and sour for my taste, Besides that everything was good. 

I'm not too sure why people complain about the fried fish, it's free, if your baby mouth cant handle a few spines then don't eat it.
author: Bruce W.

description:
As far as Korean places go, I don't think Doobu really stood out much. The staff is friendly enough and the food is decent, but there are definitely better places to go to for Korean. Their soft tofu soup was alright, but I had issues with them not having any ice water available. The seafood pancake was generous, but again, quite average.

Overall, if you happen to be in the area and want decent Korean, I'd recommend this place, but if you have the flexibility to go elsewhere, I'd certainly recommend doing so.
author: Ty L.

description: Korean Tofu soup (soon doobu) is their specialty, and Combination Soon Doobu is the best. Try spicy if you can handle it because it's a lot better than non-spicy version.   Their Bibimbap is not good at all but hey, it's been hinted on the restaurant name--Doobu!  Get doobu when you come here.
author: Mizuki K.

description:
Jennifer L., they still have the fried fish; could have been the meal choice.

Still the best + near my home!

So I finally got around to trying their Ham & Cheese Tofu.... It was actually very, very, very good. I used to make kim chee omelets with cheese at home and it tasted similar but even better. Amazing once again!
author: H L.

description: I think this place is great for the price. The food is A-OK, but it's so hard to find anything spectacular these days. Very reasonable and great service.  They open on time and the place seems to be very clean.  I normally get bibimbap but I suppose I should try some tofu dishes in the future.
author: Aban E.

description: Bland Bland Bland, tofu soup felt like drinking spicy water. Only 1 waiter for the entire restaurant. Banchans tasted like they spoiled. Not coming back.
author: David L.

description:
I was worried that Doobu would be disappointing like a lot of the places on cute little Buchanan Street.

Slim pickings for Korean food in SF, but Doobu and My Tofu House are my go-to spots for kimchi tofu soup.

They serve lots of panchan, including that whole fish that I love.
author: jane d.

description:
i only came here once, when i was fiendin' for bi bim bap for several months straight.

it was unlike any bi bim bap i've had.  it tasted...not korean.  i would imagine if you told a chinese person to make bi bim bap, you would get the one that doobu serves.

i don't know if they're korean or not (i assume they are).  but maybe it's like how english speakers flunk english.  just because you're native/authentic doesn't mean you're good at the subject.
author: Erika C.

description:
DENIED
what, do i have something in my nose?

what's this about everyone getting a little fishie?  i saw plenty of little fishies around the restaurant, but none on our table  (nor was there a glass of water, despite our request)  there wasn't much by way of other banchan either.

three stars because the soon tofu actually is pretty good.  each quivering spoonful of tofu goes down soothingly.  

the bibimbap was unremarkable i thought, yet somehow i looked down three blinks after that judgment and i'd eaten the whole damn thing, so that must have been a good sign.

overall, not bad for a bellyful of hot soup on a gray day
author: alice y.

description:
Never had bibimbap before, and now I'm upset I waited this long. Delicious. Just the right kind and amount of seasoning and spice. Tons of vegetables. Loved the crispy rice bits left at the bottom.

And if I liked seafood even remotely, I would have been very impressed by the free whole fried fish they gave us as appetizers.

Points off for the bug in the water, though.
author: Brian W.

description:
Why is it during my last week in the neighborhood, I find all of these really solid restaurants? Why wasn't I exploring more and poking my head around the corners to try these little joints in the 'hood??

WHY? 
*cue tiny violins in background*

Well, as the bf keeps telling me, "It's not like you're never going to be able to go back."

Yeah, well. That's not the point.

I will never be able to walk in straight from work or the gym, sit my lard ass down and inhale spicy kimchee and pork soup with 5 or 6 panchan and a small fish appetizer (on the house!) with a bowl of sticky, purple and white rice. Then, after stuffing myself silly, I won't be able to stroll 2 blocks up the hill back to my place.

Wait a minute.

I guess, since I'll be living in Temescal, I'll have a lot more Korean restaurants to eat through. Along with Dona Tomas, Bakesale Betty's, Pizzaiola, Lanesplitters, Genova Delicattessen, the new Burma Superstar, a ton of Ethiopian restaurants, all of College Avenue....

Hmm.

I guess am feeling sorry for myself for no good reason at all. 

Attitude adjusted.
author: May T.

description:
I really loved the combo tofu soup, and the corned beef tofu soup was pretty tasty, too. (I had it mild, and it was tasty and delicious, not spicy at all -- next time I'll try medium.)

I wasn't thrilled with the kimchi, and the panchan was fine but not fabulous. They do give you a nice little whole fried fish, which I'm always a fan of.
author: Dina G.

description:
Oh, I do love this place. Yes I know I could probably make my way a little further down Geary to My Tofu House, but this place's soondubu is just as good.

I love the dumpling soondubu here. It's pretty much a hot pot of gyozas mixed in with spicy tofu (their level of spiciness can be pretty spicy, so I usually order the medium) and it's got little rice balls in it that makes it fun to eat my soondubu.

This place also serves some awesome seafood pancakes... the dipping sauce that comes with it is divine. 

I'm not a huge meat fan but I have to say that their kalbi dishes are well marinated and doesn't lack flavor. 

All in all, a great little place for these rainy, cold San Francisco nights that we've been having.
author: Lynn C.

description: Right when you walk in it kinda smells like Korean Heaven but when we were asked to be seated it was just like they were ignoring us.  it was really busy but we were dying of hunger and needed to eat pronto so we ended up getting a small table for 2 and adding a chair for the 3rd person.  we got seated and got the banchan and fried fish which were really good and ordered.  i got the beef kimchi tofu soup and my friend got a bibimbap.  it tasted soo good especially because i had been craving korean food since coming back to college. we finished eating and split the check but apparently the waitress who was helping us changed the tip amount on my friends check which was NOT cool.  she called the owner and she apologized and told her to come in and she would give her the amount she wanted back.  my friend kind of brushed it off but i dont know if we're ever going back!
author: Ariel C.

description:
Had lunch here today but been here many times for both dinner and lunch.  The 4 stars is for lunch.  3 stars for dinner so 3.5 overall.  I like the atmosphere here.  Food is tasty but service is spotty especially during dinner (once for dinner, they had one waitress and a full house - felt bad for the waitress so we served ourselves tea).

During lunch, they have the lunch special M-F.  This is pretty good deal with a choice of Spicy Pork, Galbi or Chicken, salad, fried Tofu, Tofu Soup and rice.

It's my pick for a good meal at lunch when in JTown on the weekdays!
author: Ray Y.

description:
My friends and I are indecisive folk, and we found ourselves in J-town unsure of where to go. How about Playground? Meh. How about Tanpopo? Meh, it's so busy. Okay, how about ... uh ... how long has that Doobu place been there?

And well, it was meh. I've admittedly turned into a bit of a Korean food snob since dating a Korean-American up in my new home of Seattle, but the soondooboo here left a lot to be desired. The seafood pancake wasn't anything special, nor was the spicy pork or bulgogi. This isn't to say that any of the food was bad... it just wasn't good or memorable.
author: natalie n.

description: Food came after 45 minutes order.. It took soooooo long time... There is only one waitress in lunch time.
author: Roger W.

description:
I thought I had reviewed this place, well this was my 2nd time here, and the seafood soon soup was the most memorable the first time so I got that again.

DELISH.  So flavorful and perfect with the purple rice they gave us.  BF and I also shared the many mini appetizer dishes they gave us, which included the good ones!  Chapche noodles, kimchi, pickled cucumbers, fish cake, a WHOLE mackerel fish for each person, and seaweed.

We also tried a Sake-to-Me a mango ginger sparkling sake, tasted like one of those IZZE sodas.

Galbi, the most important part of a korean meal.  It was just aight, not really flavorful, and bf said that the HOT SIZZLING plate it came out in didnt even sizzle.  lol i was in the bathroom.  All and all, i WOULD come back for the soups!

PS. I like it here because you get to choose how spicy you want your soups to be.  Not spicy, mild, spicy, REALLY spicy!

of course i got not spicy.
author: kim w.

description:
NOM. I go here when I feel sick and want some spicy soon tofu. I come here when I'm hungover and want some spicy soon tofu. I also come here when I'm about to see a movie at the Kabuki and want some soon tofu. Basically...I always want soon tofu, and this place does a nice job.

I also love the panchan - the fried fish is coated in potato starch and that means gluten-free: YAY! Kimchee is nice and spicy and ferment-y. 

I once deviated from my usual order and got a kalbi lunch special, and it was meh. The sauce was too sweet for me, but the meat was tender and quite edible. I'll stick to the soup in the future.

I recommend highly the soon tofu; I prefer kimchee soup with either pork or beef. It's affordable and filling. Other stuff is fine but nowhere near as exciting as a steamy hot spicy bowl of hangover-slayer.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description:
Word Play.

What comes to mind when I say HOT 'N SPICY.
Carmen Electra + Fergie + Buffalo wings

Teacher, my turn!!

"SOON DOOBU"

The Koreans cleverly turn to soup, especially after a night of drinking. Piping hot soup does the trick and simply "hugs" the palate.

Served in a charming pot, velvety tofu bathes in a spicy and savory soup.
The dark red hues from the soup marries well with a bowl of pillowy rice.

Banchans (side dishes) is all about temperature contrast.  Crunchy cool cucumbers and kimchi amplify the taste buds.

A pan fried fish is also served with the meal.  The friendly service and $10 price tag per dish makes me dance this tango again.

Ending the meal, a yogurt flavor drink rounds out the meal.
author: Rayfil W.

description: Had the spicy pork bibimbap the first time and loved it.  Came back for more the next week.  The 2nd time had the beef bibimbap and it was just so so.  The service was slow even tho there were only 2 other tables occupied.  My water took forever to get refilled.  Then after paying the check the waitress came up to us to ask for a bigger tip!!!!! OUTRAGEOUS! Bad service = small tip.  I guess she didn't get it.  VERY VERY unprofessional.  I'm never going back to this place, just because of that.  Aweful.
author: April V.

description:
I love this place. The bibimbap is excellent! I love both the beef and the kimchi. The first time I had the beef, I woke up the next morning and wanted it again. The service is prompt, it's clean and the only complaint I have is the sake selection is limited. Don't hesitate to eat here. 
I also met a Japanese girl this weekend who eats the ham and cheese Soon Tofu once a week!
author: Krista K.

description:
I like tofu soup a lot.  I was made to discover it during college.  There is nothing like a hot tofu soup with meat on a cold miserable morning or after a tough weekend adventure.  

It is pretty tasty and the meats are also quite delicious, but the negative aspect about this place is the price.  They overcharge, in my personal opinion, on everything.  The soups, the meats, and even the clay pot bi bim bab.  It is very tasty, but I am someone who is always searching good value when I eat, and I do not receive it from this place.
author: Min P.

description: Disappointing meal, disappointing service.  Nothing special about this place.  Out of all the places in J-town, I wouldn't choose to come back here.  There's much better nearby.
author: Tom F.

description:
If you want high quality Korean food, look elsewhere. Everything here is just OK, i've had much better. Service is great though
and food affordable so if you just want your basics this might be ok.
But I repeat, I have had MUCH better.
author: Sandy H.

description:
Had dinner at Doobu last night with friends, since it was so cold in the city after a gorgeous day in the bay and having to drive to face frigid weather it was a nice surprise to find they had chosen to eat warm homey Korean food. 

I had the seafood combo tofu pot, sampled a friend's bulgogi, and our other friend had the bibimbap. All in all it didn't seem like a lot of food but it ended up being way more than enough to eat. I was so full. 

The rice was this bean mixed rice that made it purple that was super tasty with the egg that I managed to cook inside my tofu pot. The clams and mussels were really good as was the soft tofu. The best part was the fried fish that came in addition to the banchan. The bulgogi was tasty, tender and marinated to perfection. We had 2 huge bottles of Sapporo to go along with dinner which is perfect to cut the mild spiciness of the pot.
author: Jessica C.

description: Ok. The complimentary fried fish was nasty! Everything else was pretty good, though.
author: Patrick S.

description: Just went here for lunch and I think the bf said it best, "I feel like I just ate at a Korean cafeteria."  For lunch, the Lunch Box Special is a true value play worthy of 3 stars but the flavor wasn't quite there for me.  The deal, as others have mentioned, is a small spicy combo tofu soup, small tofu salad, banchan (seaweed salad, fish cakes, kim chi), rice, and a portion of BBQ meat for just under $8.  Lots of food for the money, but I would have preferred paying $12 at My Tofu House and getting more/tasty banchan.  I was actually turned off by the kim chi which NEVER happens.  Overall, it's decent (esp if you're in Japantown wanting anything but Japanese food) but not worth a trip.
author: Krystle S.

description:
This has got to be hands down, one of the best tofu soup spots I have had in the bay area. Aside from the tofu being good, even their appetizer is amazing! A little fish deep fried to perfection, only when you eat it once you get it though. The entire fish is edible, because having been fried, the bones are soft and will not cause you any problems if you decide to wolf that down as well. 

During dinner time, the must get is the chicken teriyaki and tofu soup combo. I strongly recommend either their corn beef or ham and cheese soup, both of which are amazing. Although I haven't tried their other soups yet, just those alone are enough to make me constantly go back for more.

Oh, word of advice. Add cheese to your tofu soup (especially for the corn beef one), it makes it all the more better.
author: Kei T.

description:
We visited this place after a movie, so were grateful they were open pretty late on a weekday night.

At first, we were super impressed by this place. As our ordered entries started to come, we were floored by all of the extras that a dish came with... which was not listed on the menu at all. Fried fish, and a large selection of small dishes flanked our main course. We were starving, so were very grateful for the large portions as we sang them praise back and forth.

Sadly, once our hunger started to be sated, we noted that some of the food could have been better as the praise started to diminish. We ordered a steak dish, but really it was almost more of a ground beef and quite greasy as well. The fried fish was also not too great either.

What was amazing was the tofu, though. Although listed as "Doobu" here, most of the menu seemed to mention the place as "Doobu Tofu" and its easy to see why. We hadn't been a fan of tofu prior, but upon trying their extremely good fried tofu salad we have grown a new leaf and will probably be trying more tofu in the future.

So in the end, come for the tofu... but stay away from the meat, at least from what we tried and came to the conclusion of on a less hungry stomach. Place was still overall good, but not one we will probably be coming back to, despite our hunger caused delusions that made us say otherwise during the early stages of the meal.
author: Sami R.

description:
Everdearest BernaDiva,

I fondly remembered how you leaned over to me to tell me "this place gets FIVE stars... they give us our own fish AND our own faux-yakult".

Grrrl, don't be tryin' to sway my review!  Okay, so they gave us our own fish for our banchan... but it was lacking in the flavor department... which is why they bread it and deep fry it.  I like my fish broiled or fried (sans breading).    The rest of the banchan offerings were just aight.  

At the time of this review.. she has since come to her senses and gave this place 3 stars as well.

I didn't finish my combo soup (beef, clams, oysters, shrimp).  It was good but not "OH DAYNGG HELLA" good.  Yes, I come up with my own Likert scale of goodness.  See below:

Goodness Likert Scale is from 0 to 5:

0- HELLA BAD    
1- BAD    
2- AIGHT     
3- GOOD     
4- PRETTY GOOD   
5- OH DAYNGG HELLA GOOD.   

Service was pretty good.  I was diggin' that guy's haircut, but it was too Japanimation for me.  The prices were more decent.... but that's coz I didn't order a tofu soup AND 3 other things.  I paid 12 bucks (including tax and tip) for my tofu soup.  

This place is good, but not a 5 like My Tofu House.  I'd go back coz this place ain't hella bad. forrealz.

Lovingly yours,
grace m.
author: Grace M.

description:
I was so excited to get more mochi from Benkyodo but to my disappointment they won't have the strawberry mochi ready until an hour later. Honey and I were both kind of hungry so we decided to eat somewhere close by until I can get my hands onto those yummy strawberry mochi balls again. We walked by Doobu and then I thought, "Hey I saw this palce on yelp!" So we gave it a try.

Walked in and good thing there weren't a lot of people because 10 minutes after us the place was packed! There was only one waitress so the service was a little slow but I won't blame her. She was sweet. Boyfriend got the lunch special which came with tofu soup, tofu salad, your choice of meat and he chose bulgogi, chop chae?, and a little yogurt drink for $7.95! STEAL! I had the chicken bibimbap and it was a big portion for me, $11.95 and I had to to bring half of it home. I really liked the tofu salad boyfriend had. The tofu was fried and I believe the salad dressing was vinaigrette. I thought it was pretty healthy despite the fried part. I mixed my bibimbap with the chili sauce the lovely lady gave me and it was perfect because I can't really stand spicy. It gave the rice a lot of flavor. 
Speaking of rice I love Korean Restaurants that serve PURPLE rice and this place does! I love you Doobu!
author: Tracy A.

description:
"doobu" has been cleaned up and polished once more.....once a korean watering-hole....evolved into a japanese joint....and now transformed into a "soondoobu" restaurant....."supposedly" specializing in tofu stews.....

tofu stew ("soondoobu") is literally thick....starchy thick......a proper tofu stew should be "hearty" with a clean spicy broth.....

kalbi...."la cut" kalbi....1 cm thick cuts of bone-in ribeye....marinated and grilled.....while the seasoning seemed right....the meat seemed a bit dry...not juicy or moist....almost a reheated leftover taste....was it cooked and sitting for awhile?....off.....

"dweji bulgogi"....spicy pork....again...seasoning seems right.....moist...tender....but...definitely a "grainy" texture....what causes a grainy texture in meats?....answer: use of meat tenderizers...most likely a fruit which causes a breakdown of proteins in the meat.....commonly used in korean cooking to tenderize meats....what happens when you use too much fruit or use a fruit too high in this special enzyme (e.g. kiwi, papaya, etc.)?...or..if you marinate the meat and leave it in the marinade for an extended period of time?......."grainy" textured meat when cooked~!....bad...

dol-sot-bibimbap...(clay pot mixed rice)....seafood or beef...take your pick....loaded with marinated ground beef and mushooms.....spicy sauce had already been added (i normally prefer to add the right amount myself)....the problem?....the rice!...over-watered rice....sticky thick mess....need to measure the water correctly before cooking the rice.....

few various side dishes are served...sweet seaweed...kimchi....fried fishcake...spicy raddish....jap-che (korean noodle)..etc.....the hot fresh fried croaker was a nice start to the meal.....individual rice also seemed a bit over watered......while the interiors was clean and nice....the smell of mothballs was definitely not pleasant inside a restaurant....soju and beer please~~!~!!!.....it's bottled....they can't mess that up...right?....drank away our disappointment....

*sorry dinner, but a good buzz....$106 for a party of three
author: Hen A.

description:
Doobu makes me smile since I can now get my soondubu lust satisified with a quick trip to Japantown instead of a haul to My Tofu House way "over there". (Though I admit I like My Tofu House more than a smidge better). Convenience and location rate high for a soondubu taste tryst.

Mmmmmmm. Silky soft tofu soup. You are my latest foodstuff crush. The version I chose here was made with briny little clams  in a perfectly spiced broth to ensure optimal sinus throb. The tofu was particularly fresh and gorgeously textured.

Lovely array of  panchan included deep fried fish and all of those delightful vinegary , fermented treats. Cute, modernish interior with golden yellow walls and friendly service. Good stuff. Do me Doobu!
author: wendella a.

description:
I walked in highly skeptical.  It smelled like something had just burned.  But when I saw the sign for tofu soup + tofu salad + 3 kinds of side dishes (kim chee) + your choice of one Korean bbq meat (galbi, bulgogi, spicy pork, chicken teriyaki) for $7.95, I knew I had to try it.  Tofu soup and tofu salad?  I need that.

The meal was a bargain, so much food for $7.95.  Beyond that, the food was really good - like the best of mom's cooking, if your mom is Korean.  I only had to wait 7 minutes, so they're really fast (and nice).  They even tucked in a yogurt drink/dessert which was a nice touch and a pleasant surprise.

The food:

* Tofu soup - excellent broth, comes medium spicy (and it's fairly spicy) with two shrimp (the kind with eyeballs) and bits of beef
* Tofu salad - those fried triangles of tofu tasted fresh, the inside was soft and the outside provided a slightly crispy contrast - really good.  The dressing, homemade, was very nice and tangy too.  Lots of sesame oil and rice vinegar.  Yes, they use iceberg lettuce but it wouldn't feel like an Asian side salad w/o it.  They use fresh and crispy lettuce.
* Three kinds of kim chee - all very good.  Some places make the bean sprouts better than others.  These were good, not overcooked.
* Spicy pork - spiced just right, tender, with carrots, zucchini and lots of sesame seeds - delicious
* Rice - even this was special - it looked like red rice

Minor concerns:  

1) Is the tofu soup that comes with the meal the same as their soft tofu soup?  If so, the tofu isn't silken soft but is firmer than most places.
2) You don't get to bbq your own meat.  
3) Why do they served chicken teriyaki?

For dessert, you can have mochi ice cream!
author: Lolia S.

description: Long story short during our meal there was a cockroach that ran across our table, and the only waitress in the entire building was attending to everyone in the restaurant so we were hesitant to address the issue. When she gave us our check (which totaled ~$102) we asked to split it $20 on my friend's card and $82 on mine. When I was putting her tip, I gave her $5 on my card and $2 extra in cash, she stopped me and proceeded to tell me that what I paid her was not enough, suggesting that I pay more (%15 gratuity that only applies to parties of 6 or more, which we had only 4). I was not happy being that the difference she demanded from me was only about $4 extra. After that I didn't want to tip her at all, and told her about the cockroach. When we handed her the dead bug (that I killed personally) on a menu of theirs she took it and flung the cockroach onto the floor. She later replied to us, "what cockroach?" When we asked her for her management she said that there was none and that it was only her. We wanted a number to call the owner but she said that they don't give out that information and proceeded to "try" to call them herself, in which no reply. We asked for a name and a number so we could call them ourselves but she said that there was no management and no one in charge and that only servers come in. That made no sense to me. So, basically she called no one? The more we tried to settle on some type of agreement, the more she got flustered and tried to ignore us saying she suddenly didn't speak English because she couldn't get to her tables rather than easily refunding our money and sending us on our way. Being an hour and a half out of town, we needed her priority, but now 5 days after our visit, we are still having issues with this establishment. We emailed the owner whose information we located online, and after giving her photo evidence with a detailed explanation, she proceeded to call me a liar and accused me of fraud. I am just very embarrassed and dissatisfied with their service and being a loyal customer for over 5 years it makes me sad that I may never eat there again because of such bad service and management.
author: Alex D.

description: They Spicy Tofu soup is amazing. I try to make an effort to come here since it's so close to where I work. When you order it there, they serve it to you in an iron pot that keeps it cooking for a while. The beauty is in that they give you a raw egg to put in your soul which gives it a much brothier texture that makes it so much more delicious. I can't get enough of it. A cold night with this soup is the perfect combination!
author: Michael N.

description:
This might be the restaurant that brings life back into the Peace Plaza in Japantown. First of all, the place is cute as can be -- maze yellow walls with wood booths and an open kitchen (sort of). As soon as you walk in, you can smell what's cooking: meat and garlic. Oh, it smells so good in here.

This is a tofu soup house and it does not disappoint. We got the Soon Tofu soup (medium spicy) with seafood. Yummmmo. We also had the kalbi (called Galbi here), the seafood pancake (kind of like okonomiyaki) and that was excellent as well. It was super crispy and had lots of veggies, octopus bits, and something chewy that I couldn't identify... but I didn't care because it made the pancakes a real standout. 

Our kids had the fried tofu salad (they polished it off and gave it thumbs up). And the side dishes they brought out were also really good -- the silver noodles and fried fish were especially tasty. But the stand out dish for me was the bibimbap. Oy! They come in the stone pots so the rice at the bottom gets really crispy. It is topped with minced beef, onions, mushrooms, and carrots. It was probably one of the best bibimbaps I've ever had. 

To top off the meal, we got Yakult drinks with our check. (In case you don't know what Yakult is... they are tiny little bacteria yogurt drink that Asian people like because they are good for digestion.) Our kids are obsessed with it so they were REALLY excite when the waitress came over with a whole tray. The service was wonderful -- really attentive and friendly. This is our new favorite Japantown restaurant... should tell you the state of afairs when the best restaurant in Japantown (aside from Bushi Tei) is Korean.
author: L. M.

description:
Great Korean restaurant! One of the best place you can have Korean food in Bay area.
Soft tofu soups are kind of main dishes and were pretty good. Their Galbis, fried rices, Bibimbap were all good. I also liked their side dishes a lot.
author: Woosung A.

description: A pleasant surprise for lunch.  I came after 1:00 and the restaurant wasn't too busy.  I ordered seafood soft tofu soup, after the waitress assured me that it was enough for one person... and it was!  The menu only shows the soup, but it was accompanied by a small, whole fried fish as appetizer, plus all of the small dishes of pickled vegetables that come with Korean meals.  The soup itself was good and flavorful.  Medium spicy was just right.
author: Seth G.

description:
I have tried a number of soft tofu places in the city and this is my decided favorite. The sweet waitresses here know me by sight. I know they're thinking, oh there's that girl who brings, like every one of her friends here on a weekly basis, one at a time. There are many repeats of course - I just like coming here with everyone, and multiple times at that. Yes, I have had many amazing one-on-one conversations here and will probably have many more. 

My regular is the combination soft tofu - beef, mussels, clams, shrimp - all in one people, all in one! And what a deal a meal is here, which really earns it an extra star or two. The combination costs $9.95 and it includes the boiling soft tofu, a bowl of jasmine rice, the side dishes, and what seems to be a pan-fried mackerel. The fish is my favorite - I devour it quickly and then head right for the piping hot soft tofu as it is placed before me. They are not cheap on the side dishes either and they'll refill them for you (if you ask nicely..and you should!). I also love that instead of candy or gum, they give you a yogurt drink cup with your bill. I used to drink those as a little kid and I nearly forgot about them until finding them here. Brought back a piece of childhood, alright. :)  A yummy way to top the meal off.
author: Nebula H.

description:
I got the bibimbap and tofu with a friend. i like the fish that they give you as 'banchan', but the not some of the items. 

Overall though, the tofu and bibimbap made my day. I want to go again.
author: Jae K.

description: It was ok. Not the best i've had. It's a small restaurant. There's wasn't a line on Friday night, so that was nice. The kimchi tofu tasted pasty. The Kalbi was good - not too sweet.
author: Valentina H.

description:
I was with my friends in Japantown one night finding a place to eat and we bumped into Doobu. It was a small place but they were prompt into putting the tables together to fit 8 of us. Similar to Tofu House, they have Soft Tofu in clay pot that comes with brown rice and small dish appetizers (fish, bean sprout, jop chae, etc). Also, they have the beef, spicy pork and short ribs that tasted delicious.

If you're into spicy to the extreme like me, this place isn't the place to look for it in. I ordered something that I havent seen elsewhere. The Ham and Cheese Soft Tofu soup in spicy, but I had to ask for additional chili sauce to put inside. It didn't help :( Maybe the cheese was too strong but when i tried my friend's soup that was extra spicy, it wasn't either.

Overall, soup was good. kalbi was good. and some good magazines for you to read while you wait.
author: Nancy N.

description:
I don't know what to say. . . .. . 

I just love this place. Love their spicy tofu soup. A little bit more spicy would be good though, but thats not a biggie.

The food, service and decor, i like. 

I usually come here on a cold evening with my gf. We need something hot and warm, Doobu is the place to be.

Never been here on a packed night, I usually come here in the middle of the week so we get excellent service. So great, my Asian cheap ass tipped her $7 on a $25 bill. Usually Asians = 10% max tip.
author: David L.

description:
One of the best places for vegetarians and carnivores to eat in each other's company.  Though the place touts its tofu (which is really good), at least half the menu involves meat.

I had the tofu Bebimbop.  It was excellent.  Not to mention, i think everything comes with a little preset appetizer assortment of seaweed, kimchi, glass noodles, tofu, and salted fish.  Quite a quantity of food.

The next time I'm entertaining eastern-oriented dinner options, this place will most likely pwn the alternatives.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Tucked into a small space in Japantown, this place serves up good and relatively inexpensive Korean food in a nice modern setting. I went with the Combination meal of BBQ and Soondubu and chose spicy pork with the combination tofu stew. 

I actually ended up with galbi, which was ok and seasoned nicely, not too sweet like some I've tried. The combination soondubu came with shrimp, clams, beef and soft tofu. The ingredients were pretty good and my "medium spicy" broth had a nice kick. Though it didn't have the depth of flavor at my favorite spot Pyung Chang in Oakland.

What is cool about this place is that in addition to the 6 or so small plates of panchan, they also serve one fried fish for each person. We had a party of 5, and I thought it was rather generous of the kitchen. Then for dessert they give you a small yogurt drink, apparently helpful for digestion.

Their drink menu includes soju (unflavored), nigori sake, beer, and different types of Korean wine.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Overall this place is pretty good. I usually go there for the Soon doo bu.

Things to get:
1) The girl server - she's really nice and understands what you want . For example if you say I'd like some water. She will ACTUALLY BRING WATER not like #1 on the list below.

2) ANY soon doo bu (Around 9 bucks) . It's pretty decent. It's no SOCAL BCD but it gets the job done. Comes piping hot so the egg isn't left.

3) Galbi is pretty good. I've got it a few times and yeah it's a bit on the oily side but it's decent

Things to NOT get:

1) THE GUY SERVER SUCKS-- borderline retarded (mostly because he can't speak English). I go here about once a week and pray to god each and every time that this "server" won't mess up my order. But alas each time no green onions for my friend becomes translated to me not getting green onions and no tea.. yeah just try to get the girl waitress. I haven't figured out when she works there but u'll thank me.

2) the BBQ pork- it's dry and there's not meat for the price. Just overall not worth your time.

Things you get regardless:
1) all the banchan (is that how u spell it?) is pretty good. Sprouts, kimchi, the fish cake thing, a deep fried fish, rasdish string thins, and i think kimchi-ed cucumbers.
author: Bryant Y.

description:
This restaurant looks great, is comfortable and has a great cute name. (bonus!) Unfortunately I feel let down where it counts with a restaurant; the food. 

The food is bland, I struggled to put flavour on it.  Not what you expect from Korean food.
author: Alex M.

description:
Formerly Nan is now Doobu.  They try very hard by giving special side dishes such as jap-chae (long rice) & fried fish.

I only order the soft tofu soups here since it is their specialty.  If you like creamy ask for cheese in your soup.
author: HY L.

description:
DoobsU
Great lunch special for $8(bbq beef,salad,fried tofu&soup), quick service and clean aesthetics. 
The special comes with Yakult (well the Korean version), just like home.

Only reason we went there was the name. It got me and probably get many more.

Learned that Doobu actually means tofu in korean (makes sense really as it is a tofu house)

For all you wannabe restauranteurs out there, heres a collection of names that'll get me in the front door: ganjaU, jointU, dankU, reeferU, dankU, BluntU, potU, methadoneU and of course CrackrocksU. Names to avoid DoodU, PoopU, and DumpU
author: Tak H.

description:
I know nothing about Korean food and had no idea what to expect so I feel bad for giving this place a bad review... because it could be amazing for Korean cuisine.. but for me, it was dreadful.  I love to try new places and this was one of those experiences that makes you question why you try new things.

We were totally open-minded when we walked in.  We thought the decor was trendy and cute.. but as soon as they brought out the whole fried fish with the mouth open screaming at me, we knew it was going to be bad.

My chicken teriyaki was ok but the quality of meat was sorta iffy - and the beef in my tofu soup was sorta nasty.. I couldn't eat it and I felt so bad that I asked for a to-go bowl - and then I threw it in the garbage outside the restaurant :(

I won't ever go back but I hope this doesn't discourage others from trying it, especially if you're trying to be open-minded and try new things.  Maybe if it's you're first time you should try it with someone that knows what they're doing?
author: Derek B.

description: Delicious delicious delicious food! I love the dumpling soon tofu soup!
author: Sami Y.

description: Nice atmosphere. Tea is not hot enough. Tofu soup is descent. Small dishes are so little.
author: KBs C.

description:
I tried this restaurant with some trusted Korean food critics and came away disappointed to say the least.  Here I thought I had found a great little Korean restaurant in my neighborhood, but alas it was not to be.

The Soon Doobu was average in flavor and lacked the spice I was looking for despite having requested extra spice.  The portions for both the Kalbi and Daegi Bulgogi were small and the flavor was uninspired.  

I suppose on the positive there is plenty of seating and given it's short existence, the decor is modern and clean.  But the seating is available for a reason - the food is average at best and this is definitely not the first stop you want to make with friends who truly enjoy Korean dining.
author: Drew W.

description: Amazing Korean food - great bibimbap!!! and tasty side dishes! Service is nice.  The food is as authentic as you can get.  You have to go.  Don't just read the yelps.  Just go!!!
author: Sheue L.

description:
My fellow yelpers, you guys are awesome; I tried this place because I was being my normally indecisive self, and you were able to give me some guidance (as usual). I wasn't opposed to something different and I love tofu, so I thought why not Korean (especially since I am not fond of Chinese food)? Anyways I ate lunch at DooBu and was very pleased. 

The menu is categorized very nicely: tofu soups, combo plates, special plates, salads, etc. The even have a really great lunch box special (Mon-Fri) that gets you 3 sides, a main dish, and a tofu soup and salad for $7.95! Too bad I don't work near Japan Town right?

I had narrowed my choices down to the Vegetable Soon Tofu, which is a soup and the Silken Tofu Salad which sounded delightful. I was in a more silken (raw) tofu mood, so I went with the salad. It was perfect, the dressing was light and had a subtle ginger flavor. The tofu was also perf. not too firm, but not falling apart. The chunks were a good size and there were plenty of them throughout the salad. The best part was my lunch was only $5.95. 

I really would like to try their lunch box special soon. Cool place, casual inside, dine-in or take-away, very nice hostesses, open at least until 9:30pm everyday.
author: Theresa T.

description:
Big Plus-you can choose your level of spicyness.

Doobu's food is very good, with tasty and fresh panchan.  Some other restaurants do give you more dishes, but it is more than enough food for a few people.  I have gone for the Soft Tofu Stew (Soon Doobu Jigae) which is served boiling hot from the stove in stone bowls.  Rice is similarly prepared and served in metal ware; water is added to the crisped rice in the stone bowl and served as a end-of-meal soup.  The other dishes are very tasty and appropriately spicy for my taste.  I ate some medium spicy food with a friend and found it slightly flat.

The Yakult has a large load of live Acidophillis culture, and I drank it in Mexico as a GI aid (since I ate food from street vendors).  It tastes like the Japanese Calpico/Calpis.

I knew the owner before I tried her restaurant.  I like her even more now.  Service can be sparse when the restaurant is busy (sometimes only 1-2 servers in the restaurant) so I time my visits to avoid the lunch and dinner rushes.  The bar/counter often has an asian food channel playing.
author: YearOf M.

description:
We were originally going to get some ramen but saw Doobu and decided to get some Korean Tofu.

The food was really tasted and the prices were pretty good too.

The hubby got the combo- doobu (tofu) + spicy beef. He choose the spicy tofu with dumpling. The combo was $16 and it was a $16 well spent. I tried some of his doobu and it was really spicy and tasty. 

I decided to get bibimbap.  It was a hearty portion and had a good amount of flavoring. I've had some where you have to pile on extra sauces and spices cuz they were bland. I didn't have to do that here.

The server was really nice, and did a good job considering she was the only one there besides the cooks.
author: Mary L.

description:
Before Doobu, there was My Tofu House (MTH). Soon dobu in the city was a sad, sad scene back then. Dinner consisted of 1 hour for eating and at least 1 hour of waiting for a seat. The food at MTH was mediocre even when famished. 

Since discovering Doobu during their grand opening week, I haven't returned to MTH once. The soon dobu here is delicious and the must-get item. They also offer other items on the menu (kalbi, bi bim bap, etc), but the soon dobu is the best here. It is a tofu house, after all. With your soon dobu is a bowl of bean rice that they scoop right by your table. Each person gets an individual clay pot of rice. Once they scoop it out, they'll fill the pot with tea (so you can enjoy it as jook later). That's one of the many things I love about this place. The bean rice makes all the difference. 

Admittedly, their banchan is not my favorite. The usual offerings are kimchi, fried crocker, seaweed, bean sprouts, fish cake, and one or two other things. That's my one complaint. The bf says tofu houses are not known for good banchan, but I've been to a few in other cities where both the soon dobu and the banchan were equally delicious. Minus one star.
This place seems to have grown in popularity lately. Good for them! It's also important to note here that even with business booming, I've never had to wait more than 10 minutes to be seated. 

For soon dobu in the city, my recommendation goes to Doobu. The tofu is excellent as is the extra offerings (e.g. bean rice, yogurt drink for dessert). If you are looking for something else, there is always an hour-long wait list with your name on it at MTH.
author: Rona J.

description: Tofu soup is the ONLY thing you must get here! If you haven't had the Doobu  tofu soup, you haven't lived.
author: amit s.

description:
Visit: 9/22/09 - Lunch.  Special bulgogi with tofu soup.

This place is the best.  The bulgogi was great and the tofu soup was better.  Everything was so tasty.  Even the pickles.  I normally don't like pickles.

Service was good.

Price was good.

I will come back.
author: Christopher C.

description:
not bad at all. prob would have been better for me if my friend can eat spicy. 

started off with the fried tofu salad-delish. my fave dish

got the beef bibimbap-my friend said it was really spicy, but i tasted no spice. the flavor was good, but didn't liek the rice. it was like brown rice or something

got the mushroom tofu soup-gave you lots of tofu, but again couldn't order n e spicy. 

i would give this place another try though, but gotta order it spicy! yum
author: Karen H.

description:
I come here when I want comfort food.  Especially when it is cold outside and I'm feeling cheap.  This place has great food for GREAT prices.  

This place mainly serves the hot soon tofu pot so let's talk about that first.  It is delightful and warms you up.  I can take spicy so I get the medium spicy version which tastes great.  But I can see this being bland and not exciting if you get not-spicy or mild.  They have the usual soon-tofu option and a very unusual ham and cheese version.  I'm not adventurous enough to try that.  I have had all the other ones and they all taste great!  Another plus is if you are a vegetarian they do have vegetarian versions that don't use chicken or other meat broth.

Non-tofu dishes.  I have had the beef bibimbap, it is very flavorful and the crispy rice at the bottom is tasty and fun to eat.  All the flavors in the dish work well together.  Another good hearty dish.  The kalbi is good but greasy, I felt like I was going to have a heart attack after I ate it.  But I knew that when I ordered it.

I know some other Yelpers are not hot on the fish.  For me, I go here because I get a free fried fish in its entirety (and a bunch of other wonderful small dishes, good deal!).  If I'm lucky enough, I get a fish that still has roe in it.  I screamed for joy when I got the fried roe last time I went.  The free yogurt drink when you get your check is another plus.

I never had to wait long to get a table.  This is why I stopped going to My Tofu House on Geary and started coming here.  Food is just as good, so why do I want to fight and wait for a table at the other place?
author: Helen C.

description: First red flag: no Koreans. Second red flag: lots of seats available.  Soft tofu soup was overly salty as if to cover up something.  Mixed rice seafood one would think cant get wrong... Had strange color, soy saucey/ teriyaki sauce? Was one of the more undelicious seafood mixed rice I've ever had. Safe to say I wouldn't recommend or return.  One on Geary goes above and beyond the call taste wise.  Went against better judgment and my initial instincts to stay away.  Best thing was the fried fish go figure.
author: Rich K.

description:
A friend of mine told me about this place, and I think they are the best restaurant run by korenas in Japan town! They can't make sushi, but real good korean food! 

I love their tofu soup.  I normally get oyster soup with no spice in it, and put some Kimuchee in my soup when it comes to my table.

My boy friend's favorite is teriyaki chicken and he says it's pretty good too!  Since he hates tofu, he always gets this meal.  I know teriyaki is not korean, but it's cooked with some korean teriyaki sauce I think. 

Rice is also coming with meals, and they started serving purple rice!  My boyfriend was like whatta hell is this!? when he saw it for the first time, but I think it's some sort of beans are in the rice.  Looks very healthy, and taste good too. 

I always like little appetizer dishes everytime I go to Korean restaurants, and at this place, they give you nice fresh fried fish for each person at table! They are yummy too. 

Then they'll give you nice little drinks (Yakuruto!) after you pay.
author: moshi m.

description: I like the bibimbap! the flavoring is really good and the proportions are perfect. the tofu soups however are extremely bland in my opinion.
author: Tina N.

description:
I wanted to give this restaurant two stars but gave it a three because I may have ordered wrong.  We had the Galbi and the Seafood Pajun.  I would definitely recommend NOT getting these dishes.  They will only leave you disappointed.  

Galbi- flavorful but it was not amazing.  It was probably pan-fried instead of grilled.  It didn't have any of that charred goodnes.

Seafood Pajun- oily and lacked flavor.  There were pieces of seafood that were chewy but I couldn't distinguish the taste or the type of seafood.

Complimentary fried fish- awesome.  mostly because it was free. 

Panchan- the free little appetizer dishes you get along with your meal were also disappointing.  It came with only 6-7 dishes and the kim chi felt watery and weak.   

After reading Yelp post my disappointing dinner experience I realized that I should have A) ordered the tofu soup, B) went during lunch when prices are more reasonable.  Unfortunately, I just stumbled on this place and didn't consult Yelp.  My bad.
author: Melanie O.

description:
If you go here, order the fried Tofu salad.  When it arrives, ignore the iceberg lettuce (why is this common at Asian restaurants?) and focus on the perfectly cooked tofu...crisp on outside but oh SO mouth-watering soft on the inside. You get about 8 big triangle pieces for $5.95.  

J ordered the Galbi (short ribs)...arrived on a sizzling platter atop a mass of onions. It was good though not spectacular. 

With respect to the Ban chung,  the strips of tofu are INCREDIBLE...I asked for seconds on this and the waiter obliged. 

I ordered the clay pot Bi Bim Bap--TOTAL disappointment after eating this dish at Sahn Maru. I asked why this dish tasted different from the classic Bi Bim Bap and the woman (owner?) explained to me that they cook all the ingredients. The rice was crunchy...the taste was odd. 

Our waiter was a young man who ran hither and thither...despite him being the only waiter, he was reasonable attentive.

Bathroom was clean, though out of toilet paper. I told the waiter. He couldn't do anything b/c he was too busy...I didn't insist as I was staying (currently house sitting for a fellow Yelper) one block away.

Decor made me feel I was in a Korean soap opera/drama. LCD TV over the bar broadcasts cooking shows. On  this particular Wed night, there was a cake baking contest that totally transfixed J.

Our bill totaled $32 for 2 entrees, 2 appetizers.

I would go back for the Tofu.
author: Grace C.

description:
I dont know why seeing tofu dishes with meat in them bugs me.  I mean, seeing any other combination of meat and vegetables isnt weird.  Oh well.

Anyway, they do have a number of vegetarian items.  I got the bibimbap which didnt disappoint.  It was a little expensive but i thought it was quality plus there are all those dishes of kimchee and stuff that are like an appetizer.  The staff was friendly but it was a little tough at times to get more tea.

FYI the after-dinner treat they give here is a yoghurt drink.  I had to ask.
author: Nessie V.

description:
Outstanding lunch special for $7.95.  Perfectly proportioned and presented in a nice bento box.  Rice is mixed grained (more healthy for you).  A nice selection of salad and cold dishes that perfectly played off each other in their salt to sweet flavors.  And then to top it off...a little yogu drink....

I was truly impressed.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Doobu is really great, went to dinner here with some of my friends and we had a good time, the food is super tasty, and i love my bibimbop in a stone pot, the crispy rice on the bottom is probably one of my favorite things in life.

we ordered a couple beers which entitled us to not only the standard array of panchan but whole fried fish for everyone, rob was able to help out the two of us who were veggie and took care of the extra fish.

Their chili paste is the perfect combination of spicy and sweet. 

the only problem was the restaurant was full and they only had one waiter but other than that, perfect.
author: Jared Z.

description:
Great Customer Service!
 Very homey type of restaurant. Good food and i liked the side dishes.. it's yummy! =)
author: Selina L.

description:
You may think I'm a dreamer.  

But I'm not the Only One.

So good for describing my need for awesome tofupot.  Let's be real here - for the good stuff you still need to go to Cupertino/Sunnyvale over yonder, but this is my fix whilst I am in the city.  

Good fried fish, good make-me-cry spicy, good-ish flavor, good waitress that only needed to be briefly reminded to crack my egg into my tofu, good yogurt after dinner.  

All in all, I give you 4 stars, because let's face it, even though you'd be 3 stars in the South Bay, you're kinda a rockstar over here.
author: Glamorous D.

description:
Been here once. had a Bulgogi lunch special or something and it was excellent. They have greaaaattt tasting side dishes too. I really liked the small salad they served -- the dressing was amazing!

clean. & the customer service was excellent. probably because there weren't too many people in the restaurant.
author: Betty T.

description: i've come here several times before and it wasn't that great, but today I decided to try their lunch menu was pleasantly surprised. I got their lunch Kalbi special (bento box I think) for $8.95 and it was pretty tasty. I got a decent amount of kalbi meat (super tender and yummy) with some special rice, a salad, two pieces of fried tofu and a bowl of small bowl of soon tofu soup. They also gave some kimchi and panchan on the side but those were ok. My only real complaint would be that the soup was lukewarm but it might have been because I left it out for a few minutes while I was devouring my meat. I'd prob go back again for the lunch special if I was in Japantown and craving Korean.
author: Annie T.

description:
I love tofu and I love soup, so I love soondoobu, esp. after a heavenly meal at a Korean tofu place in NYC. But alas, Doobu is not the SF answer to my dreams. 

The Good: Clean, casual, fun ambience; fresh panchan; tasty stews; reasonable prices ($20 per person for very filling food and drink plus tip); and a pleasant, shy waiter with stylish hair. 

The Not So Good: MSG, MSG, MSG; the selection of panchan was small and not that exciting; and three of us wanted to share two combo dishes so we asked if the portions allowed for that, but the waiter said "No, no, they're small. You can't share." But man, it was too much for each of us to get our own combo! We could've easily shared two combos and a side. 

I like Korea House better (on the next street)...
author: Sumi Y.

description:
Why is everyone comparing it My Tofu House?! The tofu soup is decent, but not comparable. The soup is thick and sauce like rather than a soup, I couldn't eat the soup without rice. 
My bf had the lunch plate for $7.95 wasn't bad for it's price. Bulgogi with veggies, served with tofu soup, tofu salad, and 3 sides.
Ok Korean restaurant but there's so many other Korean places around that area that are better.
I did like that they served Jap Chae and fried fish as a side (not with the lunch plate)
author: Flavia H.

description: I like Doobu! Their tofu soups taste soooooo good. And the side dishes they serve for no extra charges are the best! I think the service can be improved, though.
author: Hyewon C.

description:
3.5 stars.

Doobu has a bright orange sign, which reminds you of the fiery soondubu waiting inside. The first thing you notice when you walk in is that the decor isn't too shabby. Pleasant lighting, clean tables. Not all soondubu places can say that. The menu selection boasts some different options such as corned beef tofu soup (??) and ham and cheese tofu soup. But my tastes veer towards the traditional. 

The soondubu here is good. Thicker broth probably due to the generous amounts of tofu. Banchan includes a whole small fish. I ordered the combo dinner w/spicy pork to share. The pork wasn't the greatest, coming in small pieces and sitting in a bed of onions. What I did not see here and missed is the crispy rice in water at the end. Still, they do give you a yo-geu-reu-teu with the bill. Service was just ok, I had to keep asking for things.

In the end, I prefer My Tofu House.
author: Michael S.

description:
I consider this place to be a staple. My favorite tofu spot in the city. Never a crazy line like Tofu House. Sometimes when I come here (not sure if it's the time or what) but it feels like a hidden gem it is so empty. 

You can't go wrong with the Tofu or anything else like Bulgogi. Really big portions. Although I've only been here for dinner (on many occassions), the lunch special looks like an AMAZING deal.
author: Jon N.

description:
Doobu was exactly what I was looking for!  My friend was visiting from Miami and told me I must take her to Korean.  (Apparently MIA is not a mecca for Korean food.  Go figure!)   I wanted something cheap, quick and authentic, i.e. with all the banchan and good kimchi.  Doobu did it for us!

I got the seafood bimbam bop and she got the bulgogi lunch special that comes with the tofu soup.  We pretty much shared everything except the bulgogi itself (I am not a meat eater.)  Then, we also broke down and shared the seafood and kimchi pajeon (pancake).  It was A LOT of food but we pretty much finished all of it.  And, we were out of there for under $30.  I will definitely be back!!!
author: Melissa M.

description:
Not spicy, mild, medium, or spicy/hot?  

I ordered the Seafood Tofu Soup mild since I know Koreans turn up the heat.  Well it came back not spicy at all and it lacked flavor:(  There was a fair amount of shrimp, clams, and oysters in it though.  Came with all the fixin's as everyone else mentioned.  But since I didn't love my soup, the rest was just extraneous.

My friend liked her lunch special.  I can't remember if she got Kalbi or Bulgogi.  Smelled yummy.  *sigh*  If I only ate beef...

I would go back but next time, "Look out Ulcer, I'm going for spicy/hot!"

For now, 2.75 'not spicy' stars.
author: michelle s.

description: Yummy!  Great value, great for groups.  Very sizzle-y, spicy bibimbop and lots of complimentary kimchee and other treats.
author: S C.

description:
3.5 stars

$8 lunch box special is a great deal ... it comes with tofu soup (tastes ok), tofu salad (good), some kim chi (very little), and your choice of meat ...

i got bulgogi, and it was okay ... definitely had better ... there was just a lot of flavor lacking in the marinade ..
author: Anvy A.

description:
There aren't too many non-Japanese restaurant in J-town so this caught our attention to try. The service was friendly and I liked the bright, colorful decor. 

I took an immediate liking to their selection of banchan (small appies) with fried fish. We ordered the soondubu (tofu soup) since it seemed to be their specialty and added the dolsot bibimbop (rice in hot stone bowl). The combo soondubu was good and the beef bibimbop was extra crispy....just the way I like it. I would suggest not to use too much of their sauce for the bibimbop b/c it is not spicy enough and tasted more like hoisin sauce.

This is definitely the place for soondubu cravings.
author: Katie K.

description:
my sister: this is the place
me: doobu tofu?!! *giggles*

my sister took me to Doobu tonight and i must say i was slightly impressed. i wouldnt except to find this cute little korean resturant outside of japantown. the interior itself is very bright and comfortable. i almost fell asleep sitting down in the comfy seats after a long day of shopping!

the restaurant is quite small but she said its never fully packed. all meals comes with free appetizers -- fried fish, vermicilli, and 3 other dishes. i ordered the beef soon tofu which was pretty good. my brother order the bimbibap and i wished i order that too because it was soo good! 

i would defintely come back again and the name "doobu" is very cute. :):)

update: 2.21.08
