i became a regular Doobu customer. this is my favorite place to eat when i am craving for tofu soup especially on a rainy day like tonight. my BF and i usually go to My Tofu house if i was craving for tofu soup but i felt that the service and food went a little downhill. So tonight, on a rainy day i went to Doobu and decided to try something new so i order the seafood pancake and BOY! was i surprise! the pancake was very good, crispy on the ends and stuffed with lots of shrimp, veggies and octupus. but the pancake itself was way TOO big for me! Also, i notice there was only one waitress working tonight but she was still very attentive and always came back to refill my tea. 5 stars for her. my bf and i left her a $7 tip on a $27.00 bill for the excellent service.
i love Doobu! :D
author: Carol Y.

description: Great Korean food and affordably priced.  I'm a big fan of the spicy pork lunch box.  So many great flavors.
author: Mark G.

description:
Good place to slurp down some spicy tofu soup and dismantle the little whole fried fish and chomp on bancha before catching a movie at the Kabuki Sundance theater.  The tofu soup and purplish rice was super yummy.  four hearty stars because service was good, atmosphere is nicer than My Tofu House, food was yummy.

we were so full we almost didn't get popcorn at the theater.

me: want popcorn?
BF: nah, i'm so full from Doobu.
me: sure?
BF: yeah...
me:  Let's just get some. we don't have to eat it all. [I start to order a small popcorn at the concession stand.]
BF:  wait, maybe you should get a medium...
author: Corii L.

description:
I had a birthday dinner here with around 18 friends. We pretty much took over the entire restaurant with our voices.. sorry. It's a pretty small cozy place, so I was pretty surprised they fit us all in there at one long table. The waitresses were really nice. It took us forever to order because people came late, really late. But the waitresses still kept their smiles on and patiently waited. Food was really good. I had soondoobu and loved it. Very moderately priced, or in my opinion, cheap for something in Japantown. 

Very niice!
author: C. Z.

description: First time review long time eater. Was near Japan town and thought I would try this place. We had four adults and two kids at dinner. The waitress took our order fairly fast. We sat waiting for our Kimchee to arrive but only were given the fried milk fish which was alright. We asked about the rest of the Kimchee but was told it comes with dinner. The food arrived 10 minutes later. We had the sizzling pork, beef tofu soup, and two sizzling beef rice dishes. The food would have scored 2.5 stars but then the check arrived which included a 20 percent tip....
author: Israel S.

description:
banchan is delicious plus you can always ask for extra...

the bibimbap is good..

the tofu soup is GGGOOOOOOOOOOOOODDDDD!!!!

whether, beef, chicken, mushroom, or seafood for the toppings...

it's just simply good...
author: chris b.

description:
Hells yeah!!
I know, the thought of a Tofu Restaurant isn't usually inspiring, or food for thought. But, in our search for all the best food in our neighborhood while visiting San Francisco, this was the dope!
Great service!
Informative waitress. When she brought out our hot pot, she told us immediately to crack the egg and add it, and I'll tell you, she has seen this before - tourists wander in of the street...never having this dish before, see the egg...don't know what to do with it (I thought it was boiled), and let the hot, boiling pot cool down before realizing the egg goes in the steaming dish TO COOK.
We cracked the egg and added it to the hot pot of tofu deliciousness  while we all had a good laugh about her comments on waiting too long to add the raw egg "just bad". Yes. Just bad.
The food was so good.
The spicyness reminded me more of Thai food than Korean, yet the soups and noodles were traditionally good. It was one of the best choices of our food tour, if only for the unique surprise we received which surpassed our concept of "tofu".
author: Sherri K.

description:
This is one my favorite  Korean Tofu house.

Reason why??? 
Because so easy to seat in!! No waiting. No long line.

I have no patient for long waiting line.

Also this place is very kids friendly. 
That is  why main reason this place always first choice for us  to go.

Food is very descent. 
 I know some people say this place is just avarage but for me good enough for over roll.

The meat dishes is little bit too small portion but always taste good.

Tofu soup is always very good here.  Also like any other Tofu place you can have a choice how much spicy you want like.

I always go medium. For me still medium is hot enough.


The condiment is well portion and you can ask more if you hungry enough. Usually condiment come with little fish call by Korean."chogi" 

I am not sure this fish English name. I only heard by Korean Name.
It's could be a smelt.
It is white fish with lot of bone but still taste good way they made.

The inside decor is very clean and descent and oriental.

The service of this place is very friendly. Those waiter and waitress almost make me feel like they are my brother or sisters.

I feel so saline in this place.

One of my favorite Korean Tofu house in the city for sure.
author: Faith I.

description:
I'm going to be generous and give this 4 stars. Honestly Korean food in SF isn't all that impressive but at Doobu, it's pretty solid at least the comfort foods. 

We had the Beef Dolsot Bibimbap ($11.95 or something close to it) where you get veggies and meat served a la stone pot. I love smashing the rice against the hot stone and letting it get super crispy. Mmm. You must use patience though and let the rice cook. Very difficult to exercise self control.

The Tofu Soon Doobu is also super yummy. We got the combo Tofu and Beef  Bulgogi ($17.95). You get a mini pot of soup w/ tofu, seafood if you like or other combos that they offer. It's great on a cold day, and the soup is sooo flavorful. You get a bowl of red rice (which I find is such a nice touch) and of course all the Pan Chang (aka small side dishes that accompany all orders). You get 5 or 6 different varieties from kim chee to sweet tempura to chap chae (glass noodles) to daikon. Oh you get a fried fish too. This was crispy and delicious.

The Bulgogi (bbq beef) was served on a sizzling plate with sliced onions. I find this dish a bit lacking. I've had better, where the meat has marinated longer and you simply get more of it.

The best part of the meal is when you're given a mini yogurt drink. Memories of my youth float back. These are a treat and a super special touch to an excellent meal. Yum!!
author: Cindy W.

description:
bubbly cauldrons of spicy soup with silky tofu. yum! I used to love My Tofu House on Geary, but have since been converted after trying this place. The tofu is much tastier (seafood and clam are my favs!), the pajeon not too doughy, and chicken (I like it w/o the goopy sauce) is nice and tender. 

and the little dishes they serve with the meal.. always one of the highlights of the meal!
author: tessie n.

description:
I like the restaurant name Doobu..sounds funny:) This place is located in J-Town. Anyways, my co-worker told me this place just recently opened, so we decided to give it a try. To my surprise, the food was actually pretty good. On the menu, they have several combination meals, where you can choose a tofu soup & a choice of a meat -galbi, spicy pork, bulgogi, etc for a great deal (around $16-$17, which is not bad). 

Everytime i eat Korean food the portions are so huge, that i can never finish it and i have to pack it to go home.

This place is cool, they give you a small yogurt drink as a dessert at the end of the meal.

A little fact, one of my friend's told me that the little dishes that come before the meal, well we're not supposed to eat it as a appetizer, it's suppose to be eaten during the meal. But usually anytime i go out with my friends we are really hungry that we can never wait to eat it.
author: Jenny K.

description:
...for some reason all the dinner dishes i ordered - including the tofu - were blend and not hot. Does anyone know if there has been a change in ownership? Because from what I've heard, this place should be better than what i've tasted.

The decor is well designed, hence the extra star i've added here.
author: Maxwell C.

description:
I think it must be the drunks spilling out of the nearby club that keep this place in business.

Service was terribly slow. Both waitresses failed to acknowledge us for a good 5 minutes despite the fact that there were only two other tables of patrons so we stood and waited reasoning that we were too hungry to drive all the way to My Tofu House. The food was pretty bland so I wish we had made the drive.
author: JaM W.

description:
Ate here on the recommendation of Yelp during a weekend stay at the nearby Hotel Tomo. Unfortunately, it was overpriced and very nearly a joke of a dinner.

It didn't bode well that its two-member wait staff made me stand by the door for an excess of 5 minutes with empty tables and uncleaned tables throughout the restaurant.

After getting our menu and quickly deciding on what to order, it took an excess of 10 minutes for anyone to return. I looked up to realize that the staff kept going back to the same 3 or 4 tables while ignoring everyone else.

They finally brought out the small dishes followed rapidly by our entrees, although in a pretty random order. We were enjoying the fried fish and the miscellaneous dishes when the waiter came around to take our egg. Sure, we hadn't ordered a tofu dish but why give us an egg just to take it away? I could've used it for my bim bim bap.

At any rate, the tofu bimbimbap was decent. Nothing to write home about, unfortunately. The seafood pancake was soggy and flavorless. The galbi, however, was the restaurant's saving grace. The meat fell from the bones and was relatively tender.

The total bill, however, was $46 with water to accompany our dishes.

Overpriced to be sure. I won't be going back.

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description:
One of the nice things about having a toddler who likes to take late afternoon naps is that my husband and I get to enjoy liesurely meals, and by liesurely I mean two to three hours, while she snoozes in her stroller.  Earlier this week, we headed over to our favorite Korean restaurant, Doobu, nestled in the heart of Japantown. 

When you walk in, you notice the clean, simple decor with wooden booths on one side and tables on the other side just before the bar.  A literal layer of warmth emanates throughout the place, an indication of the piping hot dishes being prepared in the kitchen.  Servers are courteous and acknowledge familiar faces like ours.  They bring out a myriad of side dishes including a whole fried yellow croaker for each of us, pickled cucumber, kimchi, fishcake, seaweed salad and vermicelli salad. 

We order the kimchi tofu soup, with beef and medium heat.  The cast iron pot is filled to the brim with silky soft tofu, bits of beef and kimchi, and the pretty red chili flecks characteristic of kimchi.  We quickly stir in the raw egg while it's hot.  It's so good over rice which soaks up the flavorful broth.  The rice, by the way, is a light purple color as a result of combining both white rice and black rice together.  We've had the corned beef soon tofu before but the kimchi version is tastier. 

We also share the seafood bibimbap loaded with mussels, clams, squid, baby shrimp, assorted vegetables like mushrooms and onions, and an egg yolk all piled on top of white rice which has a delicious crispy layer coating the bottom of the sizzling pot.  The only thing that doesn't seem to mesh with the other ingredients is the imitation crab.  Nevertheless, it is very satisfying.

Doobu is the perfect warm-you-up-from-the-inside-out place for a cold, foggy San Francisco day or night.  They give you such heaping portions that it's best to go when you are really hungry, and even then, you will leave stuffed and possibly with leftovers.  One of these days, maybe my daughter will be awake and actually have a chance to enjoy their food.  My son is a big  fan of kalbi so we will have to bring him, too.
author: Dina B.

description:
Soup soup soup. I heart kimchi jigae. They've got lots of soup options, so yum.

Bulgogi and spicy pork are great as well - fairly standard, great flavor.

Lots of great sides to assist.

And where else will you get a small fried fish per person to start off your meal?
author: Angela T.

description:
Doobu vs. My Tofu House

Food:
The tofu soup and rice is much better here than My Tofu House.  My opinion has been confirmed by my friends who've been to both.  The flavors are more robust and the amount and variety of their complimentary appetizers are generous and taste pretty good.  I remember the little fried fish appetizer from My Tofu House was dry and fishy tasting but here it's moist and light.  I also really like their bimbimbop.  The short ribs aren't as good as the regular Korean BBQ places, but not bad.  

Service/Environment:
The environment is definitely very inviting.  You feel more like you're in a well decorated restaurant rather than a white box with some tables and chairs.  Also, everytime I've been here there has been no wait and the service is very friendly.  The waiters/waitresses are the host and bartender as well, so your not dealing with multiple people who will forget to relay the message that you asked for water.
author: Sandy W.

description:
Place is alright. 
Kalbi was pretty small portioned, and made me ask "where's the beef?" It was almost a plate of bones with a bit of meat on each one. 

I got the dumpling tofu stew, and it came with 5 potsticker dumplings and some weird rice cakes in it. Flavor was alright but about 30 minutes later I had major MSG induced thirst. 

Decent but not as good as My Tofu House.
author: Derrick L.

description: Bad service, bad seaweed salad dressing, bad fish. I gave them 1 star because they're open till 10p on weekdays. For sushi in the neighborhood, go to Toraya instead: www.yelp.com/biz/toraya-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco
author: Amy P.

description:
Soon doobu
The sooner the better

I hereby grant to Doobu the right to use the above slogan for free.

I've been coming here now and then for a few years, not sure why I didn't review it, and up to today I would have given it a low 4 stars.  But after today's meal, I have to upgrade them to a low 5.

I ordered the beef dumpling soft tofu stew, medium spicy, or in Korean, mahndu soon dubu, botong mebkeh. 

here's why it's a low 5. they waited until they brought out the soon dubu to bring out the panchan. But then again, maybe that was a good thing, so I had something to distract me as the soon dubu, as always, came out hot enough to cook a raw egg. which is a good thing, because it comes out with a raw in-the-shell egg beside it. as always, I broke the egg into the stew immediately so it would cook. 

In the meantime, I dug into the panchan. It was much better than I remember it being in the past. Not that it was bad in the past, but this time it was excellent: seaweed, kimchi, fish cake shreds, spicy cukes, and one more but I forget. And a whole small deep-fried fish which was just okay but not bad. 

Warning to vegetarians, if you order the vegetarian soon tofu they still automatically send out the fish, the fish cake and the egg, so if you don't want these you need to say so.

but that mandu soon dubu was super delicious, including several decent-sized tasty dumplings, soft rice cakes (similar to Chinese nien gou), and lots of chunks of soft tofu swimming in a yummy, on the spicy side of medium, broth.

some pink rice on the side

Too bad I ran out of stomach room before hitting
the bottom of the bowl.

Soon doobu.
The sooner the better.

Remember that phrase.

On the very low side of moderate. Most dishes $10-13, lunch specials about $8.
author: Charles B.

description: I just ate dinner at Doobu last night,  but have been there previously many many times.  Last night,  I ordered the beef dumpling tofu soup, spicey.  My friend told me I should just order Medium bc the spicyness kills the actual taste of the soup and just thickens the soup.  I thought about it and I AGREE...so going forward I will order Medium so I can actually tasted the soup vs sweating bc the taste is soooo HOT.  I really cant tell the difference from Doobu and Tofu House.  I guess I'm not Korean enough to tell the difference. haha
author: Sandy L.

description:
Love this place!! 

They know how to make (tofu, doboo, doobu, duboo...all saying the same thing)  found this place by an accident.  walked around japan town to look  for some korean food (how irony looking for K food in J town...LOL go figure) there are a few other K restaurant but overpriced but food is about two stars.  

I ordered doobu (combo with seafood & beef) with korean hotness & kalbi (marinated bbq rib).  side dishes came which weren't impressive much.  kalbi is what was expected...very decent.  i want to brag about doobu soup.  this is the best i've tasted anywhere...just like how i remember last visit to korea.  

when craving for something spicy along with some garlic (not overpowering), beef broth base with seafood taste (mainly shrimp)...this is it!!

If spicy (chili based) is your game...you have the winner here.  mixed Doobu soup (beef & seafood), i highly recommend it!
author: B K.

description:
I will not be coming here again.

I don't know if it was just what I ordered, but whatever I ordered was.. well, let's just say - YUCK!

We ordered the bulgogi which was terrible and tasteless. Our bibimbap was better than the bulgogi, but not by much... 

As I looked around to see the other patrons in the restaurant, I thought to myself "they look like they are really enjoying their food... what is wrong with MY food???" and then I thought about it.... there were signs all over for their special tofu soup dishes and even a sign when you walk in that talks about the benefits of tofu....

hmmm... maybe I should have ordered the tofu. Anyway, the next day the bf asked his coworker (who recommended this place and is Korean FROM Korea) and she said we should have gotten one of the tofu soups.

Anyway, I'm no Korean food expert, but I will say that bulgogi is one of those items that everyone and anyone knows about, even if you aren't Korean... so at LEAST that should be decent / good... but it wasn't. 
So, yes. I am judging this place based on it's bulgogi. Sigh, sorry Doobu!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I am a fan of this place! The food is excellent, the portions are huge, the price is so reasonable for what you get.  The tofu soon doobu and sides dishes were delish.

A great casual down to earth place with comfortable booth seating.  The only downside is the strong BBQ smell which fills the whole restaurant so be prepared.
author: Teresa T.

description:
The food here is OK but definitely not authentic in any way. The food is prepared with care and the quality is fine, but the flavors are weak and on the sweet side - They seem to be more of a Japanese take on Korean food (imagine that, a Korean restaurant in J-Town). I should have been tipped  off by the advertisements for Corned Beef tofu soup and Ham & Cheese tofu soup in the entry way. Who puts ham & cheese in tofu soup and why is that a good idea?! Hey Doobu, here's a suggestion for the next tofu soup sensation -  Mayonnaise/Ketchup/Natto  - a little creamy, a little sweet, a little lumpy, with just a hint of unwashed gym socks. YUM-O! Build it and they will come.

The dining experience  wasn't good or bad, just different. In my opinion, you should come out of a Korean restaurant burping garlic and wiping kim chee stains from the corners of your mouth. There was none of that here - The food was definitely polite, a little too polite. 

We had the spicy combination tofu soup, the beef bi bim bap, and kim chee pajun.

The spicy combination tofu soup was definitely pretty spicy, but had a very different flavor, almost like creamed corn and chili pepper. Hmmm...

The beef bi bim bap was OK but had no kim chee or pickled veggies in it. It was pretty much ground beef with stir fried carrots, zucchini, and onions served in a stone pot. 

The kim chee pa jun was pretty good. It had a lot of veggies but was a little on the soggy side
author: Miyas J.

description: I've been here some many time now that i'm sure i could count them all on one hand.  The soup a Doobu is solid, and by solid, i don't mean that it is not liquid.  I've only had the soup here, but that is their speciality, so why have anything else.  I've never been disappointed.  It comes to the table hot enough to strip every layer of flesh from your mouth in a cute little stone bowl, perfect to cook that raw egg that also magically appeared at the table.  The tofu is super soft and the broth is super spicy (though you can pick your spiciness level) and it tastes great.  You also get a cute little fried fish with your order and the little plates that accompany all Korean meals, all pretty yummy.  All of this for a ten'er, and my belly is full and happy and i will definitely be going back many times.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Like most Korean joints, Doobu can get get intense--there's a potent aroma, and it can get hot and sweaty.

But, the food makes it worth it.  The wait staff was incredibly friendly, and they give you a free Yakult yogurt drink with your check (GENIUS)!
author: Jeffrey L.

description: the seafood pancake was ok, standard. it's difficult to find anything bad about doobu, but also nothing that places it higher than other korean restaurants in the city.
author: Ethan L.

description:
in SF, you can't really find a place that'll serve korean tofu. scratch that...a GOOD place that'll serve korean tofu. i'm from LA where i have K-Town right down the street. but i had to find SOMETHING comparable to BCD. 

this place isn't too shabby. i love the unlimited panchan (with most korean restaurants) but i dunno why i like Doobu's panchan a lot. must be that yummy fish cake!

they used to give away Yogoo (yogurt drinks) after your meal, but with the downfall of the economy, so is the downfall of yogoo drinks after your meal.

come here on a cold day if you're in the mood for korean tofu. you won't regret it!
author: Scott L.

description:
Tasty Korean food--large portion of bibimbop (the tofu version was quite yummy).  Large variety of soups to choose from (egg on the side and you crack it in yourself), and all of the side dishes (kimchi, jop chae, fish cakes, etc etc).  

Was kind of freaked out by the full fried fish that was put in front me (on the house appetizer which was a nice touch, but didn't love seeing the head looking up at me!)

Overall a nice experience, and for those of us who don't make it to Japantown very often, it was fun to explore the general area and enjoy a nice and friendly dinner.  Felt very clean too.
author: Tamra K.

description:
dont be deceived, there are actually quite a few korean restaurants in japantown.  ive been here on a few occasions.  the food here is not too bad.

we come in and he led us to a table that was cleared but not wiped down.  we move to a clean table.  they have a couple interesting options for the adventurous people out there - ham and cheese soon duboo and also corned beef.  they also have the option of adding cheese to any soonduboo for $1.  they also have kalbi etc on the menu

they only have one waiter since its not too busy. while my friend was in the bathroom taking a deuce i noticed that the waiter would often retreat to his cubby hole, drink some water and look in the mirror.  he put a little mirror next to the calendar so he could check himself.  i guess in case of any hot customers?

the side dishes were ok.  they didnt taste exceptionally fresh or great.  there was kimchee, seaweed, fish cake, the fried fish, a bit of jap chae.

i got a veggie soon du boo mild.  they give purple rice.  all in all pretty good.
author: claudia y.

description:
I was waiting a few months as well to check out Doobu and it was worth the wait. The dolsot bibimbap was very good, the best I have found so far in San Francisco.  They only confusing part was that the spicy sauce was already in the bibimbap when it was delivered instead of being on the side, but the right amount had already been added. The atmosphere was good as well, The sides were good, especially the kimchi and the fresh fried fish as well.

I would have given the place 4 stars except the service was a bit lacking. True we went on a weekday around 2 pm but the servers didn't check up regularly after they delivered the food, not filling up our tea. I had to literally wave my hands in the air back and forth to break the two servers away from a conversation with a friend that came it.  But besides that the servers were very nice.

All in all I am definately looking forward to comeback to have the bibimbap again!
author: Douglas Z.

description:
Wonderful Korean food, wonderful staff, wonderful price, wonderful experience.  I always feel satisfied after a meal from here, and it is definitely my favorite place to escape from the cold winds of a chilly San Francisco evening.
  Getting into the "nitty gritty" of the place, the space they've created is warm and, at times, homey (largely due to the kind staff).  The food is fun and, from what I've seen, innovative.  I recommend the Corned-Beef Soon Dofu.  It has so far replaced the love affair I had with their Spicy Pork and Bulgogi.  
  Additionally, as a Korean tofu house, DooBu has a lovely array of kimchi that one can enjoy before and during their meal.  As well, the complimentary dry-fried fish is a delight.
  In short, DooBu is definitely on my "food map"/"constellation chart" of San Francisco.
author: Scott N.

description: This place is great. It's pretty inside, and the seats are really comfortable, well the ones that are in the booths. I've been here a few times and the service is really good. The tofu soup is really good and I like their purple rice. The galbi is really good too. I would always come back here.
author: Amy X.

description:
With the days slowly getting colder, one often reaches out for some warm comfort food. What could be better than a nice hot 'n spicy bowl of soon dubu?

I passed by this place a few times, before I ventured in. But it is Korean Town ... errr Japan Town after all. So I was a little dubious of it at first.

On my first visit, I got the Kimchi Soon Dubu. I ordered it spicy. The broth was buttery in flavor, which I found odd. I almost wanted to let the damn thing cool down to see what kind of hardened fat layer would appear. Also, there very little kimchi in it.

On my second visit, I got the Hae Mul Soon Dubu (seafood). This time, the broth lost its buttery taste (which was a good thing). The shrimp was overcooked and lacking in flavor (probably frozen). 

Overall, this is a so-so place. The spicy broth isn't really that spicy or flavorful. The banchan is also just so-so. The people there are nice, but the service can be a bit spotty at times.

Oh, and the Yakult they give you at the end? Think of the taste of the orangey taste of liquefied children's aspirin. A bit too sweet for me.

Hmmm, I wonder what the next Korean establishment in J-town will be....
author: Mobile B.

description: Not a huge fan of Korean BBQ joints, but decided on this place on the recommendation of a Vegetarian friend and was quite pleased! Ordered the flavorful Tofu Bibimbap, and was quite glad that I did.
author: K. C.

description: Order the ham and cheese soon tofu soup.  Sounds strange, but tastes good.
author: Wakako U.

description: Average food. Nothing too great. Hair came out of rice. Waitress ran out of the restaurant to tell me that I should tip 15% because it's dinner time. Enough said...Probably won't go back again.
author: E H.

description: Not the best Korean I've had, although I can't call myself an expert. The bulgogi was alright, tasty enough, but the amount of onions outweighed the amount of meat which was slightly dry. What was good was the seafood bimibap. Although I made a faux pas by loading some on my plate before the sweet sizzling sound stops. The servers laugh at me and tell me to wait for it to finish. I take their word for it. The dish loaded with squid, shrimp, shitake mushrooms and other yummies. The rice was perfectly stewy and crisp at the same time. The crispy crust at the bottom was the highlight of my day. Kudos for the free fried fish for an appetizer and the little yogurt drinks that come with the dessert with the check. And even though they laughed at me, the servers were very nice and helpful :)
author: Farah S.

description:
nice bright orange party inside...or it could be.  service is alright- though today the waitress didn't provide us our place settings until after she served drinks and banchan.  big no-no.  what keeps this place afloat is the decent flavors and reasonable price. oh yeah, a yummy fried white fish is also on the house- score!

me and two homies grinded on beef bulgolgi, seafood doobu, and bibimbap (for super yummy bibimbap check out Kukje Market).  we all were pleased by the speed of the kitchen and surprisingly tasty broth.  The way to go is spicy though this time we did medium...okay..if service was a little better- a 3 and a half.
author: omar b.

description:
still a fan of Doobu for lunch!

even though they've cut their servings a little smaller.  the tofu soup is about 3/4 the size it was before.  the side dishes aren't as complete since they only give you the ones on your serving box.  but the galbi (+$1) is stil worth it becuase i got about 6 meaty pieces.  

Nonetheless, Doobu is still the place to go for lunch!
author: Vincent K.

description: The tofu soup is alright, but I wouldn't trying anything else one the menu. I ordered a Tofu soup + Spicy Pork Combo. I'm a meat lover and when I order Spicy Pork I expect there to be more meat than vegetables. They served more vegies and were pretty stingy about the meat. It tastes horrible. Save your money and find a better place.
author: Isaac B.

description: In the past, I've been satisfied with this place, but our dinner tonight changed my opinion.  The menu said "18% gratuity added to parties of 6 or more."  Actually, it said "15% gratuity," but the owner had taped a piece of paper with an amended "18%" on the menu.  Well, we only had 5 people in our party, so we were quite surprised when the check took extra long to get to our table because the waitress was calculating the 18% gratuity that she thought we should add to her tip.  When we pointed out that the 18% automatic tip did NOT apply to our table according to the terms of the policy spelled out on the menu sitting right in front of her, the waitress inexplicably told us that the 18% automatic tip actually applied to parties of 4 or more.  That's a lie, because I've been to Doobu with a party of four recently and, consistent with the normal practice, we were allowed to determine our own level of tip.  I understand the policy of adding an automatic gratuity to large parties, but please don't lie through your teeth to me and change the policy arbitrarily without any notice to us customers.  Shame on you Doobu!!!
author: Elena L.

description:
Maybe its me, but my husband thought that it warranted a 3 star at least.  When you have a party of 3, and you ask for water...why do they ask if you want just two glasses?  Perhaps its because your "party of 3" happens to be a sweet little tyke of 4 years?  Whatever.  Party of three means 3 freakin' glasses of water dammit!  Anyway.  The best thing about this place is that you can get a bbq and tofu combo for about $15.  Nothing super special to rave about or get on the phone to tell your friends to come and eat at this place, but heck, I'm on a roll.  
We had the bbq chicken which was actually okay and their spicy pork was not spicy or tastebud tingling either.  The husband had the seafood tofu hotpot which he devoured (okay, so maybe HE liked it) but my son and I shared the mushroom tofu, which kind of bored me as they only had one type of mushroom in there...come on now...dress it up a bit.  
A good plus, their rice is purple!  Yes, purple.  Its a mixture of white and wild rices, and its a good "eat me" tactic for kids, but its pretty plain and lacks flavor.  Service...mediocre.  The gal was great, attentive, but she wasn't our main waitperson.  The guy, well, if he took the time to pay attention to us as much as he pays attention to his hard spiked hairsprayed do..then maybe they would have received a three star.  The good thing about this place...if you find it...skip it and head right next door to Fuji Shiatsu to get yourself worked on.
author: T C.

description:
What a pleasant surprise this place was.  In the heart of Japantown, I would never have guessed this place would be any good, but we wanted something quick before the Asian-American film festival. 

The tofu was super-spicy.  First off, let me tell you about the 3 physiological indicators that help me gauge the spiciness of food:

Level 1: My scalp constricts and gets itchy.  This is actually a pretty new phenomenon, probably about 2 years old, after I ate a particularly large dose of wasabi.  My scalp felt like it was on fire, and ever since then, it gets itchy when I experience a medium level of hotness.

Level 2: My left nipple gets hard.  I don't know why, but it does, and it's kind of unnerving.  I noticed this, for some reason, after having the Quizno's hot sauce once day and I could feel my shirt rubbing against my nipple (not that I find their hot sauce hot, it just seemed to have spurred this reaction).

Level 3: My right nipple gets hard.  This takes some super spice to get to this stage.

Anyway, the tofu at this place was right nipple.... err, I mean Level 3.  It was so spicy I actually coughed after taking my first spoonful of tofu.  But it was delicious.

As well, the galbi was quite above average, I really liked it.  The 2 Qs (Quality and Quantity) were pretty high for me, so this place was a real treat.  As well, the side dishes were good, especially the jap chae (which was superior to Korea House).

Overall, I highly recommend this place, it's just a bit shy of Myung Dong in the South Bay, but very good.
author: Stan L.

description: Went with a friend here today after a movie at Sundance Kabuki. I am a dolsot bi bim bop whore. I've had better but it was really good nonetheless. Pan chan was sufficient which is a major reason I love Korean cuisine. The kimchi & vegetable pajun was super-yummy. This is definitely a visit again place. I absolutely loved the waitress and forgot her name. She was the best and so pretty.
author: Larry R.

description: It was good but not awesome.  The kimchee pajun, vegetable soon doobu, and japchae were good.  There were some things that tasted a bit off.  The kimchee seemed old, boricha tea tasted a bit burnt and honestly cheddar cheese in soon doobu?  That sounds downright wrong.  Nevertheless, I got my fill for chigae and it sufficed.
author: Tanya S.

description:
good energy, comfortable booths, nice decor.  

ban chan was pretty good, but the kimchee wasn't spicy and they don't give you as much as other restaurants.   their scallion pancake was the worst i've tasted in san fran - way too greasy.  i ordered  the extra spicy seafood & doobu soup, which  was muy bien, but i had a terrible garlic hangover the next morning...and i usually love garlic.  

not the best korean food.
author: Immer E.

description: The people here are really nice.  The only thing i come here for is the LUNCH SPECIAL.  Everything else is a little pricey but the lunch special is amazing, u get so much fucking food and it is good too.
author: Kenny C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the food at Doobu. It was good, really good in fact. 

I can't speak for most of the dishes, but everyone I went with had some variation of the Doobu chigae and they were all delicious. I like mine super spicy and extra hot...and they were perfectly both just that.

They give you lots of banchan and the service was efficient and friendly.

I would go again in a heartbeat.
author: M. C.

description: The kimchee soon for 9$ is awesome.  You get: a fried fish.  Six plates of things like noodles, seaweed, kimchee, etc.  A bowl of rice.  A pot of tofu and soup, and an egg for good measure.  It's a lot of food, and it's all delicious.  I've never had to wait for a table here and the service has always been fine.
author: Stephen D.

description: One night last week, when we were too lazy to cook again, we went to Japantown to find me some soup. Somehow we ended up in this Korean place and were pleasantly surprised. I ordered a tofu and dumpling hotpot and my husband had a salmon teriyaki. The side dishes were really tasty and my hotpot was great. It tasted a lot better than it looked, so don't be shy to try it too :)
author: Alexandra D.

description: I still love Doobu, but hey, where's my complimentary fried fish!? I came here on Friday with my girlfriends and we didn't get ours! What happened? No more fried fish? Is it because of the recession? Bummer.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Seafood sook soup is good. The mushroom sook was ok. The beef bibimbop was almost good.
author: Christopher L.

description: I've been coming here for a couple years now.  My boyfriend lives in the area so we're able to walk down here whenever we crave Korean food.  This place is YUMMY!!  I have tried a lot of their different dishes and I always come out satisfied.  My favorites are the Spicy Pork Bibimbap or the Kimchi Soon Tofu.  Of course, you can choose the level of spicyness, but I'm usually good with Medium and already sweating bullets.  I like my food spicy, so a Medium is just right.  Everything comes with the typical Korean side dishes and the unique thing about this place is their meals also come with a little fried fish that's really good.  I highly recommend this place.  I remember when I first started coming here it wouldn't really get packed, but nowadays, sometimes there's a short wait to get a table.  The servers are always nice and very attentive.  I've tried some other Korean places in the area, but this one is by far my favorite.
author: Leah A.

description:
The spicy tofu soup (soon doobu - yes, the place is named after the dish) was spicy as hell - they sure weren't kidding.  Everything is a bit on the spicy side in this restaurant - from the abovementioned spicy tofu soup and bibimbap sauce to the fish cake side dish that always are the staple freebies at any Korean joints.  Extra point for making a spicewhore like me *slightly* work up a sweat.

And while the kal bi (korean short ribs) wasn't anywhere near the quality that Korea House or any self-respecting Sunnyvale Little Korea establishments can offer, it wasn't at all bad.  (As a side note, I couldn't help but notice that the quality has been declining at Korea House - I was completely underwhelmed the last time I went there but that's another story).  

But I digress.  Now, going back to the matter at hand - at $17.95, a kal bi / soon tofu combo offered by Doobu is an absolute steal.  

And so is the $12.95 bibimbap, which, unlike any other Korean restaurants that I've visited, has the purple bean rice which gives it a neat twist.  Long after the lunch was over and the lovely lady server came out with a check and complimentary little bottles of probiotic L-Casei Shirota yogurt for the patrons, I still found myself scraping the bottom of the still-hot stone pot.
author: Ange L.

description: My korean tastebuds are probably shitty due to all the crappy korean food in sf.  Nobody will ever beat Korean food in LA but it is what it is.  I was surprised about thw qualty and taste of the korean food here.  The seafood pancake was not greasy and was served on a hot plate.  This was the first time I've seen it served like this.  The kalbi was pretty tender.  The quality of the meat was good.  The combination sindabu was ok.  Wasn't my favorite.  he korean side dishes were realy good.  Everyone was served a fresh fried fish along with the seaweed, kimchi, and the fish cake.   I will definitely be dragging my fatty ass back here.
author: Fatty A.

description: I went here when I was really sick with a fever and felt like something hot and nourishing. The spicy tofu soup lunch set dealio hit the spot. You get a piping hot cast iron pot of the spicy tofu soup (with meat and other stuff in it), bulgogi (thinly sliced marinated beef), rice, some kim chee (I think?) and then a sweet yogurt drink at the end for "dessert" all for around $7. I couldn't eat all that food since I was sick (even if I wasn't it was a ton of food) so I took it home. Leftover Korean food always stinks up my car and my fridge so I think I'll go with a friend next time and share and forgo the doggy bag.
author: lani P.

description: I am really running out of hope for Korean restaurants in the city. This is mediocre at best. Very few side dishes, where the Kimchi is not fresh enough. The (combination) soon-tofu is lacking some main ingredients - or not enough garlic or bean paste perhaps? Also, this is crucial (for me) - to have rice cooked in stone pots...otherwise, it's not a true tofu house. The server was nice but a bit absent-minded and had this naivete that makes me wonder if she is capable of  running this understaffed restaurant all by herself.
author: Audrey L.

description: Pretty darn good place for Korean tofu dishes, despite our spastic waitress. She was so jittery, she looked like she was doing the pee pee dance when taking our order.  I was impressed by the fact that this is the first Korean restaurant I've been too that didn't serve up Korean short ribs that were not super fatty and did not come off the grill chard, plus they were hella good. I really enjoyed the Soon Doobu, Not too spicy and the Tofu was outstanding. The seafood Pajeon was good but, very very filling.
author: Marco M.

description: This place is pretty fabulous. Uber tasty. I always order the beef soondoobu and beef bibimbop, so when I read complaints on the quality of meat I was quite confused. I confess to being a finicky eater and I won't eat anything resembling blubber. My boyfriend always gets the bibimbop too or the spicy pork. I hate pork, but I like their spicy pork. I think this place is better than My Overrated Tofu House. So there. Eat here. They even make you a custom ice pack when you have a second degree burn on your hand. I'm serious. The staff is nicer than your best friend holding a gallon of ice cream.
author: Sue K.

description: This place is definitely better (to me) than the Tofu House.  Similar fare, but tastier.  The panchan is really good:  seaweed, bean sprouts, kimchee, chapchae, whole fishies, etc.  We had the kimchee tofu vegetarian soup, which was hearty, warm, and yummy.  Also we ordered the terriyaki salmon, which was a bit overcooked.  I like the rice, it was mixed with some kind of bean.  The restaurant is pretty clean, and very attractive for a Korean joint.  I would really recommend this place.  Great for vegetarians.
author: Sarah F.

description: Went here for lunch on a visit to Japantown. It was a cold day, and I was looking for a nice hot bowl of Korean tofu soup. Indeed, they had it, and it was good... but not as flavorful as I have had - a bit bland, but I would go back if I were in the area.
author: Marc R.

description: the food...ahhhh...not good.  the soon tofu, lack of flavor, the special spicy chicken and squid...not good at all.  the only thing good about this place, just comfortable seating area and they're not BUSY....will we go back there? NO WAY....
author: Pikachu P.

description:
I must have my Doobu fill at least once a week.  I simply love this place and here are the reasons why:

1.  VERY flavorful tofu stews - my favourite being the seafood tofu stew,  a spicy broth with a taste of the sea from the shrimp (sometimes, they are filled with yummy roe!), clams and oysters.
2. Cheerful atmosphere - simple but bright interior with comfy leather booths
3. Busy but helpful staff - constantly running around but never impatient or rude
4. Freshly fried fish to start, and a yakult as a finale - Need I say more.
author: Karen Y.

description: Look, I'm not claiming to be an expert on Korean BBQ or anything.  In fact, Doobu is the only place I've ever tried in this neighborhood.  All I'm saying is that, it will ever remain the only place I try in this neighborhood.  Bring a big group, get one of everything, and see for yourself.
author: Edith h.

description: Compared to the wait at Tofu House, i rather come here for the exact same stuff. Good Calbi, Tofu soups, but one thing they trump tofu house is their seafood pancakes made on the black iron skillets.
author: Patrick M.

description: Here, the food was just okay =3 stars, but the service was HORRIBLE!! = -1 star. I do recommend the tofu soups and the chicken teriyaki combo, though. Anyways, back to the service. I have never experienced such service in my entire life. First, the waiter there was really welcoming and kind, before we ordered. After we ordered, it was a whole new waitress. I remember eating here with my coworkers and waving my hand in the air to order just a simple glass of water, and fully ignored. Actually, the waiter saw me, came toward me, and then WALKED AWAY. And I'm there thinking, "What the heck?" So yeah. Imagine that. I whole heartedly prefer My Tofu House on Geary.
author: Tara V.

description: I've been here a couple of times and i have to say they are consistent. The food is ok and i like how there is a small korean style soup restaurant in Japantown. What does bother me is everytime I've been there the service was just sub-par. No sugar footing this commentary, leaving us at the table without checking on us after our food was served was just the impression that is burned in my mind. Had places to go and asked for the check twice. Oh and get this, you know how they serve the egg in tact for you to crack it into the soup well I didn't. So the waiter asks if I'm going to use it and I say "no..." he picks up the warm egg and brings it back to the kitchen. So this is just a guess... but I think the egg was going to be served for the next set of customers. Hell, I could've gotten a used egg! I haven't gone back since '09 so hopefully things have changed but they've gotten enough of my $$$
author: graham c.

description: Doobu is a place my friends and I like to go when we're around Japantown and we're craving for Korean food. This place is pretty quaint, and has a small selection of dishes with big flavor. My boyfriend and I like to come here for their lunch specials, which are called "Bento boxes" which come with your choice of meat and salad and tofu soup for 7.95$ and that's a GREAT deal. The dishes that you get to aid your meal are unique as well, as they give you chap-chae, and each person receives their own deep fried fish - very good (: The service is great, the waiters are friendly and the environment is quiet, not overbearing.
author: Terri G.

description: Went there with my family for a birthday dinner so we ordered plenty on the menu. The tofu soup is  ok  but I still think Tofu House is better. The tofu salad was a bit disappointing. The small plates of kim chee was lacking and not like other places. No anchovies! what a disappointment. However they did give full size fried fish..a large plate of it. The seasoning is good but too many bones so annoying to eat especially with kids because we had to remove the bones for them. The seafood onion pancake and bibambop were good though but the hot plates were bad. The chicken teriyaki didn't taste like teriyaki or regular korean grilled chicken. The bulgogi was on the dry side and tasteless. Overall the meat did not taste fresh. It has a weird texture to it.
author: Yenly M.

description:
I've eaten here before and thought it was real good until last week.  I'm sorry to say that I had an experience with bugs here.  Yikes! I know!  I don't like having to write this, but peeps have the right to know.                                     
Was here on 4/20 and ordered a tofu stew.  When the server was handing me my dish I thought I saw little 'black specks' moving about. I thought my mind was playing tricks on me because I was sooo hungry.  When p;aced my food down and left, I  saw all of bugs that looked like black sesame seed with tiny wings crawling from inside the serving dish that the tofu stew was placed in.  I was in shock as they started crawling all over the table.  We called the what appeared to be the manager over and he saw the bugs crawling around and quickly took it away.  He came back and said they'd make a new one for me and asked me what he could do.  In all honestly, there was nothing he could do to erase the sight of that and crazy thoughts going through my head. Appetite ruined? YES!  We told him we were just going to leave.  It got me thinking- do  they even  wash the serving dishes? Where do they keep these serving dishes- on the floor in a dark, dank room? And what kind of condition must the back of this restaurant be like to produce a bug infestation like that?  Anyway, it was real bad.  Doobu.. please, please, PLEASE check yourselves.  I know that was a busy weekend being the last day of the Cherry Blossom festival but as a restaurant, cleanliness has to be top priority.  The image is stilled burned in my head.
author: Carol Lynn M.

description: Had a boxed lunch here last Tuesday, between work appointments.  It was a lot of food for $10 out the door.  I had the teriyaki chicken.  Liked everything but the kimchee (sp) - I've never lived kimchee, so that didn't surprise me.  And the noodle dish had some sort of kimchee like vegetable with it that I also didn't like.  Everything else was great and it was enough food for both lunch and dinner.  Soup was great!
author: Kevin M.

description: If you could earn an Olympic medal in "using Korean hot stone bowls", Doobu would have several.  The dolsot bibimbap here is excellent.  Sure, most Korean restaurants bring you a black stone dish that is fairly hot, but at Doobu it's practically glowing.  And that extra fire makes all the difference, producing perfect rice "crunchies" at the bottom, just below a mixture rich with mushrooms and tender morsels of meat.  The banchan (side dishes) are hit-or-miss, but after experiencing stone bowl mastery like this, nothing else seems to matter at the end of your meal.
author: Chris P.

description: All I've had is the lunch box special, but man, what a fantastic deal. For $7.95 you get to fill up and sample a range of what the restaurant (and , I assume, Korean Cuisine in general) has to offer. If you don't know squat about Korean food, like me, get the lunch box special. You won't be disappointed.
author: Noah M.

description:
MmMm...Korean food!  I normally dont eat tofu, but I love their tofu soup.  The people are really nice here and they always have a smile on their face.  

The only dish that I do not find good is Chicken Teriyaki.  Why would there be Chicken Teriyaki at a Korean restaurant?  Everything else is really good.  

The pricing of the dishes are pretty decent. It's $8.95 for any kind of tofu soup.  Range from $13.95 to $16.95 for Galbi, Bulgogi, Spicy Pork, and Chicken Teriyaki.  There is also a combo which is any tofu soup with a choice of galbi, bulgogi, spicy pork, or chicken teriyaki for the price $15.95 to $18.95.  The food is pretty filling and dont forget about the little dishes that they give you in the beginning.  Each person gets a whole fish to themselves.  

I think this is better than Tofu House!
author: Linda H.

description:
I'm editing my original post and giving Doobu 5 stars because after several improvements, Doobu's tofu is now just as good as My Tofu House!

*****Original Review*****

I live near Japantown, so I was excited to find out that a Korean tofu place had opened up nearby.  I used to drive out to My Tofu House, which is cheap and excellent, but now I can walk.

I took off one star because the tofu isn't quite as good as My Tofu House, but it's still a great place to get a meal at a bargain price.  They do give you a free fish along with their other free appetizers, which is a unique bonus.  The service is great too.
author: Erik B.

description: I've eaten at a few Korean restaurants in the city, but no one has bi bimbap that tastes like Doobu's -- with carrots, zucchini, onions, ground beef, rice, and egg, etc.  -- it has its own unique taste.  Maybe it was because I had just seen Sweeney Todd, but it tasted almost exactly like a meat pie.  Not bad, not great.  Sustenance.
author: Tim G.

description: That food wasn't the best but wasn't the worst. Giving it only one because they ask for a bigger tip. Their service was not the best, they got what they deserved.
author: dennis h.

description: This place is so fun to go to!  It is on a very cute little pedestrian street in J-town, across from the Shabu Shabu place.  We love to go before a movie and have some drinks, fried fish, ban chan and spicy eats.  I think the food is great, but I'm just a stupid white girl, so what do I know?  I am not even sure when to use the spoon and when to use the chopsticks!  I should probably ask sometime...
author: jessica d.

description:
Positives: good combo lunch/dinner, ribs are good, soup is good, sides are good, good atmosphere

Negatives: service is slow, food took too long to come out

Recommend to go to Doobu if you are not hungry and limited in time.
author: Liana C.

description: great food. had the kimchi bibimbap .. IT WAS SO DELICIOUS!! 5/5! my bf had the seafood combo tofu soup - it was good... but not as good as my bibimbap!! i would say 3/5 .... it doesnt look like the picture at all lulz
author: Cindy L.

description: I visited Japan Town for the first time last night. When I mentioned to my friends that I had been craving fried tofu they suggested we have dinner at DooBu Korean BBQ & Tofu Restaurant. We got there at around 7 PM. and there were a few other people having dinner, but the place felt empty. The space is small but quaint. There are colorful geometric paintings on the walls that brighten up the place. Our server/waiter was really nice and polite. He was smiling the whole time. Before placing our orders I used the restroom to wash my hands. The ladies' room was small but very clean and no funky smells. From looking at the menu, I was torn between the meat dishes and the tofu dishes. Later I found out you can ask them to mix the meat with the tofu. I decided on the Tofu Bibimbap. As the menu reads, the tofu is served with mixed vegetables and egg yolk over rice in a sizzling stone pot. My friends ordered the Fried Tofu Salad and the Haemul Pajun (assorted seafood & green onion mixed pancake in sizzling stone plate). As we waited for our meals, an array of appetizers were brought out as a part of the meal. Among the offerings were kimchi, bean sprouts, seaweed salad, rice noodles and what my friend called "fat noodles". Everything was just as it should be. I particularly enjoyed the seaweed salad and the rice noodles. The noodles were delicate and had a hint of garlic. The seaweed salad had a very natural taste compared to the kind of seaweed salad I've had at Japanese restaurants. Before I had had a chance to try all of the appetizers, our meal had arrived at the table. The sizzling hot pot is such a tease. I couldn't wait to dig in but it was definitely too hot! As I write this the morning after, my tongue is still a little sensitive trying to recover some lost taste buds. Bibimbap is a fun dish because you get to play with it somewhat while you stir the egg yolk and watch it cook. You also need to make sure you stir enough so the rice doesn't burn and stick to the bottom of the bowl. It's ok to let some of the rice get crispy though. The crispy rice adds a delicious flavor and nice texture to the dish. I added spicy sauce to my dish and stirred it in until I just had to taste it. The food was too hot but I chewed slowly and drank some water after. Everything just melted together and filled my mouth with a wonderful savory comfort I should feel guilty about. I let my tongue cool down a bit and tried the Fried tofu salad my friend ordered. The salad was a pretty basic mixture of lettuce and carrots, cucumbers and onions. The dressing is really tasty and the fried tofu was a little crunchy on the outside and firm on the inside and didn't feel greasy at all. Before returning to my bibimbap, I also tried my other friend's haemul pajun. It was also hot but it had cooled enough by that point so as not to cause any more damage on my tongue. This dish was a delightful mix of pizza and omelet and seafood and noodles. The bottom was slightly crispy from being on the sizzling stone and the middle was just a little gooey from the noodles. The egg held everything together and you could actually eat a slice as you would a pizza. I finished my bibimbap after touring the rest of the dinner plates on the table. Every bite was just as warm and delicious as the last. It was the perfect dish for a cold evening. After the meal I felt satisfied and still retained the light feeling from before the meal began. Taking this into consideration, and the desire to give a proper review, I decided to order the dessert. Mochi Ice Cream is the only dessert option but you can choose from green tea, strawberry, mango and vanilla. They were out of green tea last night and I ordered the mango and my friend ordered the strawberry. The presentation is cute and simple with the single mochi ball on a small plate drizzled in strawberry syrup. The mochi ball tasted good although I'm sure someone in the back just opened a package anyone can find at the grocery store. I did appreciate the presentation and that it wasn't overpriced. In fact, nothing seemed overpriced at all. I felt the portions were appropriate and was actually surprised that the whole meal for the three of us was just $41.00. Overall I enjoyed the meal and I am truly a fan now. I recommend this place to anyone that wants to try Korean food for the first time.
author: Daisy S.

description: After lots of walking around, Doobu made a very relaxing resting place.  The booths were large and clean, and the restaurant was very quiet (but it was about 2 PM).  My bf and I shared a combo and could barely finish it and the numerous dishes of panchan.
author: Hoa Q.

description: The korean food is pretty good for SF.  Def. not as good as the better places in LA.  The meat quality is good, but the flavor is not all there.  Some minor things missing here and there.  I had a tofu bowl here once and it wasn't as good as My Tofu House.  The meat is better than my tofu house though and they do serve beer unlike My Tofu.  Quick rant... I hate smelling like Korea after eating at places like these.
author: Christopher D.

description:
ham and cheese soon doo bu?!?!?!? weird.

i love that they give you the fish with the panchan.  it's like BCD in LA.  the dolsot bibimbap is not the texture i'm used to, but the flavors are great.  some of the best in the city.

and the doobu... pretty good too.  but i'm too chicken to try the ham and cheese.  i'll stick with what i know, thanks.
author: Steven C.

description: Lunch special was great -- kalbi, tofu salad, soon dubu, rice and 3 sides (kimchi, seaweed and beancurd) all for under $10.
author: Mitzi C.

description: Probably the best soon tofu place in SF.  I've had pretty much the best Korean food in the world in LA , and this place is quite comparable to those in K-town.  Their soup is actually thickened unlike the other tofu houses in SF.  Their side dishes were quite tastey too, and the price is actually a bit cheaper than other tofu houses in SF.  Service was really nice -- and she spoke English, which is a perk for those non-Koreans out there.
author: Latef X.

description:
i've been here a few times, and it actually wasn't too bad.  the soon doo bu was decent, and the ban chan (side dishes) were good too.  

my main complaint would be that it's a bit pricey.  that, and the soon doo bu didn't have enough doo bu in it.  oh, and the lighting could be improved.
author: Matt P.

description:
i only come here for the combo (meat + tofu) or just tofu.  i'd say a 3.5.  let's not lie, i'm a guy, so once you see the first item as "combo", i never really read any more, so i can't comment on the other food.  there's not a lot of joints in sf where you can get good tofu for a reasonable price.  last night when it was super foggy (you know, the kind where it's really indistinguishable between drizzle and heavy fog), it was nice to have warm tofu in your insides, warming your body up.  i know the 20 or so times i've been here, the food is always reliable.

plus a half-star for the waiter with the funky hair, he always cracks me up.  though that's kind of balanced out by the fact that their pan-chan is kind of limited.  good, but limited.
author: Jason J.

description:
Korean restaurant in Japantown.  

I was the first to arrive for a party of 6 on Saturday night at 7:30pm.  We had reservations but they didn't really seem necessary..maybe not until 8pm at least.  The waitress was completely unaware that I was there staring at her but that was my only bad impression of Doobu.  Once she noticed me she was nothing but attentive with a sweet smile on her face.  

We had the beef (galbi), chicken, combo tofu bowl, seafood pancake, and a bibimbap.  I'm no expert on korean food but I do know that I love their small dishes.  Everything was noticeably fresh (except their VERY bitter cucumbers which was odd).  Total bill came out to be a little less than 100 including a bottle of soju.  6 ppl? worth it.

Not a super nice spot or anything but you can tell its clean and I would like it if a date took me here ;)  PLUS: nice plasma tv to watch the olypmics!
author: Vivian L.

description: This is the best Tofu house around - as good as My Tofu House on Geary.  It's clean and with nice decor.
author: Jonsee J.

description:
we tried some other korean bbq place within walking distance of doobu and it was horrible (both food & service) and really expensive.

so considering that, doobu is great!  their lunch sets especially are a fabulous deal.  it sucks i can only get those when i have a day off work, but that is my special treat on those days.

i like their bulgogi because it's got a lot of veggies in it.  (could have less onions though!)  their tofu salad is also delish although oily at times.  plus the brown wild rice thing is awesome since i started swearing off white rice.  and sometimes at dinner, you get these tasty noodles and a small fried fish with the side dishes.  and instead of a wad of melon gum at the end of the meal, you get a yogurt drink.  nice!  

they're open fairly late and it's great to have them in the neighborhood.  something else to fall back on other than on the bridge (or OTB as we call it) and suzu.

p.s. interestingly, 'doobu' has now worked its way into our daily vocab.  as in 'i need to doob.'  'doob or doobu?'  'doobu!  i gotta go bad.'

p.p.s. if you go to doobu (or any other korean joint for that matter) and order chicken teriyaki, you should be shot.
author: Miss K.

description: The soy milk is okay but isn't sweet . The teriyaki is decent . The kimchee is okay . The kimchee tofu was okay but wasn't flavorful enough for me . I ordered spicy but it wasn't all that spicy . They  only have brown rice at this place .. they don't have white rice . I like how instead of gum , they give you one of those small yogurt drinks . However , most of it is frozen so you have to wait for it to melt . My friend ordered a combo meal of kal bi and tofu soup for around $18 which I think was pretty worth it . This place is okay , but I prefer the tofu house in Richmond .
author: Eileen L.

description:
tried doobu couple times and each time was always a great experience. good vibes too! definitely generous for a lunch meal. the spiciness is perfect for a caucasian like me yet not spicy enough for asian spicy monsters. haha 
i like the yogurt drink they give at the end of meal. service can be spotty but they are nice enough. i would assume the servers are all korean since they r speaking in korean. DUH
author: Richard K.

description: Went there for lunch and they don't serve soon doobu as the name suggests at lunch time.  Had the spicy pork lunch plate and have had better in many other places.  I'll give it a shot one more time when they are serving their main dish. Out of the 4 dishes served at table not one was great just mediocre.
author: Yo Y.

description: Colorful interior. Helpful staff. Great barley tea. The food didn't make me want to throw up. I did not feel the symphony of flavors in my mouth from the BBQ, but at 8 bucks plus tip, what can I expect. Check it out. Support your local restaurant.
author: Lams L.

description: Delish.  I had tofu kim chi soup and battered/fried tofu salad.  My partner had the spicey beef bbq.  It came with six separate included appetizers and tons of rice, the double booth table was covered with dishes.  The food was exceptionally good, perfectly spiced and soup very thick and hearty.  The tofu salad was great esp with the small puddle of great dressing to be soaked up by the tofu.   Service is extremely good and attentive.  Pleasantly surprised by this fairly new place.  You will not be disappointed.  My friends dish of bbq was huge.  Appetizers included a small whole deep fried fish.  Go.
author: William G.

description: I'm not discouraged, although I had tasted better.  The set lunch menu is reasonable for under $10 w/tax...salad, rice, spicy tofu soup, teriyaki or bbq,or spicy pork, dessert (although I'm not a fan of go go yogurt) and 6 different sides to compliment your meal.  Nice, modern decor, flat screen tv, fast service.
author: Kui T.

description: Love this place, the tofu soup is legendary and the Bulgogi and Galbi are amazing ! Nice touch with shallow fried fish as an appetizer. 5 Stars !!
author: Lisa M.

description: Went in for lunch while wandering Japantown.  Service was a little slow, but it was well worth it.  We tried a tofu pot, bibimbap and a lunch special combo.  Everything was delicious food and the prices were very reasonable!  Well worth another visit on my trip to San Francisco!
author: Kelly S.

description: Simply put: This is the best sundubu I've had in the city!  Minus one star because I think one of the side dishes they gave me was not the freshest.
author: Allison Y.

description: This restaurant hits the spot every time.  So far I've ordered a few of the soup options and tried a friend's bibimbap (have to say the soups are better), and have been extremely satisfied after each visit.  The soup is complete with a fried fish, several side dishes including vermicelli, kimchi, marinated veggies, etc, and a raw egg to cook in the soup which is always still boiling when served.  This restaurant not only has some of the best Korean food I've had in Japantown, but also is clean and nicely decorated.  I highly recommend this restaurant, especially to anyone looking for a hot, satisfying meal on a cold day.
author: Seema K.

description: Came back recently with my husband and it was DELICIOUS!  It's best to come when it's not too busy or service will suck.  Nothing was forgotten this time and we both got our own individual fried fish...yum!  And they weren't cheap on the side dishes this time.  With the prices of the entrees here, you're practically paying for the side dishes...I think they is true in all korean restaurants.  Their fried tofu salad is delicious!
author: Katniss B.

description: cheap for SF - and they give you a lot of food.  dig the fried fish and all the ban-chan.  the combo (soon doo bu and side of BBQ) is a bargain and worth getting.  i've had better of both soon doo bu and bbq - the soon doo bu is too thick and broth could be better.  but great value for a quick no frills lunch/dinner if you're in the mood for korean food in SF's jtown/ktown and don't want to head out to oakland or brothers.
author: Nana S.

description: Delicious tofu soup, Kalbi and side dishes. Most of all, they are very cool to my 2-year-old even though he makes a mess every time. Clean, serene atmosphere as opposed to some of the tofu houses that tend to be a little hectic. There's been a few restaurants in this spot in the past 4-5 years. The last one was another Korean joint  called Nan, I believe. I hope Doobu sticks around. Highly recommended.
author: Patrick A.

description: Since I live around this place, I come here frequently. The food is good, and the pricing is quite reasonable. The only problem is that it gets really crowded starting from 6 pm. There's usually one or two waiters, so expect some waiting.
author: Marina C.

description: For Vegans and Vegetarians let me recommend this Korean restaurant with several dishes that are quite good. The hot spicy clay bowls have many different selections, two or three if I recall that are vegetarian. One can choose the level of spiciness for your dish, if you love spicy dishes and you think you can handle it, go with spicy! (Spicy is like fire breathing, don't do it unless you are a veteran). Go with with medium so you don't over kill the flavor of your dish. As far as cleanliness, it see they maintain this place very clean, and the staff is always welcoming. Some may ask about the rice because it's a purple tint, let me just sprinkle you that it's mixed with wild rice which makes it taste a lot better and gives it that color. During these winter times this is a great location to come and have a hot bowl. Oh! Being a Korean restaurant there is the traditional pre-condoments including fried fish! Not my forte but i thought that is worth mentioning. Finally try the HITE beer as a light ale worth having after work.
author: Oscar G.

description: I love this place. I can't get enough. I always get the tofu bi bim bap or the tofu soup. One of the few places I've found a really good veggie bi bim bap. It's good, it's hot. The tofu is nicely crisped and the rice gets crunchy on the bottom. The yakult at the end always seals the deal for me.
author: Aditya B.

description: We came on a Tuesday night, and the place was almost full!  Although it was the evening of Veterans day, maybe most students has that day off?  Got seated right away and waitress took our order relatively fast, considering she was the only one covering the front part of the restaurant.  GF and I shared the Seafood Soon tofu combo w/ Bulogi.  I love how they bring out all the kimchi-like sides in small plates, so you end up w/ something like 7 plates covering your table.  There's kimchi, sprouts, and a bunch of other things i can't remember, all pretty good though.  You have to order rice separately though, but it goes well w/ the spicy tofu.  The tofu is a bit spicy and very soft, and we got a decent amount of Bulogi as well.  Overall, a bit expensive but better than the generic korean food I'm used to in Berkeley.  YOu used to get a Yakult yogurt drink at the end of your meal, but we didn't get anything this last go-round, so maybe she forgot?  Nice ambiance, ok service, above average food.
author: Chi N.

description: I have mixed feelings about this place.  I can't deal with MSG at all, so I called ahead, and they assured me they don't use any.  The Tofu Soup I had was delicious, and I loved the warm, inviting atmosphere.  I'd decided that I'd found my new favorite Korean tofu soup restaurant, but as soon as I got home, I had a major MSG reaction (swollen joints, thirst, digestive upset).  Reading some other posts that mentioned a similar reaction, I'd now have second thoughts about going back.   Too bad; I'm sure they can cook just fine without the chemical additive.    For now, I'm going back to My Tofu House, which is as delicious, and for sure doesn't use MSG.  If only My Tofu House were cozier!
author: Michelle K.

description: I'm not really a fan of the soondubu here, although I can't quite pinpoint why-- it's something about the soup. You do get quite a bit of food, and the banchan are pretty high quality. Note of warning about the fried tofu salad: they use super-firm tofu in this dish, unlike the soft tofu used in the soondubu.
author: A. T.

description: I had the chicken bibimbap tonight.  Wow, that was pretty good.  Again, ew on the fish, but the condiments were good.  Service is a little slow, but the guy who works here has to cover all the tables.  He is really nice though and it's not his fault.  Bathrooms could be a bit cleaner.  And when it gets really crowded, the smells from the kitchen permeate the dining area.
author: Brian L.

description: I waited for this place to open for at least 3 months.  I am a big fan of Korean soon tofu (kimchi, no meat), and I live nearby.  So, if this place was good, I was set with my meals.  But alas, it was not to be.  Maybe I don't know Korean cuisine, but I do know tasty, and my soon tofu was not near tasty.  So after months of waiting, I go back to thinking about the soon tofu at Hahn's Hibachi in Palo Alto.  I know it's a chain, but the food quality and taste is different at every branch.  I've been to 4 so far, and the BEST one by far is the branch in Palo Alto.  I go there occasionally (sometimes once a week when I have a craving) for a fix because it's just that good.
author: Lisa F.

description: It was late and my boyfriend and I were in J-Town so we found Doobu since I love a good bibimbop. The starting dishes were just okay. I ordered bibimbop and my bf ordered spare ribs. His ribs came first and the meat was very low quality - hardly any meat on the bones and what was there was chewy and tough. Then my bibimbop came, but they said they had run out of rice so I had to wait as my bowl was getting cold for rice. Then the purple rice came and it didn't mesh well with my food so I asked for regular white rice but they didn't have any. Also, it was pre-spiced with hot sauce. I wish they had said that on the menu as I like mixing in my own amount since I can't handle that much spiciness. Also, the ingredients on the bottom of the bowl weren't a little crispy, they were incredibly burnt black! Bleh. I ate a little bit of it, but it wasn't tasty. Still, I asked to take it home and they took my mostly full bowl then returned with a tiny takeout box with only about half the amount of leftovers that there were. Bleh. Don't waste your time or your money here with so many better places to go.
author: Katherine C.

description: Standard Korean tofu soup with a good variety of banchan...it's good for what it is and the quick service and clean ambience works for me.  It's a go-to spot since I live so close...for whenever I'm craving tofu soup.  I will keep coming back for sure :)
author: Marsha L.

description: never tried this place until yesterday 'coz it looks pretty cheap from the outside, but thanks to my friend yesterday i discovered its inner beauty!
author: Evan P.
